Keep walking and discovering!. This is a wide boulevard and not a passage as the name suggests. It is mainly lined by various Gaudi buildings along with some other architects. Unlike the Ramblas, there is no sense of crowds here. It is a very pleasant walk from one end to the other. However, be careful as you walk around, since you will be looking up most of the time!
Lovely. Was a really nice area, lots of buildings to look at and good food! At pizza here and it was fresh! Easy to get to
Watch your bags!!. My phone was stolen here while i was walking one street to another. Keep your bags in front of you and be aware of your surroundings!!!
Lovely elegant street. Definitely not to be missed...very elegant street and Gaudi's buildings well worth seeing. Just a very pleasant walk.
Shopping center!. The main shopping center with all the boutiques. Expensive, touristic, but if you are looking for specific shopping, then it might be the right place at Barcelona.

Great area lots of interesting shops. Passeig de gracia is a great area witg all kinds of lovely bakeries and llitle restaurants with a variety of high quality shops that range from exclusive to affordable (mango zara etc) its a nice place to go for a stroll or dinner or tapas and drinks with lots of great places open in the evenings.

Gorgeous avenue. It is a must in barcelona! The architecture is amazing, including Gaudi´s important works like Casa Batló and La Pedrera. Full of nice stores, high end boutiques. Great walk of the city. Avoid eating in the restaurants in the main street, usually very touristy and a bit pricy. Don't miss it!
Full of life. A cosmopolitan street, full of life! You can have your walk, shop or eat. There's also an access to metro station. Casa Batllo is on this street too.

A street full of treats. This avenue is a delight to stroll, from the top with Casa Mila (La Pedrera), through the houses in the Block of Discord, down to Plaza Catalunya, where you can cross one block to walk down La Ramba. Lots of places to stop and eat, expensive shops to browse, and fantastic Modernisme facades to photograph.

Shoppers Delight. On one side was the rodeo drive of Barcelona with high end stores such as Chanel with two Gaudi buildings- La Pedrera and Casablanca Batllo. However, at the other end near Las Ramblas there are also plenty of stores with high street prices. Definitely worth a visit.

Look up and around. This is the street to visit if you want to see Gaudi's domestic work and also the work of other early 20th century architects. Do take time to go inside one or other of Gaudi's houses. But be careful with the traffic.
High end shopping. Great street to walk up and down for shopping or just window-shopping. All the high end stores you can think of.

Very nice!!. At Paseo La Gracia will will find the best hotels in Barcelona and the best stores.Lots of restaurats, nice walk and good shopping.You can walk and enjoy El Corte Ingles, Zara, Gucci, Channel and stores that you will find only in Spain.There are also a lot of places where you can have coffe and just enjoy the view.One of the nices places in Barcelona.

Beautiful and alive. This is essentially the neighborhood directly north of Placa Catalunya. Lots of great shopping. Beautiful streets to stroll during the day with mature trees, fountains, grass areas.For dinner one night, had some delicious Italian food at a charming small eatery in Gracia off of the Fontana Metro station.

The Rodeo Drive of Barcelona. High end stores (LV, etc) hotels, restaurants and two great Gaudi buildings you can visit (buy tix ahead online) all within a few blocks! Wide boulevard great for walking. Metro stop as well.

Great shopping mile. I believed it to look a lot like champs elisee in paris. Lots of fancy stores, you'll find you're Starbucks frappuccino along the way down to the promenade. If you're looking for cool stuff to wear, look there first.

Shopping. Passeig de Gracia - a paradise for shopaholics. It's a long street full of shops well known brands. From luxury boutiques to democratic brands. Clothes, shoes, bags, jewelry, cosmetics - there is everything for the most refined taste. Also, there are restaurants that make up the strength and snack tapas and seafood. And, of course, on this street are placed such famous sights as La Pedrera and Casa Batllo.

Shopping Hell. OK. I'm a male, females will think differently. High priced fashion houses and overpriced cafes are not my thing, so I'd steer clear of that area unless you want to visit Casa Battyo. The waiters in the cafes seem bored in general and make very little effort to speak to you in Spanish (which may be an advantage for some). To me this is NOT Barcelona at all, just a big city that could be anywhere. Even Las Ramblas is better.

Shopping and more.... The most beautiful shopping street of the city. Very beautiful walk for those who love fashion and expensive clothes. There are also the famous Casa Batlo and Casa Mila of Antoni Gaudí. Worth the walk across the avenue.
All the big name shops. All the main big name shops really...Mini Oxford street. Not my scene on holiday but still a nice area
a very chic street. This very wide street boasts a significant number branded shops for the discerning shopper. There are a couple of landmarks worth visiting like "La pedrera" and "Casa Milo"

One of the best streets in Barcelona!. Unmissable when you go to Barca! So much great shopping and also just off Las Ramblas. The reason I love this street to much is the Gaudi buildings you pass such as Casa Batlo. Well worth a visit!
Passeig de Gracia a must to visit. It is a very crowed, but it is a place that you have to go when you go to Barcelona, lots of restaurants, stores, shopping, etc Love this place
Park. One of Gaudi's great works. The mosaic benches as well as all of the buildings and works in the park were amazing.

A Great Street for a Stroll, for Shopping, for Museums, for Food. In short (if you began by reading my title) a great area for just about anything you might want in Barcelona. The metro station of that name is a vital one, and it's not difficult to get to other parts of the city if you'd like to, but I had a great time just taking my own private paseo along it. I'm betting most people would - if not for that, for some of the finest examples of the modernista architecture, including Gaudi's Casa Batllo and farther up his La Pedrera (aka Casa Mila) actually on it, and for several others easily accessed by turning left or right and walking a block or two from it.The Passeig ends, as far as I can tell, at the Placa Catalunya, from where you can continue on the various Ramblas, also charming walkways, though it gets a bit frantic south of, and not quite as classy. I'd definitely include it in your itinerary!
The Boutique area of Barcelona. Fantastic array of shops and restaurants in a bustling area of Barcelona. The architecture of the buildings is absolutely stunning 10/10
We just loved the walk, sometimes for a couple of hours, there is so much to see. liked everything, disliked nothing, excellent large walking pads, and...very CLEAN STREETS !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The main shopping street and transport hub. A very busy and central location. Excellent for high street shopping with an array of local and international shops. Some interesting flagship stores and a number El Corte department stores dotted around.
Pretty main street. It is a very wide street, lots of cafes, restaurants and stores. Taxis readily available, centrally located. Not overly touristy as Las Ramblas can be
Shoppers paradise. Every shop you want to look in ! Wow could have spent days here everything from Zara to Chanel, ate at a lovely place called Browns where the food was Fab !
Lovely place. What an interesting and beautiful place. Loads to see and do and if you do people watching there is no better place!

Must do but i was Robbed in it's subway on the weekend. The Good: all brand shops, lots of restaurants, cannot visit Barcelona without visiting it.The bad: as it's very crowded as a main metro subway " Passeig de Gracia" especially on Saturday morning, I was robbed while boarding the metro. Everybody is trying to get out while others getting in, in a fraction of a minute, I was bushed from behind by an old lady who stole my wallet from back pocket. It's like magic I realized it immediately but it's too late!. I only lost cards no Money but reporting missing cards is time lost. I wear my money in a hidden place.So enjoy but be extra careful and learn from my experiance.

Always return to walk the Street. Wonderful street, full of all kind of hi end shops and places to eat.extremely secure. Lots of old building in perfect state of conservation. Some of the old houses must be seen. Gaudi lives in spirit in some of the buildings.
Lovely strolling boulevard. Wide street, attractive architecture, including some Gaudi houses. Nice restaurants in the area. Taxis always at the ready.

A Wonderful Stroll. A visit to Passeig de Gracia is a must for both Shopaholics and Architecture buffs. The principal buildings to look out for are La Pedrera and Casa Battlo, however, look around and up as there are stunning buildings the length of this wonderful street.
Nice street in the heart of things. Just round the corner from our hotel. A nice wandering around street. Quick link to La Rambla where there are lots of eating places.
All time attractions :). Amazing Passeig, morning , noon and evening always there is something to see and to do. but in the evening (late hours) check for your wallets...

The Champs-Elysees of Spain. Passeig de Gracia is a beautiful stroll down a boulevard with wide, wide sidewalks. All of the designer shops that you could imagine. If your home base is La Ramblas, and you want an easier walk (that is, downhill), take the metro to Lesseps (on the Green Line), and walk back. You can't miss two of Gaudi's architectural works enroute: Case Mila and Casa Batllo. While being alert to pick-pockets is always good advice, we never experienced a problem.
Many Stores and Shops. Passeig de Gracia 1 is the Apple Store - an amazing one, made with Barcelona's natural architecture. The whole street is packed with stores - from clothes to electronics...

Beware of bag snatchers.. while you are lulled by the sight of designer stores on the one side and Gaudi structures on the other, bag snatchers take full advantage. We witnessed two nattily clad young men requesting an Asian tourist couple to take their picture. Before we knew it, the tourists had their bag snatched. Passers by caught one of the young men, but his accomplice vanished with the bag. Do not underestimate the many warnings of crime in Barcelona. This happened at 5:30 pm in broad daylight on a busy street.
Beautiful shopping and great architecture. All the major Designers have shops along this beautiful walkway. In addition you get to see great architecture including Gaudi's La Pedrera and Casa Bitllo.

shop till you drop. If shoppping is your thingthen this is the area to do it big time. Every corner one turns you find another wonderful experience of clothing, food and entertainment. Walking down Cala Gracia we found a square off the main drag where there was a human castle building competion in full swing. The competition has been held annualyy in May since 1995 and was amazing. We spent over 2 hours in awe of the physical agility of the competitors

Beautiful area. This is one of my favourite neighbourhoods in BCN. Just loved how leafy green the area is. Truly a beautiful place. The architecture has so much flair and history to it. I enjoyed strolling around the avenues and absorbing the atmosphere. This is a great place to sit outside a little cafe and order a cappuccino. Some great little shops in the area too. This area has some amazing buildings such as Casa Batllo and Casa Mila. Great for photos.

Beautiful. Great street to walk down on a sunny day, quite a few good restaurants for tapas, paellas etc can be found here. Lots of designer stores located here as well, in the case that you're looking to buy something nice it's basically all here, not as much recommended for shopping particularly if you're travelling on a budget but a nice street to walk down nonetheless leading you to Placa de Catalunya.

Great window shopping, plus enjoyable walk. Yes you could be in London, Paris or Rome, but the casual attitude and clothes makesIn a very enjoyable and relaxing experience, and the shops and prices not bad either,From H&M to Versace , if you want something a little different , Ramblas CatalunyaRuns parallel to Passeig de Gracia, with some very enjoyable restaurants, and coffees bars,and individual clothes shop unique to the area.
One of the best streets in barcelona. An excellent way to start your vacation here, beautiful promenade full of restaurants, cafes and shops and the most creative buildings of Gaudi.

Shopping on Gracia. A street full of high class designer shops and good restaurants. Although an obvious tourist venue it still felt very Spanish. Also the location of Casa Ballto and La Pedrera two great examples of Gaudi's architecture.

Shopping galore!. This passage offers everything from designer shops to small boutiques of unique clothing and shoes, trinkets and souvenirs. Great street restaurants for a nice glass of wine paired with Marconi almonds and delicious olives.

Pricey but worth it. We stayed on this Fifth Avenue of Barcelona. Highest end stores, many cafes, well-dressed people. Very comfortable and safe. See both of the Gaudi houses here, or walk down to the Gothic Quarter for "old" Barcelona. If you can afford it, stay here.

Surprisingly relaxing place to walk. Given the location in the central part of Barcelona and the plethora of shops, this street is surprisingly quiet, both in terms of vehicular noise and in terms of sounds from people. It makes for a nice break from crowded tourist spots. Aside from window shopping, one can enjoy the views of the exteriors of Casa Batlló and Casa Milà. This is a great free diversion in Barcelona.
Upscale shopping street. Lots of people and lots of upscale stores. It was fun to walk down the street, but the shops did not call my name really.
walk on gaudi's tiles. i love walking on Passeig de Gracia... Look at the tiles, the shops, the avenue, the Gaudi houses (Casa Batllo and Casa Mila)

Shopping Galore!. This is where the good shopping district in Barcelona is. It is at the top of Las Ramblas (opposite end of the water). It has great stores like Kiko Makeup, and Mango. There is a metro stop that will take you close.

Pedestrian paradise. One of the great pedestrian walkways I've experienced. Thanks to angled corners, this street and others in this section of Barcelona are made for strolling. The assortment of elegant shops makes window shopping an Olympic sport. Tired walkers can stop for a coffee or a glass of wine at the many outdoor cafes. I was impressed with the lack of cars -- there were many buses and taxis (all ad-free) - and the assortment of scooters - a popular mode of transportation in this city where parking spaces are rare and expensive. Like Washington, DC, Barcelona in this section at least, has very low buildings giving walkers a nice sense of scale and a lot of beautiful sky to crown their ambles.Passeig de Gracia lacks the street scene of the nearby Ramblas that goes past the market and other attractions, but it well worth spending some time and clocking some miles along this impressive street.

Walk. Do walk down the street to placa Catalunya, turning head both ways - there's architecture and life all around. You don't even see the passing traffic, there is so much more to grab your attention.
Fab!. Brilliant place to visit. If you get chance go see as it's amazing to wander round and reflect. Wonderful.
Overrated. Walked by this part of town. Nothing jumps out at me that you would not see in large towns or cities.
Epic. Nice, safe clean, loads of shops hotels and places to eat highly recommended! Transport links are just beyond wonderfully wonderful!
Much better than Rambla!. If you want a proper shopping street with - I must add - quite a bit of fancy stores -> Pick the Passeig de Gracia.

Don't Miss it. Passeig de Gracia is around 1 km where you can do shopping, business, eat, drink and see architecture of Barcelona as "La Pedrera", "Casa Batllo" among others new and old buildings, these connects with Plaza Cataluña and obviously with "Las Ramblas".When I was there, I went to "El Nacional" located in number 24, This restaurant has different choices of Food: Tapas, Fish, Meat and Wine Bar.

If you are into shopping this is for you.. I do not go to foreign countries to shop at stores that are also in other foreign countries just as I do not go to Starbucks in foreign countries. But if you are interested in expensive stores to look or buy then this is perfect for your needs. Just not for mine.
Chic street. You will find all the good stores in this street. There is "La Pedrera" and "Casa Batlo". You cannot miss " El Nacional", a bunch of restuarnts and bar in a single place. So cool.

simply the best. this stretches from catalunya to the north of the city and houses every major shop you can think of together with some of the finest hotels (Mandarin Oriental just as 1 example) and shops (try Tiffanys and Burberries).it is best to travel to Barcelona with empty suitcasa and fill them up on Passeig de Gracia.It is at the intersection of the metro lines which gives easy acces to any part of the city.Just stroll along the wide pavements, stop at one of the many tapas bars or just relax with a coffee watching the world go by.it is a part of Barcelona steeped in historic buildings and many bear the hallmark of Gaudi.it is for shopping, meeting friends and family and just for people watching although that can also be said of most of Barcelona
How do you rate a street?. The place to be in Barcelona. All the best in dining, shopping and proximity to Gaudi houses, and walking distance to many of Barcelona's prime attractions.

Better than Chalps Elysées. The same kind of grand boulevard with all the same flagship stores but in a nicer climate. And much more affordable to have a drink on a terrace. Lots of beautiful buildings, including the phenomenal La Pedrera. A tribute to the era of hope and belief in limitless possibilities early 20 th century.
Great shopping street. You have wonderful shops like zara, mango but also channel and prada. Also in the street, you can find historic buildings! + there are good restaurant on that street.

The chic place to spend your money in Barcelona (or just take a stroll). This is the classy area of Barcelona where you'll find all the designer shops. Not really the place to go shopping unless you're window shopping or part of the 1%, but it is fun to look. The African immigrants selling cheap knock-off handbags in front of the stores when they're closed (holidays, etc) are really annoying and it seems the police look the other way.
Nice shopping and area. It is a very nice shopping area and walking there is very pleasant. The Gaudi piece of art make it more charming

Sip coffee, shop, drink beer, see Gaudi's works.. Beautiful street, must go in BCN. Walk through Passeig de Garcia to see Gaudi's buildings at some locations, expensive designer shops if your wallet allows you, good small and medium cafes in the streets off the passeig. Do not go to Starbucks or other chain-shops, believe me, the BCN cafes are far more superior than generic North American coffee. Even if you are a budget traveler, go to this place.

Beautiful!. Whether you're a shopaholic or not you will adore this street. Beautiful buildings and trees lining the road the whole way down. Lots of upmarket stores as well as lovely restaurants and cafes. Could have wandered down there all day!

Vibrant. Passeig de Gracia is a vibrant and bustling street in the heart of Barcelona. It has plenty of designer shops as well as stunning buildings and transport links. You don't have to go in to any of the shops, simply wander along the street, not forgetting to look up, to take in all the magnificent architecture.

Big street to walk. Passeig the Gracia is a very big avenue where everybody can walk and chill. It's about 2km long, so there is enough space to walk. There are also lots of shops, the most famous ones. There is also "La Pedrera" and at the end there is Plaça Catalunya, so it's a great place to be.

Elegant area, easy walk from Las Ramblas. Passeig de Gracia is an elegant shopping and dining area and a short walk from the end of Las Ramblas area near Placa de Catalunya. You can also see some Gaudi buildings in this area as well.
Lovely street. It is a really nice area full of shops and bars/restaurants. It is not on my top 10 list for Barcelona but it is worth a visit.

Take your wallet. Some fantastic and expensive( exclusive) shopsas well as some beautiful buildings and wide tree lined avenues. If you want to eat orjust have a coffee then if your budget is not huge then explore the side roads, look where the Spanish/locals drink and it can be half the cost of the same fare on the main walkways and just as good.
Classy!. What a wonderful experience! Stylish, upmarket, showcasing the best. Apart from the designer shops, have feast of architecture. Just sit on the pavement benches and enjoy!

Fabulous street. Designer boutiques and fabulous restaurants including El National (which houses tapas bars, a fish restaurant, brasseries, cocktail bar). On this street you will also find Gaudi's famous La Pedrera
nice for shooping. Better to sight see than La Rambla. Luxury shops and also good shops. Not so crowded like la rambla, with some of the best atractions of barcelona in the walk.

Shopping, cafes, gintonics. The main top stores are here, and there is also a reasonably priced European chain called Mango that has great prices and cute outfits, particularly in its Kids' store.
Many cafes and tapas joints offer outdoor seating, the better to watch the parade of fabulous Barcelonians.
Lots of shops and restaurants. Very wide street,with huge selection of brands, including disigual, bershka and many more .great restaurant along the street, lots of taxis

Beautiful street. Our hotel was just off this street. What a lovely location. Lots of gaudi examples. Keep on walking in the opposite direction from placa catalunya towards the gracia district where it starts to get a little more villagey.

Good for special highlights. This is the road to the Gaudi homes, and lots of mega brands, the latter did not interest me much but of course the former is the pull factor for many people. There are nice eateries that branch off here but personally i did not get a huge kick out of the street per se.
Elegant area. Lovely wide avenue, with plenty of opportunity for window shopping, lots of designer shops, and places to eat.

I just love to walk. To many tourist but this "passeig" its just beautiful, this city is lovely, but please do not eat near this street, to expensive and you will not eat how you expected, too many tourist places made for tourist to spent their money

Shoppers paradise. An attractive wide street with trees and pavement cafes and tempting shops. Intersting buildings including some of thr Gaudi houses. An enjoyable way to spend a morning drinking in the architecture while having a little retail therapy.
Nice street. A lot of big fashion names but also not so expensive brands. You can definitely find something you like and the ambiance on this street is great.
A passage to the past.... Understanding how all the buildings in this area relate to each other is key to appreciating the beauty beyond what you see. Well worth your time.

5th Ave in Barcelona. The architecture is amazing, just walking on this street is a great experience. There are many retails stores for those who like shopping as well as restaurants and spas in the adjacent streets. Two of Gaudi's attractions are nearby. Passeig de Gracie is conveniently accessible through the metro.
Shopping on Passeig de Gracia. Lots of high end shopping and a beautiful street to stroll on. Lots of people everyday in Barcelona and most stay up all hours of the night on La Ramblas.
Beautiful and fun. Many of the main sights are on this tree lined street. Restaurants, shopping, museums. Good people watching.

Beautiful and safe. My husband and I stayed at hotel sixty two on this boulevard. Definitely very safe. We walked out at different times during our three day stay and felt vey safe. Lots of shopping(for those who love brands/designers). Good transport, restaurants, cafes and shopping centre. Walking here is a must. Beautiful architecture, trees and helpful locals.Easy to get to tourist attractions, metro and the airport is only 4 stops on the Renfe train.(4.10 euro for a single trip)
Stylish street. Great shops if you have expensive tastes. It also leads to the the central Plaza Catalunya, full of glamorous 19th century architecture and with grand fountains and statuary

For shopping or just walking around. This is the street where you can go from Diagonal to Pl. Catalunya, going down, to the sea. A perfect place to walk and go shopping. Some of the main modernist buildings are just there (Pedrera, casa Lleó i Morera,...). Also some of the most exclusive clothing shops, if that is what you're looking for. But what I like is the wide sidewalks, the modernist lamps, the open space feeling, the Casa del Libro and the Vinçon!
Great shopping, high end. A rambla with it all! Shopping, Gaudi, restaurants and shade. This city is just too beautiful and clean. The he rest rooms are also free.

Let's be real. This must rate as one of the best boulevards in the world for browsing amazing architecture and up-market shops. The architecture is the thing. Really, the shops can be found almost anywhere, with a few exceptions. It's mostly a great spot for anyone with a retail itch to scratch but way more interesting for the architecture. The retail aspect is undermined by the unfortunate individuals who are begging: even had I been there to shop, there is no way I could spend money frivolously when people are in need. They are not in your face as one often finds in various countries in Asia. They sit, maintaining what is left of their dignity. Did I help them? Well, no, not much. I hope that this entry will prompt people to think about why they are here. For the architecture, fine. To shop, why? Maybe that helps the overall Catalan economy. That is good. But, ok, I am a bleeding heart. I would rather give my money to local traders in less affluent areas of this city than to multinational traders.

Shopping Haven. If you're into shopping than this is the right place. All the big branded stores including Chanel, Hermes, Bulgari, Cartier, Prada, Longchamp, Mango, Zara, Desigual, Rolex, etc are all here.
Wonderful window shopping. A beautiful, wide boulevard lined with designer shops galore and outdoor cafes for tapas,pizza, and more.
Some of the Best High End Shopping in Spain. Beautiful shops, streets, food and people. There is almost every major higher end clothing store you could want, and a wonderful street to walk down.
Must see. If you make to go to Barcelona you can't miss to walk through this area. It's very nice and beautiful and free!
Buzzing & vibrant!. There is a convenient mix of bars, restaurants, small and corporate businesses, financial institutions and high end stores, all against a mountain backdrop.
Give time to this street. Walk and admire. Every building here is a masterpiece. I don't care so much about the fancy stores but the modernist buildings everywhere are stunning.

designer shops and good tapas bars here. I very much have an affection for the Gracia area. When walking up the street? an area to the right and running parallel with the Gracia is also worth exploring. Plaza de la independencia sometimes hosts a barbecue for the local community (ticket can be bought for it in situ). Great atmosphere/food and fresh herbs adding the flavour to the barbie. good to stop at one of the bars in this square and get chatting to the locals/students etc.

great place to stay!. Our hotel is on this boulevard just up from PdG metro, a fab central place to stay. we have Casa Batllo one block down & Casa Mila a few blocks up. La Ramblas is one block over, with lots of tapas bars in it, these are ok, along with the ones by our hotel, but there are better ones around a short walk off the main drag.Unless you have money, it's mainly window shipping along this street, with Chanel, D&G, Breitlig, etc, but up at Diagonal you have to Viacon design shop which is quite interesting - but pricy!

Wide pavements, designer shops. A very long and wide avenue with a lot of designer shops dotted on both sides of the road and some amazing architecture including some of Gaudi's well known works like Casa Batllo, La Pedrera.
Lovely choice. Enjoyed my visit here. It is one ne of its most important shopping and business areas, containing several of the city's most celebrated pieces of architecture. Worth a visit.
Nice place to walk. Lots of shopping along this road, mostly upmarket like Chanel and Jimmy Choo. Wide walkways and trees lined the road. Casa Batlio and La Pedrega are all along this street.

Stroll and enjoy. The scene changes throughout the day and evening. Weekends are different than weekdays.
Shopping is great. Good restaurants. Lots of sites to see to.
Worht a walk by. Nice place to walk by and check some stores or restaurants. The architecture is also beautiful is some areas.

Beautiful Experience.... Lovely place to explore...to walk with someone you love...enjoy sidewalk cafes together...take in the art and architecture...beautiful, charming and romantic especially when combined with visits to the Casa Batllo and Casa Mila!

Nice buildings, nice shops, nice avenue. This is one of my favourite streets in Barcelona. I love its architecture, the paving stones, the trees, decorations and, when feeling like going shopping, the shops!
Modern part of Barcelona. A wide Boulevard with beautiful modernista architecture, lined with designer shops and restaurants. Casa Mila designed by Gaudi is also on this road.

Beautiful avenue. upmarket and Designer shops rub shoulders with Gaudi styled buildings.
This is a wide tree lined avenue with plenty of pedestrian friendly areas.
It is on one of the most beautiful streets in Barcelona.

Lovely Area. A lovely,peaceful and safe upmarket shopping area.All the top shops are here!
Don't forget to take plenty of money with you , you will need it.

Shopping Heaven. My wife was in shopping heaven On the Passeig de Gracia. Lots of high end stores mixed in with Zara and Mango for smaller budgets.
Bring your high limit credit card or mucho euros.

Shopping in Barcelona. All the big international brand names plus Spanish and local shops on one magnificent street. Also Hotel, Bars, Cafes and Restaurants. This is the heart of Barcelona for the Shopaholic.
What a Main Street wow!!!. Sensational main shopping street in Barcelona . If you have time walk up and down both sides ... A tree lined street ...wonderful
Gracia. Nice street, full of attractions and usually crowded. Lots of restaurants and bars to sit and enjoy some good tapas!
love it. the vibe of Passeig de Gracia is so good, it is grand and beautiful. With so many beautiful buildings, so much history, great food, designer shops, you could spend an entire day here.

Beautiful wide boulevard - simply stunning architecture. This is one of the most beautiful streets anywhere, with gorgeous architecture and top name brand shops and hotels in these historic buildings. Two Gaudi buildings are on the street along with other superb examples of Modernist architecture. Better than 5th Avenue!
Shooping. All the big Trade name shops was in this street.Spanish restaurants ,and also international restaurants you can fiend it in this street

An interesting street to walk though. A high class, tony, commercial and residential district lined with boutiques and offices, a lot like the Champs Elysees in Paris or Fifth Ave in the fifties in NY. The block of discord includes three famous buildings, reviewed separately.

One of the best shopping streets in Europe. This is a very long street with all the best shops from LV to Prada as well as top high street stores such as Mango, Zara and Massimo Dutti. It stretches from the Passeig de Gracia to Las Ramblas and is very wide. There are some great tapas bars dotted along the street and numerous buses serve this thorough fare. The Casa Batllo as well as the Casa Milà which are huge tourist attractions are also situated on this fantastic street...probably up there along with Paris's Champs Elysees and London's Regent Street.
Loveliest street in Barcelona. Everything is glamorous and fine tuned.Enjoyable walks day and night.All the shopping brands are available, with few Tapas houses, coffee shops and restaurants.
Luxury. Beautiful avenue, great restaurants, hotels, and of course, GAUDI and more GAUDI, you will love this avenue lots of beautiful people you can feel the energy of the city.

Good Place. Shopping along Barcelona's grand Passeig de Gràcia means being right in the heart of the centre of town, where you'll be taking in a breathtaking modernist building one minute and the next dodging others out for a walk, in a hurry to get somewhere, or doing their own spending
Great shopping strip. Don't miss this girls. Unique Spanish style midst the major chains. And a smattering of good eateries in between.

Women Paradise. My fellow male travelers be careful... this is the women Paradise. this street has absolutely every single high end designer that you can imagine and it is really difficult to avoid buying something for your lady. We loved it. we visited Barcelona for two days and we spent more than 3 hours per day on this street. you can find almost everything that you need for fashion and the same time there are two of Gaudy houses for pictures. lost of small and trendy bars and restaurants on the street

Great walk. Definetely a walk you will be doing a few times if your hotel is around passeig de gracia. It is just very nice, nice environment, cool stores, large sidewalks, good for riding a bike as well. it is a busy avenue, but the walk is nice. Knowing the parallel streets, smaller and quieter, is also part of the fun.
Shopping Central. A lovely street to wander down. Lots of (pricey) nice tapas places and designer shops galore. Keep your credit card under lock and key or the spending can go a little crazy.

"the architecture!!!". It's a miracle my neck didn't snap considering I was staring upwards most of the time! :P The best way to immediately see this area is the Hop On Hop Off (HOHO) bus. Then, find the stops you're interested in & get off the HOHO & walk around. Lots of high dollar shopping stores, wider avenues and brilliant architecture everywhere you look--from Casa Batlló, La Pedrera & Illa de la Discòrdia down to the lamp posts! A beautiful area!

the best place to shop in Barcelona. beautiful street with the best commercial shops in barcelona, there is a lot of room on this big boulevard so you won't feel overwhelmed by all the tourists compared to Las Ramblas

The street isn't interesting, its buildings are. Don't visit Passeig de Gracia to visit Passeig de Gracia. It is a street. It has shopping. Just like a million other places in the world.Go to Passeig de Gracia en route to a Gaudi house: La Pedrera, Caso Batllo, etc. The houses and architecture are what make this street interesting. Don't visit it for the sake of it.
Passeig de Gracia. Might want to get your credit card limit raised, Versace-Rolex-Chanel-Cartier-Tiffany-Jimmy Choo-Dolce Gabbana plus others.

one of the world's best walking streets. Start at the Plaza Catalunya and walk northwest up towards the village of Gracia. Walk up one side of the avenue and down the other. You will pass the most extraordinary collection of architecture. Gaudi's casa Battlo and Casa Mila. Gaudi even designed the benches and light fixtures. Beautiful buildings by Gaudi and his contemporaries, art deco. One of the world's great walks. Be sure to take an architecture guide with you.
Nice place to go shopping. It's a real cool stret to go shopping - and be surprised and amazed by the Gaudí beautiful buildings
Wonderful. Neat and lovely walking street..Mostly high brands both sides..Very nice to have a walk ..Several different restaurants, cafes and bakeries..Worth a visit

The Fifth Avenue of Barcelona. Passeig de Gracia is a chance to experience upscale shopping at its finest as the wide avenue is lined with luxury shops to please every taste. The area also features beautiful benches and street lights (designed by Gaudi) and the tiles paving the pedestrian walkways are works of art. Whereas Las Ramblas has the feel of a constant street fair, this avenue is more sedate but equally enjoyable.

Buzzing and trendy. We stopped on this road and it was a great central choice of venue. Its a very trendy street. Lots of high end shops, cafes, hotels and important architectual jewels. Feels very safe.

Great shopping street. Definitely worth strolling around for shopping. The tapas bars are must visit! We ended up going twice- once in evening and once in the afternoon and really enjoyed walking and checking out shops.

Wide avenue great for people-watching. This reminded me of Paris - a wide avenue full of stylish shops and restaurants, and people walking out (on a Sunday) in their best clothes. Very Spanish, apart from the inevitable tourists. Fabulous architecture - far better than La Rambla.
Luxory brands shopping. Shopping street :) luxory fashion brands - Prada, Jimmy Choo, Louis Vuiotton, Gucci, D&G, Chanel, Valentino...Heaven for my eyes

Nicest part of town - great for high end shopping. Prada, Gucci, Chanel...you get the idea.This is a street for shopping and not the cheap kind. This is THE shopping street in Barcelona, pretty much after the Ramblas ends and the Passeig begins. The key area is about 3 metro stations in length. Restaurants on this street are a bit of a tourist trap (pricing) so I wouldn't eat on Passeig or 2 blocks in either direction. But it's clean, wide, even the benches seem to be brand new, great for people watching or just a nice stroll. Check out some of the architecture including a couple of Gaudi homes.
A great stroll.... A grand boulevard with the top names of fashion. Reminds me of the Champs Elysee. Definitey worth a walk down it and make sure to visit La Pedrera.

Nice street, bad shops. While the street is nice for a walk (just like many streets in Barcelona), the shopping experience does not match that. It is just a street of Mango, with some dots of Zara. The shopping malls have last year´s fashion, literally (we actually saw Swiss price tags of 2014). What is really a winner, are the smaller boutiques in other streets. They have very nice fashionable stuff for a good price. Very stylish stuff, with shows the Spanish do have taste.

bring the credit card. this street can be super busy and at other times it feels like you are the only one there ( early morning and national holidays) - it has beautiful lamps and benches, i love that they planted trees and have Gaudi tiles at one point of the street. I think there is good shopping - I just didn't have the budget for the shops there

Some of the best shopping in Europe. Among the best high streets around... take your time and enjoy the stroll, especially the non-chain department stores. The Gaudi museum shops have some excellent unique merchandise as well as the Zara Home and Vincon that you can't find elsewhere
Great road for shopping. Great place for shopping. Shops from high end, luxury (expensive) brands, to popular brands which are not so expensive.

Magnificent Mile. This street is packed with so many stores and shops! The architecture of the buildings is also fun to see along this strip. It is one of the main strips in the city..definitely worth going to for shopping, dining, etc.
Excellent. Excellent area. Walk around and see the beautiful environment. Barcelona is a great city and you have to walk a lot to discover it...

Great Place for a Walk Round. It is a great place to make for especially if you enjoy unbelievable architecture. Casa Batllo & Amatller are close by, but have a look round some of the other buildings nearby which are just as good. It's a short walk down to Place Catulunya then the Ramblas.

Go here if you love to shop. Lots and lots of stores and restaurants. Be prepared to walk. Many stores and restaurants. Metro stop along the route as well. Fun place to explore. You'll also find Casa Battlo along this route.

Shopping Heaven!. A Heaven for shoppers as well as walkers, beautiful area full of amazing shops and brands across the views, with many restaurants and cafes everywhere, beautifully paved, beautiful buildings and lamp posts, lemon and oak trees smartly and delicately located as you roam around, you can also see 2 Gaudi buildings.
You will love it!

A beautiful street. Spend some time walking along this street. There are some Gaudi buildings, international shops (Zara, Mango, Luis Vuitton etc...) and nice restaurants. It's a wide boulevard, almost Paris-like.
Great Architecture. This place positively buzzes as does all of Barcelona. The architecture on some of the buildings is amazing - Gaudi.
International!. Big avenue that makes you feel into an international athmosphere, and gaves you the perception of live in the town thought time

Nice avenue, with some buildings created by Gaudi.. This is a nice avenue with many stores and restaurants in the relatively new part of town. (only about 100 years). You can visit two Gaudi creations, Casa Batllo and Casa Mila or Pedrero, which are interesting
9

Top of the line in Barcelona. Make a priority to spend time here. Beautiful buildings, high end shops and great restaurants. Don't miss Casa batllo's corner, every structure around the building is just interesting and beautiful. Also import is Casa Mila( La pedrera) if you are into walking, start from Plaza Catalunya and just stroll down this beautiful boulevard.(10 times better than Las Ramblas)

Beautiful Area. Our hotel was in this area. It is beautiful and quiet, yet there is plenty to do and completely walkable. As 3 women traveling alone, we felt completely safe walking in this area at night. Wonderful shopping and plenty of restaurants. The high end designers are on the main road, but just a block off there are more reasonable priced shops.

A good location to stay. This street is one of the main shopping areas with lots of high end retailers located here. We were diagonally opposite La Pedrera, another of Gaudi's creations and the last stop on our full day tour with Explore Catalunya so very convenient. Walking straight down to Placa de Catalunya, La Rambla, the Catedral or harbour it's quite easy to navigate your way around.
Luxury shops. Nice big street up from la rambla. Full of expensive luxury shopping and up market eateries, it's a nice place to spend a few hours window shopping.
Nice for walking. Wide street with high end stores. If you go up far enough just before you get to the diagonal you'll see Guadii's La Pedera.
Expensive street. This is most beautiful and expensive street of barcelona.. Very close to Plaza catalunyta the great rambla street.
always amazing. Filled with great architecture, La Pedrera and Casa Batlo from Gaudi, but there are many other amazing buildings. All the big fashion names are there...

Passeig de Gracia underground Train station. Passeig de Gracia underground Train station, please be aware of pickpockets, this is the green line from the airport and pickpockets are rife. A friend of mine had her bag pick pocketed getting onto the Metro. Beware of people standing in front of the doors to the metro so you have to brush past as they are ready to take you valuables.

Beautiful. Lovely wide boulevard with trees, outdoor bars restaurants and cafes, not to mention the beautiful buildings and fountains. Designer shops and posh hotels galore lead downtown Placa Catalunya, the top of La Rambla

Elegance. We did not know anything about the Passeig de Gracia, but found ourselves walking along it many times, either window shopping or sitting at one of the cafes watching the world go by. We expected to spend more time at La Rambla, but this was our favourite street in Barcelona. Big designer names all along it and Casa Mila and Casa Bottla. Do watch out for the cars appearing from the underground car park. If you have teenage daughters send them off to Zara while you enjoy a glass of Cava at one of the many cafes such as La Vaca Paca.

Viva Gaudi's Gracia!. While in Barcelona, our hotel was situated in the Eixample area. Passeig de Gracia is only a few minutes walk away from where we stayed. On the way, we were treated to examples (Eixamples!!) of Gaudi architecture (like the Casa Batilo) and stately copy-cat buildings, including the ornate lamp posts. It was winter when we were here - bright and blue-skied, but cold, very cold. So it was great that when we dropped in for tapas, we could sit outside under the outdoor heaters and not be deprived of gazing at the beautiful street, full of teeming shoppers and tourists. Over the long weekend, this was where you could find us, grabbing a bite and drinking hot espresso coffee; admiring Gaudi's work and watching the world go by.

Long shopping boulevard. Starting from Cataluna square, this boulevard makes for an interesting walk on many levels. Zara has a gorgeous home store, and the clothing store is quite large. Across the street is a really interesting arcade of individual shops. Further up the shops become 'designer' but worth lookin at , from the street preferably. There are two Gaudi buildings on either side of the road. La Pedera is facinating especially from the roof. Sadly, it was thronged with students when we're were there, and they did not seem interested. It's a stiff walk to the top of the boulevard but there are gardens in the middle with seating. It becomes rather austere at the top with banks and other such official buildings. Retun to the bottom and prices become lower and places more accessable. Worth the stroll though.

Stately street for fine shopping, Gaudi architecture. Our anniversary visit was headquartered in a lovely apartment one block from the Plaza Catalunya. Passeig de Gracia cuts through the handsome Eixample area including the wonderful Casa Batlo and la Pedrera, two Gaudi marvels. A number of fine restaurants are located on or just off this major thoroughfare; our favorite was Petit Comite where we celebrated with an anniversary dinner.

Fascinating to walk through the grand street. This is likely the most glorious and glamorous street of modern Barcelona. Although Gaudi's historic masterpiece Casa Batllo is right in the middle however the street is dominated by all the modern big brands of fashion and food industry. You name it. Pick a sunny late morning to walk through the passeig to enjoy the people watching and be watched.

A fabulous place to promenade :-). A beautiful road with walkways, just watch out for the changes in Tarmac/pavements because there are roads running by the pedestrian area. Don't get hit!It's very nice at night, when it's dark, to window-shop looking in all the designer shops plus the lit up Gaudi apartments are gorgeous. Busy by day with lots of cafes and the people-watching is fascinating.

enjoy outdoor space. great for people watching, this is a lovely central location - lots of stuff happening. lots of touristy stuff happening too, but overall, it's nice to enjoy the weather out here and people watch

Gaudi, shopping and strolling. The best way to describe Passeig de Gracia is-it's a combination of Park Avenue and Madison Avenue. Gaudi's La Pedrera and Casa Bastllo are highlights of this street but there is incredible architecture from beginning to end. High-end shopping and wide sidewalks make this the perfect place for an afternoon stroll.

More Gaudi and Modernista buildings. This street has a collection of Gaudi and Gaudi inspired buildings. One in particular, Casa Bastello is amazing. It looks like a ginger bread house from the outside and once again is a credit to the Gaudi design and the actual artisans that built it.
A Stroll Through History. What a wonderful boulevard! There is no better place in Barcelona for a stroll through history. Lots to see and do while studying the architecture and enjoying the view.
Lovely. Lovely area. Only visited for a short while. Would have gone back but didn't have enough time in Barcelona.

Beautiful full of history. This is a really great place full of history and architecture. There are many nice shops and restaurant. An easy stroll around here and make sure to look up at the buildings as they are just magnificant.It is one of the major avenues in Barcelona. There is not a lot more one can say about it. Make sure you walk along this avenue. You can start from Placa De Catalunia.

A grand boulevard. Originally built to welcome the visiting King Alfonso X111, Gaudi was commissioned to do something grand for him. The city decided to build this grand boulevard, which today has 4 of the mansions he was commissioned to design, as well as a host of fancy shops and hotels. It's the fanciest part of town.But look closely at the sidewalk. The design of the tiles is amazing, only Gaudi would think of something like that. Each tile is a hexagon, there's concentric circles in the middle linking up the design of the other tiles, you have to see it to understand. I can't image what a nightmare the tile layers would have had when they did this, and it's the entire length of the street on both sides! I was very fasciated by this information provided by Leon the guide from Sandeman's tour. Of you want to get your fill of the designer brands they're all here as well. But don't forget to visit La Pedrera and Casa Milla which are both World Heritae sights. Get tickets if you can, as I saw snaking Qs each time I went past.
well worth it. well worth going to - a bit under rated as people talk about the La Ramblas - but this is a gem of a boulevard!

Nice walk. It's worth walking along Passeig de Gracia. It has some of the nicest modernist buildings and it's where all the posh shops are, if you're into that sort of thing. You don't require a large amount of time to see it and it's next to other sights in the center.

Lovely!. One of te most chic, trendy and lovely streets in Barcelona. The Passeig de Gracia is a must visit during your trip to this lovely city. Restaurants, shops, boutiques, beautiful historic buildings and so much more. Highly recommended!
Excellent atmosphere. Great views and buildings. We will visit again. Its also on the metro route so easy to get to. Great restaurants too.

One special shop I love.... ...on the Passeig de Gracia is Vinçon. I'm not interested in spending loads of money in the most fashionable of fashion shops on the Passeig. But what I really l o v e is going to Vinçon. It's a h u g e gift shop full of surprising merchandise. Just bought a tiny easel(!) for my Ipad (and got three more for friends), a cuddly Rin-Rin-Tin-dog for a very special person and some lovely bowls. You could spend the entire day at Vinçon's letting yourself be surprised again and again. They have stuff in the economic range up to very costly gifts. Can't wait to go back next time when I'm in the Ciudad Condal.

gaudi master pieces. Great to see gaudi's work , go later in the day to be at the queues.When you have had enough of cultural visit the high end designer shops.Try straying of to side streets for breakfast or lunch.

Extremely Pricey Shopping, Great Architecture. I spent one afternoon/evening strolling Passeig de Gracia, and did enjoy it. It is famous for two things: architecture by Gaudi, and upscale shopping.I did very much enjoy seeing the Gaudi architecture. There are several very impressive buildings, as well as lamp posts, and even sidewalk tiles, that were done by the famous artist.As for the shopping, I personally don't enjoy shopping in stores where tee-shirts are $700 and shoes are $3,000, so that was not a draw for me. Shopping-wise, this is basically the "Rodeo Drive" or "Park Avenue" of shopping in Barcelona.

Some beautiful buildings, some shops. There are some beautiful buildings along the Passeig de Gracia, like Gaudí's Casa Batllò and La Pedrera, as well as some nice clothing stores, but besides that the Passeig de Gracia is just a busy road like any other.

Shopping!!! Great Shopping!!! More Shopping!!!. Besides walking around the area, make sure to buy something you like. Also, make sure to go into the Corte Ingles (an experience in itself). Amazing products, amazing prices. If shopping is not your thing, then enjoy the sightseeing at no cost.

Great shopping. What an interesting street to walk, explore and shop. Yes some high end shops, but neat to watch. You can also hop on the barcelona bus touristic, blu or red line in front of Casa Batlllo
Fun souvenir shopping. I was able to get some souvenirs here for my family. There was such a variety and the environment was very relaxed.
A Great Boulevard to Walk. Stately boulevard through "The Extension" (new part of Barcelona above old town). Great shopping, hotels, restaurants . . . and, Gaudi houses.

Best avenue for shopping in Barcelona between Gaudi famous buildings. Passeig de Gracia is the best avenue in Barcelona for shopping all levels. If you love shopping this the right place, but also you can stop to visit the 2 famous and amazing buidlings of Gaudi: Casa Batlló and la Pedrera.

Feeling relax and luxury at the same time!. I have stayed two nights in 5 star hotel (Hotel Majestic) at the Passaig de Gracia and I had a great chance to see around, walk around and along the Paseig de Gracia. What I felt is that you can feel wealthiness, easy goingness and luxurious at the same time...

It's always good to get back.. I can't get tired of this avenue, you have everything the, the stores, the buildings, it's great. In here you can see the Casa Batlo, La Pedrera, as well as other beautiful buildings.
If you love shopping.... this is the roght place. Passeig is fantastic for walking and then stores are full of nice things. Not too expensive though they are all higgh level brands.
Loved this street. Passeig de Gracia is beautiful and has much to offer. To warn though, this street is quite expensive. The food was delicious, especially the macaroons.
the champs elysee of barcelona. the hostel i picked happened to be on the most eatiufl art noubeau street of the city was surprsed to ahve this happen tha you god. !! !

the most beautiful street ive ever seen. i fell in love with this street and must have taken 100 pictures. its amazingly clean, full of trees, beautiful benches of mosaic, fun window shopping and people walking up and down. i think ill never forget it!
shopper's paradise. we went here just for the Orbea shop but there is everything from chanel, louis vitton, rolex to h and m, not being shoppers we just passed through and stop to see the Bastillo

Lovely place for a stroll. If you into fashion this is the place for you, if not its a great wide beautiful street, lots of windows to look in, even more beautiful buildings to be amazed at,two lovely gaudi buildings to be amazed at and lovely seats along the drive to just sit and enjoy life passing by.

nice walk. I suggest you start from the top and walk down passeig de gracia - plaça de catalunya - portal del angel - cathedral, and on the way pay attention to the buildings from the outside (you can spot the most famous ones by people taking pictures, but others on the way are worthwhile looking at the details of windows, doors, etc.). There are some fashion stores as well if you are in the mood, and the design store Vinçón, with lots of different stuff - just take 15 min inside to see some ideas for daily life items.

Rivals the very best. Fantastic thoroughfare rivalling some of the very best in the world. Take your time and savour! Plenty of places to eat and drink and watch Barcelona go about it's daily life. As you would expect, pretty expensive, but looking doesn't cost anything
Great shopping. A very regal central Barcelona avenue with all the big brands plus a few good restaurants for pit stops. A nice respite from the góthic área and Barcelona business.

A shoppers paradise. I love this road, it seems endless. Carrying on walking right up it (northwards), past the endless number of Zara's, past Diagonal station and then it moves away from the Diors/Pradas etc and the shops are less designer and smaller and independent, especially off the side streets. Here you'll find lots of little cafes too, more reasonably priced. Keep going north and you'll reach an area called Gracia which is full of little craft shops and boutiques.

loftyrob198. A fantastic street running from La Diagonal to Plaza de Catalunya. Extremely wide and very clean, it has all the shops one could wish for and several shopping centres. Cafes and restaurants of all types are plentiful.
shopping. best place to make shopping. all brands in one beautiful street. also now discounts time so very cheap.

OK, it's part of Barcelona but it is full of people, touristy and dangerous because of pickpockets. Reasonable choices for shopping but overpriced and touristy in places and dangerous because of pickpockets !
Busy and Bustling. Everybody hustling. Like a mini version of New York. Side streets a bit more interesting. Be sure to see the Gaudi sites located on this famous street!
Nicest shopping area. Many nice shops and boutiques, good hotels located there and also many bars and cafes. Beautiful street (much more classy than the fast deteriorating Ramblas).
Gaudi houses. Don't miss Casa Mila (La Predera) and Casa Battlo. These houses are a feast for Gaudi fans. If you don't know about Gaudi you'll become a fan after visiting these attractions.
Shopping haven...... High end shopping brands are full in this place....nice place to stroll around at night when things a lit up..

Not So Exciting. I have visited Barcelona many times and once found it a very exciting place to shop. However, things haven't moved on and Spain's most exciting retail offer-Zara- is now in every major city in the UK so the novelty of finding it on every corner in Barcelona isn't there any more. Passeig de Gracia is good for designer shops (all of which can be found in London) and jeans stores and sports brands but we are so spoilt in the UK now that our teenage kids in particular are left wondering what all the fuss is about. Obviously Passeig de Gracia has two magnificent Gaudi building to gasp at, the likes of which cannot be found in the UK but apart from that it's noce but not amazing.
A luxurious shopping street. Like a wider and more desirable Oxford Street of London. Crammed with high, low and mid-end shops and good reastaurants serving paella and tapas.

The barcelonna's Fifth Avenue. Loking for the High Street Shops in Barcelona? This is Passeig de Gracia. But when getting out of the shops, don't miss the public street lights design or the pedestrian ground design. It is part of the design iconic pictures of Barcelona.
Shopping!. Great location.. near las ramblas and other attractions. This is a good place for shopping especially luxury goods!

Amazing avenue. Wonderful architecture, great places to shop. Definitely worth to explore on your foot - from Plaça de Catalunya till Av. Diagonal. Don't forget to stroll down in evening, when buildings are beautifully lit.

All for the shoppers. Besides the beautiful and very wide area to enjoy a nice stroll, with all the nice buildings all along, its a shppers paradise, you find ALL the well known boutiques and brands over there, from the budget but modern H&M to Gucci, Tous etc

Amazing architecture on this street!. Said to be the most expensive street in Spain, it's certainly worth a long stroll. The architecture is amazing. While Gaudi's house steals the show, many others are worthy of a second look.
Shopping mile of Barcelona. Major thoroughfare in Barcelona that is lined with shops, restaurants and some of Gaudi's architecture. This is the shopping mile of Barcelona.

It is the center of it all in Barcelona!. A very wide avenue full of local and international stores, cafes and Restaurants(not all very good) a lot of it for tourist, but it has some great hotels like the Mandarin Oriental and restaurant like El Nacional, this is a group of restaurants under one roof

Nice place to hang out and feel the city. This was walking distance from my hotel and also a shopping hub. The street is really good to walk on and is lined with shops/ boutiques and also small eating joints along the way. You will find practically most of the Big Brand boutiques on this street. However, a word of caution, unlike in Singapore where the branded boutiques are easy to find and all close to each other, this is a fairly large street and you may have to walk quite a distance. Even if you dont want to shop, I would recommend this place to just get a feel of the city.
Shopping street with additional attractions. You can go there just for a shopping and you will be surprised to find several impressive Gaudi houses there.

One of the most avenues I've ever seen. It was a real delight on a January sunny day to walk along this incredible avenue filled with amazing architecture, upscale stores and great restaurants. What more can you ask for? Gaudi, Chanel and great seafood, all together!
A Less Flashier Version of Champs-Élysées. Trendy, upmarket location. Stores and restaurants everywhere. Probably nothing cheap, but filled with amazing architecture
Nice Area. Full of expensive brand name stores.Very trendy, Casa Batllo is in the Neighborhood only reason I went.

A must for upscale shoppers.... ...and for anyone interested in architecture. Great photo ops of stunning buildings, fountains and a perfect place for people watching. We were there on a January 6th - a major holiday. All shops were closed and there were no crowds to navigate. The perfect day to find a bench and check out the locals catching some sun rays.
Best shopping street. Upscale shopping, as well as the mainstream shops, and some Gaudi sightseeing free on your way... What's not to like?

Perfect, calculate to spend here at least three hours. This is a perfect street! Some combination of Champs Elysees in Paris and Ku-Damm in Berlin. Very trendy and relaxing atmosphere, it is nice to walk around, no hurry, sit down to have a coffee outside in the sun and just breath Barcelona. My personal advise - calculate to spend here at least three hours, it is worth!
And one more expensive shoppingstreet.... If you love to spend your money in excesively overpriced shops, then this your place. If you don't, its just another wide street...
The paradise for shopcaholic!. You will be lost in this huge street full of high and street brand shops. Everything you need, you can find it here!

Las Ramblas rich cousin.. Whatever cheap trinkets you find in Las Ramblas, you pay way more in Passeig de Gracia and they are usually the real deal here. Barcelona's equivalent to New York's Fifth Avenue many not have the towers. Here is a canyon of beautiful buildings that vary from the sublime to outworldly. It's upscale and fashionable walk so try to dress accordingly.

Nice, crowded and a lot of walking. The Paaseig de Gracia is an old shopping street, excellent for walking up and down. It's less great if you like to shop. The long stretch of road and the huge number of clothing stores make it difficult for couples to split up and catch up once in a while. It's a bit better with the Rablas in the old city, where you can dive into a small street around the corner for more special kinds of stores than the obligatory huge brands.

Champs-Élysées' Spanish Sister. Tiffany's, Cartier, and the other usual suspects litter the sides of this otherwise respectable avenue. Here, it's not so much the pick-pockets that threaten your economic well-being.

Great boulevard. Beautiful architecture, expensive area for shopping, wide pavement to walk,plenty of restaurants.Also is known as the Champs-Élysées of Barcelona.One of the most beautiful boulevards in the city of Barcelona

Best for shopping. Passeig de Gracia is a perfect place for strolling around and for shopping.here you can find both the boutiques of high-end brands , like Hermes, Chanel, Dolce and Gabanna, michael Kors, as well as the lower key brands like Zara and Massimo Dutti.There are plenty of retaurants in the neignbourhood.The sights , like la Pedrera and Casa Batlo are also here.

The Life of The City. With buildings such as Casa Batllo and Casa Milan adorning the streets, you know going in that this a beautiful part of the city. This is where you'll find shops such as Prada, Gucci, and Louis Vuitton, so you know right off the bat what kind of money resides in this part of the city. But it doesn't cost much to take in the sights and enjoy the streets, sights, food and the people. Make sure to stroll in the day and at night as they are vastly different experiences.
One of the great streets in the world. Marvelous architecture, generous street space, great procession of shops and activities. Worth the stroll, especially on a sunny afternoon.
Great street. Very beautiful street. Lots of great buildings, good surrounding. Just to go around and enjoy the city
Shopping Area. This is the most expensive area for shopping but quiet nice for walking as well. Be aware of pick pockets around, but enjoy the view and buildings!

Gaudi style. I have always been interested in this street as it is fascinating to see many Gaudi opera, from the streets lights to the various houses along the street. Large pavement to walk and also easy to drive through

Great for any activity. Whether you are shopogolic, architecture lover, city jogger or just eager for a good stroll - the street is for you. I especially liked various architecture samples that may be discovered at this street. And, of course, the whole bunch of various garment shops :)

Great Street Especially at Night. Passig de Gracia is a fun street full of shopping, attractions such as Cass Battlo and La Padrera, and many restaurants. Over Christmas, it is all lit up and looks magical. It's a great way to spend an afternoon.
Shopping fiesta. All the high end shops are here you name it. It is known as the Champs-Élysées of Barcelona. Walking around is pleasant too although it can get very crowded.

High-End Shopping Lane. Passeig de Gracia stretches for quite a bit, and houses major luxury European fashion brands like Prada, Hermes, Miu Miu, LV, Tods, Ferragamo, Burberry, you name it. There's also mid-range options like Mango and H&M. I like how this was "fused" with history and art, particularly with Gaudi's Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. There were also quite a number of cafes and restaurants along the street, but most unfortunately are for the tired, unsuspecting tourists with only quick bite-worthy food. Some have noted that Passeig de Gracia is one of the streets where pickpockets are particularly active. We did not have any such encounters, but probably because we weren't flaunting and asking to be robbed, unlike some tourists. I should warn you that your shopping experience might be marred by the rude, arrogant and loud tourists from China, who descend on these boutiques like they were your Gap or Costco. Be extra polite to the service staff, and they would treat you amazingly well - it is, of course, a world of difference compared to the other tourists (see above).

Similar to Many Cities but More Concentrated and Close to Historic Areas. Between the very upscale shopping, five star hotels, superb restaurants, and restaurants of all types this neighborhood is a joy to wander around. You will never know what's around the corner and it could be anything from a Burberry's to a flower market to a Gaudi piece of architecture.On top of that, it is a short walk from the historic precincts of El Born, Barri Gotic, and Las Ramblas.Go. Enjoy.

Christmas in Barcelona. Like the lighting on display and the late night shopping. Watched out for pickpocket though. Shopping heaven. Some of the branded goods such as Zegna is cheaper here than overseas.

Shopping.. From high end fashion (Hermes, Emporio Armani)boutiques to low end (H&M, Mango) can be found in this street. Casa Battlo is also situated in this street. Even if you don't want to shop, there are a few cool cafes. You can't come to Barca and not walk this street.

High Fashion on the Psg de Gracia. This is one of the most beautiful boulevards in the city of Barcelona. Full of high fashion, great tourist watching, the Pedrera, the Casa Batlo, the huge Apple store, the Block of Discord and fabulous street lights, street tiles and benches to sit on! Different kind of fun from Las Ramblas but great food and just tons of things to see. Take a walk, take in the extraordinary scene and get lost in time.

Obras....y mas obras. When are they going to finish digging up, putting back down, the digging up the road again. Been living here for a couple of years now, and I can´t remember a time when there was no construction on this road. Shopping is ok and there are a few really good restaurants. Normal!
Highclass on expensive shopping. This is quite basic shopping street with few nice fountains - if you dont have a good pile of money, dont bother to visit stores :)

You don't have to shop to go there. Lots of high end stores located here. I'm not much of a shopper, but I love this street. I took my time to stroll down this street to admire all the classic unique styles of archiecture. The street has some benches for you to sit and rest. That's just what I did. The Casa Mila, Casa Battlo are close by. If you walk a bit more will be Placa Catalunya and Las Rambla. A bit more will be Mirador de Colom and Port Vell, the floating walkway. Most likely you can spend a day here. Don't worry, there are lots of cafes and restrurants to suit your taste. Just have fun and enjoy!Happy Travelling!

Shopping, convenience, and the 'Block of Discord'. There's a lot of eating, drinking and shopping to do on this broad street. There are a couple of Metro stations on it, so it's well-connected.Its highlight must be the Block of Discord, with the Casa Batllo, Casa Amatller, Casa Mulleras and Casa Lleo-Morera. Casa Batllo is worth multiple visits - one during the day and another at night. (It's open till 8 or 8:30, even in this season.)

Excellent shopping in lovely buildings. There are two halves to passeig de gracia - the top is full of high end designer labels.. Chanel, Burberry, tiffanys.... And the bottom has all the Spanish high street names.. Zara, mango, Stradivarius... The architecture is of course gorgeous - it's a real treat to be inside some of the buildings. Would thoroughly recommend for anybody wanting to do a spot of shopping - there are lots of food places and it's an easy walk to plaza catalunya and la rambles.

Trendy Shopping at it's best!. If you are looking to hit some serious shops and fill your bags this is your street! El Corte Ingles, H&M, Mango, Pull and Bear, and of course Designual - all here! Wear comfortable shoes!

All the way down.. I would suggest to take the tube to Diagonal lines 3 and 5 and walk down to Plaça Catalunya but... take your time. Have a look at all the buildings, have a drink and have some tapas and go shopping if you can afford if not, just window shopping, I love it!

Great shopping. Great street for shopping. Closer to the Plaza Catalunya are the high street shops, like H&M, Bershka, Zara etc. The further up you go, the more luxurious the shops, with brands like Gucci, Luis Vuitton and Chanel.In between shopping you can visit Casa Battlo and La Pedrera and there are enough cafes to have a little drink if you get thirsty.

Exclusive shopping. Top selection of shops on an avenue that puts the Champs Elysee to shame! The variety in architecture and the sheer beauty of the buildings, coupled with nice restaurants, nice people and top shops, makes this hard to beat anywhere really! Wide walkways make it easy to move around, although we never found it to be "busy", another advantage over other top shopping destinations! You have space and can move! Not to miss!

Luxury,luxury,luxury. I lived in barcelona in the 70 and has this place changed. It's now one of the international luxury boulevards of the world. There are great hotels,restaurants,and it's a great place to stroll with family and friends if you are a tourist in this city. If you can afford it its a great central place to stay in one of the many hotels.
shopping, cafes, people-watching. Fascinating! We walked up and down this street to/from our apartment in Gracia every day for a week and never got tired of it.

5th Avenue of Barcelona. This is probably one of the nicest areas of Barcelona for strolling, talking and relaxing. The combination of stunning architecture and every type of shopping imaginable provides something for everyone. TIP: Wear comfortable shoes. Cities in Spain really space out their streets and plazas, and you can walk 5 miles before you blink an eye.

Roam to your heart's content. This is a window shopping place. Keep your wallet tucked away and just enjoy the walk. Nice place for a tapas or cup of coffee. There are some nice statues to admire and some fountains nearby. Keep about 2 hours for this place.

Perfect for Retail Therapy. Close to our hotel, this boulevard contains hundreds of upscale shops, beautiful residential buildings (several by Gaudi), and thousands of pedestrians clogging the sidewalks. A truly great street.
Best shopping street. Passeig de Gracia is a must visit. It is both very beautiful and had all the shops I was looking for.

The street for lovers of modernist architecture. Passeig de Gracia is a real gem if you are interested in modernist architecture. Not only will you find some of the most famous Gaudi works such as the magical Casa Battlo and the famous Casa Milà. You will also see some amazing examples of building created by the two other main Catalan architects, Joseph Puig i Cadafalch and Lluis Domènech i Montaner. Every facade is full of beautiful and intricate details, and you just need to look up to be enchanted. Even if you are not willing to pay entrance fees to the buildings, a stroll in Passeig de Gracia in a must when you visit Barcelona.
Shopping trip to remember. If you want to see how the other half lives, up market shopping be sure to visit Passeig de Gracia for that special one off purchase or even just to window shop.

Well worth the stroll both directions. My wife loves it with all the Brand names shops in it. Wide avenue, with a vast array of shops, be it clothes, food as well as other various products.Well worth the visit and even if for window shopping, if you are not into spending any money on that particular day. Always lively and fun to visit.We enjoyed it and shall go there again, whenever in Barcelona again, as we have done the last three times.

Go To Area of Barcelona. We have been to Barcelona three times, and we have always stayed on or right around the corner from the Passeig de Gracia in the Eixample district. While all areas of Barcelona are fun to explore, it is the Passeig de Gracia that makes Barcelona our favorite city in Spain, maybe Europe. There are two Gaudi buildings to tour, Casa Batllo and Casa Mila, and other famous architects are represented on the street as well such as Lluís Domènech i Montaner who designed the Palau de la Música Catalana and Casa Lleo i Morera which is on the same block as Casa Batllo and is now open to tour. There are also many high end shops, restaurants, and many places to sit and people watch and/or rest. One of our best friends doesn't care for Barcelona, and I believe it is because she got a wrong impression of the city from the start by staying around the Gothic/Las Ramblas area. She always comments there is too much crime, while we have never experienced feeling that way at all and we've been to Barcelona twice more than she has. While Las Ramblas and the Gothic district are fun areas to explore, I wouldn't stay there- I do feel safer in Eixample along the Passeig de Gracia. It may be strange, but my husband and I both feel like we have returned home when we go to Barcelona and are sitting at an outdoor cafe along the Passeig de Gracia. In fact, after our first visit there, he said he could move to Barcelona.
Amazing street with great high end stores and cafe shops. loved that street. I prefer walking in this place rather than la rambla. La rambla is very busy and full of wrong people sometimes ...

WORTH A STROLL. Main street where Casa Batlo and La Pedrera are located. Worth walking its length and shopping at all the high-end stores. Relax on one of the Gaudi benches. Excellent restaurants along its stretch. Beautiful architecture.

A Must See. A beautiful street architecturally, with lots of fine buildings, high-end stores, Gaudi buildings, and (with Las Ramblas running parallel) lots of excellent watering holes on hand.The main problem right now is the amount of road works and refurbishments going on - makes it very noisy and adds to the congestion. Most of the hop-on hop-off buses stop on this street, so access is very easy.

Hours of Entertainment. You could literally spend days just on the Passeig de Gracia. There a re a wealth of entertainments, nightlife, shopping, restaurants, bakeries, eateries, museums, and must sees in the area.
Grand!. Surely one of the grandest streets in Europe! Top end shops mixed with top end architecture , magic for a wander on a nice day, plenty of pit stops around if required!

Often loud with road works. not sure I've ever been to this street without some form of pipe laying or road works occurring. It's a great place to people watch and have a coffee and nibble, but very loud. Some decent shopping to be had too and a nice even pavement, very wide, is good for a stroll.

Main Road.. This Avenue is just beautiful. There you will find Casa Batllo and other beautiful buildings. The road is adorned with "lamp posts" the like of it you have never seen before. They were designed by another Catalonian architect . At the base they have beautiful white "benches" where you can seat, a great spot for a pic. The avenue also has a beautiful water fountain that changes color and it is specially nice at night. Walk bit, look at the shops, eat something, drink sangria, or just enjoy the views.
Nice street. On that street are nice cafes, and restaurants. You can see the Casa Batio, and the large Apple store when you are walking on the street. It had a very nice ambiance walking there.

Beautiful street and area!. It is a beautiful street on which you can find Casa Batlo and Casa Mila. Some nice cafes and some artistic lights on the streetand some interesting buildings ! ! A very pleasant walk !!The Metro ''Passeig de Gracia'' is just in front of Casa Batlo. Casa Mila is 3 blocks further. Close to Casa Mila is the Metro ''Diagonal'. Easy to visit this area...
large touristic shopping street. Very busy with tourists shopping or having a meal in the numerous terrasses, it is worth to walk there for 1 hour.
