Passeig de Gracia. One of the most beautiful and expensive roads of Barcelona. Ideal for shopping but for tourists who can afford them. You can find there all the famous brands.

Now THIS is a street!. This street is amazing whether seen on foot or from Barcelona's clever three-loop hop on hop off tourist bus system. There are the fantastical Gaudi buildings, of course, but many other great looking buildings as well. There are the ubiquitous motor bikes that I always will associate with Barcelona, darting this way and that. Restaurants and tapes bars and cafes for days, and shopping opportunities aplenty!

It is nice to walk there!!!. It is a very busy place and it is nice to walk around and see the shops and have lunch in one of the many restaurant there. You find there Tapies Foundation and it it is worth going if you like contemporary art.

Nice to Stroll During the Day and at Night. Our hotel was just a little off the Passeig, so we enjoyed walking up and down this avenue every day. The best time to walk and do window shopping is in the early morning hours or on a Sunday (fewer tourists). I like how the sidewalks are wide and lined with trees for nice breeze and shade. You can even sit on the bench under the Gaudi-style lamp posts and watch life go by. The Passeig is filled with cafes and restaurants (most are tourist-traps but with delicious food/tapas) so be sure to grab a seat outside for a cafe con leche! All the designer shops including Gucci and Prada can be found in the Passeig, as well as Gaudi's houses (Casa Mila and Casa Batllo). The Passeig will lead you to Plaza Catalunya, Las Ramblas, and the big department store El Corte Ingles.Be sure to spend some time here!
Shopping. If you like shopping then this is the place to visit. The mix of designer shops, café bars and restaurants, along with Gaudis famous architecture make this street a definite must see.
Beautiful walk with Gaudy influence. Casa Batllo and Le Pedrera located here. Broad sidewalks; lots of shops and cafes; more pleasant, less crowded, and not as noisy as La Ramblas.

Wonderful street. Very high end and nice to see, amongst the great architecture of this city. I more prefer the buildings and the historical sights of the city, but the way the high end shops are blended with the historical buildings was amazing.
Sort of like 5th Ave in NY. This street houses a vast quantity of stores and restaurants as well as three of Antoni Gaudi's designed apartment houses.
Good shopping - lots of options. Many choices from relatively inexpensive to high end and everything in between. Decent restaurants too. A must do and see when in Barcelona
shopping!. Best street for shopping --- eating --- people watching --- Gaudi's buildings -- very nice! We really enjoyed this area.

A Beautiful Avenue of Architecture. They say Passeig de Gracia offers good shopping...but I"m not a shopper on vacation. However, during our bus turistic tour, we enjoyed the beautiful Passeig, soaking in the gorgeous architecture, including Casa Battlo.
Lovely. Lovely street, but could be in any city that has an upmarket shopping district. great to wander along window shopping and of course see the famous Gaudi buildings.

A beautiful street. You get to see and do a little bit of everything!!! There is beautiful stores to get your shopping done or just to go and see the latest couture! Casa Batllo and Casa Mila (La Pedrera) are in than street so you can enjoy Gaudi's work, either just by staying outside or taking the inside tour. Casa Mila (La Pedrera) is being renovated, but the most important part of that house is the roof!! So dont be afraid and go in the see not only the view of Passeig de Gracia, but the wonderful chimneys designed by Gaudi.Dont forget to watch the beautiful floor, street laps and chairs that were also designed by Gaudi himself. Even the trees in Passeig de Gracia have a charm that will remained you how Gaudi was inspired by nature in his work. Specially the celling la Sagrada Familia, also a must see, but not in Passeig de Gracia. You can also find very good restaurants on the Passeig de Gracia or in the near by streets. Enjoy!!!

It really is worth the walk. A wander along here is time well spent, some fantastic architecture, and very expensive shops, but they are great window shopping. There are also some nice places to sit eat/drink and watch the world go by. A word of caution though, some bars/restaurants are very expensive for what you get we had 2 baguettes at 8.50 € each and Sangria in a pint sized tankard which cost 21 €. Which really was a rip off, and it wasn't even that good, as Sangria went

best street in Barcelona !!!. you can stroll this street from the furthest end and see landmarks and peep into upmarket brands and hotels as you walk towards the Le Enggies (??) department store where the Piazza Fountain is located. you meet the world tourists from all directions and then you continue into two roads where the La Rambla is and that's another long road for shopping and sights as well as the famous wet market where you find all the food you want !!

Shopping paradise. We were accommodated on the street and although as you can imagine, it was loud 24/7, it offered a lot. It is surrounded by all known brands in the fashion industry and cafes and lounge restaurant all around on which you can drink an ice cold beer, have tapas and continue roaming the streets. It is surrounded by narrow cobblestone streets. The street is easily accessible with metro.

Plenty to See. Our hotel was on the Passeig de Gracia, so we saw this street every day. This is really an avenue that is very wide and they are improving it all the time. The best stores are on this street. At Passeig de Gracia, 53 is the Boulevard Rosa, a small mall. Inside is the Enric Rosich Macarons store. This store sells the best macarons in Spain and we bought 3 boxes of macarons there.At one end of the street you can see the Hotel Casa Fuster. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in the city and is a historic house, another masterpiece built by Lluis Domenech.At the other end of the street is the Plaza de Catalunya, which is downtown.
very elegant area. This was a high end shopping area with many of the stores you would find in New York or Chicago. If you are interested in shopping this is the place to go.

A street worth strolling thru. This is one of Barcelona's most fancy, if not the fanciest boulevards. That's where 2 Goudi buildings are located. You'll find all the fancy designer shops from Gucci to Louis Vuitton there... Fine boutiques, enad excellent coffee shops.One amazing store to spend time in is Vinçon, which is heaven for anybody who appreciates interior or graphic design, or just good taste, truly a great and visually attractive experience.

the beating heart of the city. one of the most amazing places the city has to offer, and it's fun everytime. i came at different times of the day to enjoy the most of it. the liveliness and the amounts of people make you feel like you are in new york or paris or every other main city around the world.

The must walk it boulvard of Barcelona. This long street is always fun to walk. There are many tapas places, shops of all kinds from kitchen ware to Camper shoes, and tourists everywhere. There are also Gaudi benches and lamps, and even a building with long lines of people waiting to pay the high price for getting to the top, which we did not do.Downside: there is a never-ending construction going on on this street. Last time I was here in March 2014 I thought it was bad, but in July and August it got even worse. It is hard to cross to the other side. Another oddity is that the part after the Diagonal crossing has way too many kitchenware stores. Granted, each one is slightly different and is stuffed with clever and uniquely designed goods, but after a time one gets tired of kitchen towels and salt shakers.Two major underground stops are also on Passeig de Gracia, so it is also a good point of departure for those who, like myself, tend to easily get lost in the amazing maze of Barcelona.

Chill Out........ Just north of the Catalunya Square, Passeig ge Gracia is a great spot to sit out at a pavement cafe bar and watch the world rushing by. Quieter than the square and without the madness of Las Ramblas, this is a great spot for people watching whilst enjoying a glass of vino or an Estrella or three!!!!Plenty of decent eating spots if that is your thing - me, I prefer the liquid libation and the world slowly drifting by.
Barcelona's Champs-Elysees. Countless designers shops, two of the most iconic Gaudi's buildings and other very interesting examples of architecture, PdG is a beauiful avenue to walk onto

High end shopping. This is the luxury shopping street of Barcelona and home to stores like Ralph Lauren, Cartier, Brooks Brothers etc. A must if you like shopping. Walking down it you'll also go past serveral Gaudi-houses and som nice cafés.

Shopping!. This is the prefect street for a day of shopping. All the best stores are here. It goes from high end to more affordable as you go down the street. Some stores close in the middle of the day for a few hours.

Wonderful street!. It was our hotel in this street so we were walking it all the time! It's the champs Elysee of Barcelona! With great stores and two of the most important attractions of Barcelona Casa Batllo and Casa Mila!

Gaudi, Shopping, Romantic Walks? Check!. Well, don't go here sunday because everything is closed, but Monday through Friday, this place is thriving quaint "hipster" shops, creative clothing and miscellaneous stores is just a romantic place to be. Also, Gaudis home and museum and hotel is down this block. Best to bring your camera and the park in the middle of the road is the best place to sit whether it is in the afternoon or at night. Also, the inside streets hold hidden treasures such as old churches and local bars and shops! Dont skip out on walking down this block!

Nothing really different from the high steets in any major city. All types of stores. While many are high end and expensive, they are mostly the same stores you can find in any major city. Prada in Barcelona is little different than Prada in London which is little different from Prada in.... You get the point. While I enjoy shopping it's hard to pretend this is a Barcelona experience.

High end shoping avenue. This is the Barcelona equivalent of Champs Elysees (in Paris) and 5th Ave (in New York). The street is full of high end shopping store. Here also you can find the lovely Loewe which is a luxury Spanish brand (it isn't easily found outside Spain).Both Casa Mila and Casa Batllo are on the same avenue if you are an architectural enthusiast. And if you head south, you will arrive at plaza Catalonia which is a vibrant shopping area as well.

gracia street festival. each year, a great street festival, nice walk uo to the Passeig de Gracia, to the Gracia district, street are closed, music,drinks,food, human pyramids and fire works, Lots of people having fun, around the 15 august, if you are there make the effort, its fun.

Shopping. great place for shopping specially in the sale times
Most of the best brands are there Zara, Promod, Desigual,,,,,,

If You like High-end Shopping?. What can you say about any of the international locations for high-end shopping? Either you have the money and desire to drop large, or you want to see the city.
The only benefit of Barcelona's high end shopping destination is that there is Gaudi architecture.

A must if you love your designer shops. A long street packed full of lots and lots of designer shops. Wasn't really my bag (hence the 3 stars) but if you like your shopping and you have packed your flexible friend, then perfect. There is quite a bit of building working going on at the moment along the main road, not great for a street side coffee and relax.
Great for shopping and a walk. We walked through this place to see Casa Battlo, there are many shops around and its a great walk on a sunny relaxing day. I can see it getting quite pricy though..

great location. This is so central in Barcelona, a perfect spot and lovely shops. Great cafes, - but even better ones one block to the west in Rambla de Cataluyna, Beware the cost of beers though, check before you buy, and move to a cheaper one if necessary.

Landmarks and posh shops. I would recommend - if you are travelling into Barcelona by train - getting off at the Passeig stop. From there it's a short walk up stairs and you arrive instantly with the Casa Battlo on the other side of the street. Other highlights - the McDonalds opposite Casa Battlo is the best in Barcelona as it has a McCafé for pastries and surprisingly decent coffee a large underground eating area that is spacious and not too busy (I know I'm a heathen but when you have hungry kiddies...)The walk down from the station towards the Rambla is pleasant with some very high class shops (Max Mara etc) and the 2* Michelin restaurant Moments which I'm going to go to next time i am in Barcelona in penance for the Maccy D's. tapas24 is also on this walk down so I would definitely recommend eating in this general area rather than the tackier fare down at La Rambla. conversely if you are getting a train out of Barcelona - don't get it from here. The platforms are small and overcrowded and it is very hot and clammy in summer. I would recommend going to Estacio de Franca instead where it is larger, less claustrophobic and altogether more pleasant.

Nice. Passeig de Gracia is full of fashion stores, like Mango and Massimo Dutti. Mandarin Oriental hotel is located in it. McDonalds has stunning view on Casa Batllo. Casa Batllo is must-see while walking in Passeig de Gracia.

The prancing bourgeoisie and a long tunnel.. The rich of Barcelona don't mince and show off to the extent that they do in Via della Spiga in Milan, but the likeness is enough to make a visit interesting.There is actually quite a variety of stores on this street, from the newish Apple Store on the corner of Plaça Catalunya to the airport boutique stores such as Diesel and yet more upmarket vendors. Casa Batlló by Gaudi is on this street, but take a look at the two buildings to its left for an interesting architectural comparison. Go to a guidebook for a full explanation, if you're interested in the history, or simply take them at face value.There is a looong underground passageway between two of the Metro station lines at Passeig de Gracia. It is a marvel of the modern age that the Ajuntament (local government) has not added any artistic element, let alone a travelator to this seemingly interminable concrete highway.
Beautiful concourse. Beautiful street with such interesting architecture on every block. Also seems to be the main shopping drag, so if you want to shop, walk down Passeig de Gracia!

Shopping and more shopping.. Passeig de Gràcia is a long avenue with a lot of luxury shops like, Louis Vuitton, Michael Kors, Prada, etc... Apart from that is a nice place to have a walk, too much crowded by tourists from any other countries it is nice to see the details of the pavement and icon buildings like La Pedrera or Casa Batlló. Restaurants and bars are quite expensive due to nearly shops.

Major road with shops, cafés and fast food. Although a nice atmosphere and a nice walk in the sun, it is very European and not a good representation of true Barcelona.
The street has a mix of high street and designer shops, along with the usual cafés and American fast food outlets.
An enjoyable walk in the sun and decent shopping but nothing special.

Underground train stop. From Reus, take the Regional Express train to Barcelona and than get off the Passeig de Gracia stop. This is a good starting point to explore Barcelona. From both sides of the avenue, you can dine and shop at your heart's content as well as view some of Gaudi's architectural works of wonder. It is worth the stroll on a beautiful sunny day.
Goods shops. All the famous shops are here!Zara. Diesel, H&M. Gap etc.Fantastic place to expend money in a good way.

high end stores. We got an apartment for a week along passeig and it was one of the best decision ever. Plenty of shops, food and attractions. Just walk and you get to see most of the high end designer brands .Several metro station also located in the area for easy access to la rambla if you do not want to walk.The hop on and hop off buses has drop off and pick up points at this area also.

Great. Barcelona is one of the most beautiful cities I have ever seen . The architecture is stunning. The city is lean and beautiful.themIn street through the city is like 5th Avenue. Upscale and designer stores are all along the street. Great for shopping or people watching.

A MUST See .... If you visit Barcelona and do not visit Passeig de Gracia you have not seen Barcelona. The square with its fountains, statues and surrounding businesses is a highlight of the central city. Sidewalk cafes, shopping and vendors fill the streets, as well as the ever-popular Hard Rock Cafe, which is always busy.

Nice shopping street.. We visited Barcelona in the hot July summer and loved Passeig de Gracia.It is wide boulevard with tons of stores, and people.Just take time to stroll down, or up and enjoy Barcelona.

Worth the walk. I loved Barcelona and Passeig de Gracia was one of my favourites. Nice stores ( if you take one of the side streets you'll see Spanish designers too) nice for people watching. I'll recommend to sit and have a coffee or beer but the food is better in other places ( and cheaper too) you'll see the Pedrera and the Casa Batllo too. Make sure you bring your wallet or extra credit cards.

Better than La Rambla. We liked here more than La Rambla which is very touristic and crowded. Passeig de Gracia is a decent street with many places to eat, drink and shop also with cultural and historical buildings.

Worth a Stroll. Lots and lots of expensive shopping. Much like New York's 5th Ave or the Champs Elysees in Paris there are most of the top brand retailers in the world located on Passeig de Gracia. there was construction on going while we where there widening the pedestrian walkways. Its worth a look if you don't want to spend a lot of money you can always get a bite at the McDonald's sit in their outdoor cafe and people watch.

The Rodeo Drive of Barcelona!. This is the place for luxury shopping and eating. WOW!!! Prada, Gucci, Jimmy Choo, Stella McCarthy, Rolex, Armani, Hugo Boss, Chanel, Luis Vuitton, etc....like I said shop shop shop till your hearts delight! Very spacious street. We felt very safe in this area too, lots of security every where. Enjoy!
Beautiful!. Our apartment was right near this area ( a 3-4 minute walk). It is less crowded than La Rambla and there are plenty of shops to browse in!
Great shopping. This area is great for food and shopping! The store are cute/trendy and well priced. Just be cautious that stores and restaurants close in this area during mid afternoon.
Better than the Ramblas.... In this boulevard you can actually walk, unlike at the ramblas. Great area to eat or have a drink. I loved it!

An entire sreet of discoveries. I was lucky to get a hotel along the avenue, the entire street is full of historical monuments like the Casa Batlo of Gaudi, it has great restaurants and nice shopping places. It is less crowded and far safer than the La Rambla but still as alive. Many metro stations can be found along the avenue, and at one end is the Plaza Catalunya. It is also not far from the Sagrada Familia Cathedral. All in all a nice place to explore and stay.
One of my favorite places to walk. A great place to find luxury goods. Just go from one store to the next. Block after block of great shopping!Has so much to see.Fun to "people watch".
Very nice walking. Nothing to dislike. The street is really nice, with wonderful building specially casa battlo. There are large number of stores, cafes and restaurants
Designer shops. All the designer shops are here including Gucci, Tiffany, Jimmy Choo, Rolex etc. More normal shops appear towards the bottom of this impressive street.

Metro sauna!. Try to avoid having to do an underground Metro/Renfe transfer to L4(yellow Metro line). You have to walk down a 400m passageway that seems to radiate heat - maybe from the hot sidewalk above - somehow we managed to hit this passageway 3 times in less than a week! Not much fun with your suitcases!!

Standard Shopping. This is where you will find all the high street and designer fashion labels. Restaurants are good but in my opinion - they are there to serve the tourist who isnt adventourous enough to walk in to a true Tapas restaurant. Shopping is fine ! But can be found in any major shopping area/mall in the world.

Area is cute. The area is cute but if you are there to switch for a train to a subway it is quite confusing. There are underground well lit tunnels but confusing. Outside there are many shops and places to dine with sidewalk cafés. There are many name brand stores in the area.
Nice shopping, good walk. I loved the walking experience with all these shopping options. Good stores, nice view. Has a metro station which is convenient to head to another site as Plaza España

Out shines 5th Ave. As a native New Yorker and a booster of my home town it take quite a bit for me to a shopping area is ore impressive than 5th Ave, the broad boulevard, wide sidewalks, sidewalk cafés, and array of shops is worth the stroll.

Nice for a stroll or if you like to shop.. If you like high end shops or shopping in general this is the area for you. Our hotel was located right around the corner so we found ourselves in this area a lot. Sort of like a 5th avenue in New york city. We are not big shoppers so we would not have made this a destination spot to visit had we not been in the area already.
Lovely street. Lots of places to stop and shop...lovely restaurants and a lovely street to just wander down...a must see when here.

Much to see and do. This is one of many things to do and see in barcelona. The advantage in how the city had been designed is that it lends itself to leisurely walking and enjoyment, albeit in the hot summer sun.

Lovely street to walk.. This is a street that you need to walk to enjoy,one of the most important streets of Barcelona with the Gaudi's Casa Battlo and Mila,mayor brand names stores like Armani, Valentino,Channel etc. Restaurants to eat at every hour of the day from breakfast in the morning to tapas and wine at night, the tiles of the sidewalk,the streets lights with an iron work impressive,benches made out of broken tile,wich is a label of the city. A street that really worth a walk!!!!

Beautiful, cosmopolitan and very hip. This is one of the best pars of Barcelona to window shop or actually buy something. It also has a lot of restaurants and hotels and subway stations, aerobus connections and buses. It's in the center of the city and it's nice for a late afternoon walk.
Its ok. It's ok. Not the most fun shopping street compared to other cities, but nice to go and shop. Lots of outdoor cafe's to people watch.

charmin avenue full of people. My hostel was in this place. The modernist houses in this avenue are worth seen - at least from outside. It is very charming, but full of people, so if you want to go for a quiet place, avoid it.

Love the area!. Our apartment we went was on Passeig de Gracia 15. Thru our Europe family trip this rental and location was the best choice we made. Such a vibrant area. Walking distance to all the luxury boutiques, restaurants and train. Always feel safe at any hour. Love this area. If we come back to Barcelona will definitely stay in this area again.

Passeig. Our hotel was nearby so we walked Passeig de Gracia many times. Casa Battlo is on that street and Casa Mila is very close. Is a big road and very busy road but the drivers there seem that they are careful. Nice to walk in the morning for tapas and night for wine.
Interesting walk. Plenty of interesting buildings along the stretch, loads of shops and funky pavement. Especially some of the buildings Gaudi had designed, you'd appreciate them more with a guide.
A must for visiting Barcelona. Barcelona central avenue with beautiful fountains, shops, hotels, attractions and fun atmosphere. Worth a visit!

Favorite street in Barcelona. Passeig de Gracia is a great place to take a stroll as there are many stores to shop in and restaurants on the perpendicular side streets. It gets quite crowded with tourists, but is still a nice walk to do a bit of shopping or just people watching and to admire the architecture of the street (many Gaudi buildings).
Must see. A lovely tree lined avenue with lots of architecture, shops, restaurants and atmosphere. A must do on a trip to Barcelona.

A Museum of Architecture. If you can find all of the Spanish masters of painting in El Prado, then Passeig de Gràcia is the architectural equivalent. Not only will you find two of Gaudi's most famous buildings (the Casa Batllo and La Pedrera), but you will also find his lesser known (and harder to pronounce) contemporaries like Lluís Domènech i Montaner and Josep Puig i Cadafalch. This trio can all be found nestled next to each other on what is called the Block of Discord, thus named for their reputation for going against the grain at the time. The easiest way to describe it's location is by saying it's across from the McDonald's, which unfortunately has tables with some of the best views of the three masters' buildings for a €5 table charge. If you want something a bit more local, go down the street on the same block as McDonalds to the other corner on Passeig de Gràcia. There's a Spanish tapas chain with reasonable prices and a few tables with a view of Casa Batllo for those who want to drink in the facade with a tapa or two.Passeig de Gràcia does not begin and end with the Block of Discord, further up is Gaudi's Casa Mila a.k.a. La Pedrera, which was under renovation as of June 2014. Between and beyond, there are countless other buildings that are beautiful and unique in their own right designed by architects that have been all but forgotten among their legendary neighbors. Take some time and soak in the modernisme style that contributed so much to Barcelona, her atmosphere and the Catalunian cultural identity.

Quiet enjoyment. Our apartment hotel was on this street, which was quiet and safe. there are many stores for great shopping and many beautiful doors, balconies, buildings, etc. - including La Pedrera and Casa Battlo. Walking up & down Passeig de Gracia was always a pleasure.
Shoppers paradise. This is shoppers paradise. 3km designer brands. You can also find a Zara and hm. At the end on catalunya square there are two corte ingles a shopping center.

Not worth it. We passed it several times on the way to walk to / from center from Gracia. This place is very commercial and not worth it because there is nothing there that you don't see in any big city in North American.
Great shopping!. Zara, Mango, Adidas have a shop there, ofc, and many luxury brands, too. Many restaurants. A very long shopping street.

High End Part of Town. It's where the Hotel Casa Fuster (where we stayed) is. High end shopping in one direction, Syrian neighborhood in another. Within walking distance of Sagra Sophia and other Gaudi sites.

***Get your credit card ready...***. Passeig de Gracia reminds me a little of the Champs-Elysees, a long avenue with high-end shops, cafes and tourists. Having said that...the architecture, oh the architecture...Paris is good, but Barcelona is stunning. Casa Batllo, Casa Amatller, Casa Mila and any number of other Art Nouveau/Modernist buildings. I just found myself walking along looking up!!! Yes, it's touristy, yes, you will stop for coffee and people watch and your flexible friend will also make an appearance. My recommendation...take a stroll along in the evening when the fountain is lit, it's beautiful.
So much fun and action.. From the shopping to the cafes! Grab a pitcher of sangria and enjoy an afternoon on the Passeig de Gracia. Watch for my photos and reviews.

Gaudi, Barcelona Bus Turistic and high end shops. We walked to Passeig de Gracia to visit both Casa Batllo and Casa Mila, also has the main stops for Barcelona Bus Turistic (blue and red) - but if you like high end shops and have lots of cash this is also the place for you.
Shopping, Shopping, Shopping. All of the name brand stores. Comparable to every major shopping avenue in every world class city. You want it? It's there.
Just on the road to see. By passng the road, you will see the quarter.Not a miracle that Gaudi has designed these place as well...

High Energy Street. location, location, location. Everything you need and could want from McDonalds to exclusive designers' boutiques. Terrific metro service and the amazing Row of Discord - especially, Gaudi's Casa Batllo. Lots of good restaurants. Beautiful fountain. Go out and be part of the evening stroll.

Plenty of shopping and restaurants. This street is quite long and has plenty of big name and other shops including street front restaurants. Take your credit card and wear a comfortable pair of shoes. Gaudi's houses (Casa Bastllo and La pedera) are also on this street.
Worth visiting. If you like Barcelona areas overall - you should visit this one too. Clean streets, beautiful buildings and nice international atmosphere.
Nice shops, nice people!. If you want a more up market alternative to Las Ramblas then this is the place for you. Lots of nice shops and beautiful people!

Shopper's Paradise. I spent an entire day shopping and enjoying the atmosphere on this street. There are some fantastic shops and boutiques here and the service from the staff couldn't have been friendlier, even though I don't speak Spanish.
We also enjoyed some lovely food along this boulevard too, just stopping for snacks as and when we needed sustenance!
Perfect. My wife and I stayed here on our honeymoon and all facets; location, modern room, rates and service, were perfect. Would stay here again in a heartbeat.
Shopping. Our hotel was right on the Passeig de Gracia and it has to be similar to 5th Avenue in NY. Just make sure you have the budget because Barcelona is expensive

Chiq. Great, broad street with all of the haute designer labels. Tapas bars and outdoor cafes. El Corte Ingles, a great department store, as well. Gaudi architecture abounds. People watching at its best.

Shopping!. Passeig de Gracia is the place for shopping on a large scale. Most of the most important brands are there, save Dsquared for some reason. The Mcfashion brands are also lurking around although having taken over half of the rest of the city centre as well. A must-see with plenty of reductions (rebajas, rebaixes) for people who want to get a nice souvenir with a label on it.

Good point for those who loves shopping. Nice street full of shops and restaurants. Do not miss your camera because there are a lot of things that you would like to shoot... from beautiful architectures of the buildings to the street movements in the night :)

If you have it, spend it. This is a street full of Channel, Louis Vuitton, Louis St Laurent with cafe's dispersed. Nice place to spend the afternoon. Would be even better if you have the cash to buy yourself a nice Channel purse.

If you like shopping...... This is the 5th Avenue of Barcelona with all the usual high end shops. You will also find Gaudi's Casa Battlo--definitely worth a visit, but think about getting your tickets online to avoid lineups (and i spent 2Euros more for the fast pass--i walked right in)
Most beautiful street in Barcelona. Our hotel was located on Passeig de Gracia. This is Barcelona's Fifth Avenue with elegant shops and restaurants located in the area.
Nice Street. Wonderful central street in Barcelona where all the trendy shops, Barcelona's most emblematic buildings and the best restaurants. Highly recommended for a walk in the afternoon.

good visual overview of different architecture styles. You have to walk on this street to get to Casa Batllo and La Pedrera anyway, so no reason to miss it. It was good to see buildings by other designers besides Gaudi. Note the seashell patterned sidewalk tiles near the Casa Batllo area, the design was taken from a Gaudi house.

High end shopping. The best of the best is here on Passeige de Gracia. From Chanel to YSL
Wonderful for shopping, eating people watching.
You can see a few if gaudis masterpieces like predera and casa Battilo
We stayed at a great hotel just off the passeige, a great location.

you'd love it if you're a big shopper.. This was the closest to our hotel, I did not go to visit this area, I was staying in it. I'm not a big shopper but I could see how someone who is would enjoy it alot. all the fancy shops are there with the latest fashion trends and very nice windows that you could see it all.The area feels safe and clean. the side walks are wide. Enjoy your walk and shopping :)

Luxury Shopping. Perhaps one of Barcelona's main area for luxury shopping. My wife and daughter were in paradise although the only shopping they have done was of the window type. My and my son spent most of the time at rest sitting on one of the numerous bench along the road.

It's one place you can always get into. Barcelona was so mobbed in early June that we barely got into the sagrada familia cathedral (booking long in advance on internet) and could not even enter the famous market off Las Ramblas. We instead enjoyed the environs, including this neighborhood, where we stayed.

Interesting and chique. Whatever famous brand you seek is on this avenue. The sidewalks are wide and the street leads to Catalunya square and the ramblas. But don't try the sidewalk cafés. The prices are very high. For a sandwich, a slice of bread, a beer and a sangria we paid 58 euros!
Shops shops shops. I like to shop however this was amazing it was October so all the Christmas items were great and I would have taken lots home if I had more room in my case.
Probably the poshest place in Barca. Filled with designer shops and up-market tapas bars it is probably the most visited area next to the gothic and well worth a look.

great area. I'd highly recommend this area to stay as it is close enough for walking to Las Ramblas, close to some Gaudi attractions, has some lovely pavement cafes and is a wonderfully peaceful retreat at the end of a long sightseeing day!

The place to stay!. I chose hotel Casa Fuster at the end of Passeig de Gracia and walked to tours, restaurants from the hotel on the wide sidewalks, enjoying the clean streets, polite people, fountains and lovely designer shops. Great street to see a couple Gaudi buildings as well.

chic, trendy and central in a nice area. Nice central location in Barcelona, very safe and well serviced by public transport. This whole street is lined with beautiful buildings including Gaudi's creations. There are lots of fancy and chic shops to peruse, and lovely cafes to dine at and people watch.

Great stroll to view the gorgeous buildings and famous stores. It takes Anjou 45 minutes from the Old City pass some famous Gaudi's work as well as the windows of famous brands such as Channel etc. There you find enormous crowds of all ages and dress codes. We also visited the main store of El Corte Ingles
So Much Better than the Rambla!. This elegant avenue is lined with beautiful trees, fantastic restaurants, and beautiful boutiques. A very pleasant walk with lovely stops.

Best location in Barcelona. Stayed at a hotel in this street and after having gone around the city, I would have to say this is the place to be. You get a wonderful variety of shops, restaurants, cafes and there are tour bus and metro stops that make it easier to move around. The whole area stays alive even late at night and you feel safe taking a nice stroll down the street.

Grand Ave.. Several modernista buildings are on this road. Take a note of the street lamps that also provide benches. The street is lined with lots of shops some of which are of the high end. Even if you are not into shopping window watching could be fun here.

Interesting walk past several Gaudi buildings.. I followed a walk recommended in a guide books through Passeig de Garcia. It's one of the more expensive areas of BCN with beautiful buildings, shops and restaurants. There are several examples of Gaudi architecture, and attractive apartment buildings with pretty little courtyard gardens to be seen. I really enjoyed this hour long and easy walk.

The heart of Barcelona through which everything passes. This is the main street in Barcelona and is the equivalent of Fifth Avenue in NYC but with more charm and better architecture. If you visit the city, you'll undoubtedly stumble upon this wide boulevard flanked by countless restaurants and shops, so window shop till you drop and buy a baguette to munch on the go. It is a bit touristy, but I don't mind it because it still maintains enough Catalonian character to appease locals. The metro from the airport will take you straight to the heart of this street, so take a stroll here and see for yourself!

Where all the action is! - So much atmosphere. In the summer this place comes alive! Definitely the best place to be in Barcelona. During the day this epicenter is a great hub for shopping. Zara, H and M, you name it! All the best shopping for males and females is here. Plus its only a 20 minute stroll to the beach. At night this area comes alive with a nightlife and buzz like no other. Be safe! pick-pockets are around to grab your cash so be aware. So many great bargains can be found around at the local markets as well.

Favorite Street in Barcelona. This part of Barcelona has a completely different vibe from the Gothic quarter, with wide streets and beautiful art nouveau buildings. Makes for an excellent stroll, particularly if you're planning on visiting Casa Batllo or Casa Mila. It's very classy.

great shopping street. Have lived in Barca previously and just love something about this street, it's wide, great pavements, lots of good architecture, busy streets crossing it, a big buzz of excitement on it and some decent shopping thrown in. Have never eaten here and never intend too but it's a great street in a great City.

Shopping. No doubt the ladies will enjoy this as much as my wife did. However to me it was just another shopping street, albeit with high end names like Gucci etc.. If you like shopping you will like it. Some interesting Gaudi architecture here.

Lush shopping strip in the heart of the city.. Stunning wide streelined avenue, much like the Champs-Elysees in Paris or Regents Street in London. Lots of beautiful buildings to marvel at (including La Pedrera and Casa Batllo by Gaudi), and lots of wonderful stores to shop in. Designers and highstreet fashion. It's not for everyone but the street is worth a wander for the atmosphere.

Favorite place. I love Barcelona and Passieg de Gracia really is one main reason. We stayed in an apartment right off this great street. It's lively with restaurants, bakeries, bars and is a shoppers paradise. It's clean, busy and magical, just like the beautiful city of Barcelona. You can't visit Barcelona without spending a day walking, eating and shopping on this great street.

THE street. If we compare, Passeig the Gràcia is to Barcelona what 5th avenue or Champs elysees to NY or Paris. A street full of life, colours and great places, besides some of the nicest buildings in the city. are you going to miss it?

got ripped off at La Baguetina. We stopped for a spot of lunch away from la ramblas as got ripped off there 8yrs ago, well we got totally and utterly robbed blind at this place. Disgusted that I was charged €21.00 for a 0.5l glass of sangria argued with the waiter about our total bill coming to €42.00 for 2 sandwiches at €8.50 each a can of fanta €4.00.DO NOT USE THIS PLACE. IT WANTS TRADING STANDARDS OR EQUIVALENT TO INVESTIGATE ITS ROBBING WAYS

Boutique Central. Passieg de Gracia is the perfect place to job off the Metro and spend hours exploring. Hugo Boss store as my land mark you can stroll away the afternoon with all you need in the vicinity.
safety. lived near this street - 2 main Gaudi´s architecture is there. if you pay attention your eye can catch a lot of small details that are really nice.really safe!!
beautifull architecture and luxury shops. A must in Barcelona for Gaudi houses (which are very nice and interesting to visit even though I usually don't like its work)
Lively, upmarket street. This street is very nice, it's wide & has some wonderful shops as well as delightful Gaudi attractions & bars with outdoor seating

Shopping street. The most noticeable street in Bcn where you can find all premium stores, such as prada, gucci, tiffany etc. Starting from its very beginning you can get to Plaça de Catalunya metro station where the streets starts and go through it straight ahead passing metro Passieg de Gracia and Diagonal. If tax free needed you can get it if buy more than 90 EUR, bringing the passport with you while shopping because they ask for it.Not only stores are the main attractions of the street, there you can find also the architectural monuments of the genius Gaudi, such as Casa Milà "La Pedrera" and Casa Batlló.
Shoppers Paradise. If you are looking for the best shops in Barcelona, this street has them! I often walked this street on my way to other sites, just to enjoy the window shopping.

Pleasant street for browsing. Lots of high end shops for window browsing. Some good restaurants. Far fewer tourists and crowding than on Las Ramblas. Some great architecture on this street as well as 5 start hotels.
Lovely Stroll. Stayed very near this lovely street. If it's your first visit to Spain, you'll enjoy the walk, stores and pleasant cafe's along the way.

Loved the buildings and long street full of shops. You should go here for shopping, for strolling or even just for hanging out. This street is full of restaurants, up-scale shopping brands and great buildings!A must visit

Beautiful. We happened upon Passeig de Gracia on a stroll through the neighborhoods near Las Ramblas. It is a beautiful place. Still, I enjoyed walking and experiencing Barcelona on foot. Wonderful city.
nice shop for bigger budget. if you like shopping, you must take walk in this street... but be careful for your budget, here you can find the more expensive brands ;-)
The Champs Elysées of Barca. If you are in deep need of Fashion House brands this would be the avenue to be. Obisously you'll need to carry the right credit card in your wallet...
Busy street. It is just a busy shopping area, with lots of restaurants, tourists. Good for window shopping and to have a cup of coffee.

Beats La Rambla by a mile. One of the world's great thoroughfares. Wide pavements, fantastic architectural detail, great shopping, lovely cafes to sit out and people watch in - what more could you want?

This is the heart of Modernismo Movement in Barcelona. This area and surrounding streets are the heart of the Modernismo movement in Barcelona. You can't leave Barcelona without visiting. Just walking through the area you will see beautiful architecture and wonderful shops. Come at a few different times and will get a feel for the "real" Barcelona. Of course some of Guadi's masterpieces are in this area, but you will see other magnificent architecture created by less known architects. A wonderful place for people watching, having a drink at one of the outdoor cafes and just watching life pass by.

Very crowded in the summer but still wonderful.. How the city designers many years ago could have had the foresight to plan such a wide boulevard with plenty of room for pedestrians and cars is amazing. It is great for people watching and window shopping. But I would recommend spending more time on the street one block over that runs parallel --- Rambla de Catalunya. It has wonderful shops that are very individualistic and better restaurants in the middle of the street.

Great people watching street. Everyone who visits Barcelona needs to visit Passeig de Gracia. The street is lined with outdoor restaurants, filled with the smell of delicious tapas. Its a great location for people watching, and they have all kind of street entertainers, who are extremely talented. It also has shops, but the shops are more souvenier type shops, not really any quality stores.
nice area. Stayed in royal hotel on passeig de garcia. Nice location, very safe, well serviced by public transport

Brilliant street. Great for tapas, shopping, drinking and seeing.The famous bone house is on this street along with another Guadi building. loads of nice tapas bars, little shops and as an F1 fan, the Ferrari shop, complete with full size display car

The Park Avenue of Barcelona. Many, many upscale boutiques in this picturesque street. Great shopping and many outdoor cafés to rest your legs between shopping excursions. Safe area to walk and shop in a city where danger can lurk for the unaware. A must visit area for anyone going to this great city.
Great sightseeing waling trip. Enjoy the architectural beauties of Barcelona while walking in this promenade. Stores, food, people, let yourself be immersed on the sounds and smell of Barcelona!

Beautiful street for an afternoon stroll. This whole street is lined with beautiful buildings, both domiciles and Gaudi's unique creations. There are fancy shops to peruse, inviting sidewalk cafes to dine at, and an overall wonderful atmosphere.

one and only. the road with the expensive store .very nice road for walk alone or not (better alone) ,there is not place for women all the butique for women are there.... vitorio, luis vuiton , dolce , all the first class anyway you can stay for a coffee or walk at the alleys,it is uniqe i recomend it

Main drag. This is the main drag in the L'exaimple district that will run you right down to the Plaza Catayuna and onto the Barri Gotic. The highlight of the walk is the Apple of Discord or Block of Discord that includes Gaudi's trippy masterpiece, Casa Batilo, which is prohibitively expensive to enter in my opinion but great to admire from the street for free

Shop till you drop. A bit on the pricey side but worth strolling up and down. Avoid it on a rainy day or leave your credit cards in the hotel safe. Stepping out of the rain and stepping in one of those fashion temples turned out to be an expensive experience in the end.

Barcelona's Oxford Street!. Posh shops, wide street. It costs you nothing to walk along it and enjoy the vibe, but would cost a lot if you shopped/ate here. La Pedrera and Casa Batllo, two of Gaudi's most interesting buildings, are found along here, although I was disappointed that La Pedrera was covered by screens and undergoing refurbishment when we walked past - I'm not sure how long this situation will last.Imaginarium is a very nice toy shop with a frozen yogurt snack bar. Not cheap though.I'd recommend having lunch in the top floor self-service restaurant of El Corte Ingles department store which is at "La Rambla" end of Passeig de G. The hot meal portions are large, so get one between two, and enjoy the panoramic views.We did Passeig de G and La Rambla one after the other, with lunch as described above to break up the roughly 1.2m total walk.It was fun.
Beautiful street. Go early or late to miss the crowds but don't miss the fabulous architecture...don't forget to look up!

Lots of chain stores and name brand shopping. This street is full of tourists doing lots of shopping. A very large selection of restaurants are available as well. Since I am from the the States, I did not do any shopping here. Generally speaking, the prices in Europe are way higher than the States. You will also walk past a few of the museums along the way. It is a very safe street to walk along even late at night.

Inevitable That Will See This.... A VERY central location and if you use the metro you will find that you are at this station a lot, plus its very close to other main attractions. Its very nice to see at night and a total must i would say. You will see a few times during your stay, so make sure to see it night and day for the different effects, very cool. :D

Long business area in a modern city. Full of Luxury stores like Champs-Élysées Paris. Many famous building are there such as Casa Lleó i Morera, Casa Amatller, Casa Batlló and La Pedrera.These famous building also were art in building and of course the ticket is expensive. Google them in the website to decide to visit them or not before leaving should be a good move.

Beautiful, but.... The streets are clean and well kept. They also are beautiful, but...The shops are the same as the expensive streets in other big city's.I couldn't find one Barcelona exclusive shop. I was also really disappointed with the personel of the shops. They are only there to take your bankcard and charge it, instead of helping you. In the Louis Vuitton shop I walked away after asking 2 staffmembers to help me and waiting for about 15 minutes. This is not LV exclusive too bad...

Chic and trendy. Though it's full of the big brands, this street also has some of the best architecture in the city. Plenty of great places to eat and drink and you'll find having a glass of wine sitting outside will not cost anymore than in the rest of he city

Lotsa shopping, but I wish they were closer together and more organized. Many great shops along this stretch, although it takes a bit of effort to go from the left side to the right side and back again through the whole stretch to find what you like. Its a bit of effort and can be confusing sometimes, but i guess this is part of the shop and walk magic!

The Ritzee Area of Barcelona.. Passeig de Gracia is were all the big names are found. Take out your wallet if you want to shop there. You can go though just to look at the beautiful buildings and sit for a glass of wine at a cafe. In Barcelona you cannot walk with your head looking down: every building is a work of art and the best place to see it is probably Passeig de Gracia and Diagonal.

The place to be. I certainly can't afford the prices but I love to window shop and this is the place to do it... Great photo opportunities for Gaudi buildings or just stop for coffee and watch the world go buy.
sloane street in BCN. Top luxury brands for those with loads of money and a great loewe handbag shop. But they are digging a lot of the road up at the moment which made it very noisy and dusty.
Shop, Shop and Shop. Oh and some great buildings. This is the place to shop wit designer shops galore. And in amongst them all some great buildings including some of Gaudi's finest

Shopping paradise. If you like designer shops, then this is where you need to go! Prada, Gucci, Channel, etc... It's a paradise for your eyes, and a hell for your pockets :D. You can walk from one end to the other easily, or you can jump on the metro. Make sure you spot the gems left from Gaudi on the way.

Very enjoyable. Very nice high end designer shops and restaurants. Very enjoyable sidewalk sitting, if you prefer. Enjoyable atmosphere and varied architecture. Has three stops on the Hop On/Off tourist bus.
Shopping haven. Love, love, love....fabulous shopping, great tapas bars where you can take a break and enjoy a glass of wine and delicious nibbles.

Shop, Eat, Gawk, Gaudi. This is a beautiful, proud, modern, sophisticated street with lots of fashions and dining spots. Sit out on the street and have a drink or gellato and watch people go by. There are also a couple of Gaudi homes you can visit. Start at Catalonya Square and just keep going.

Fifth Avenue Of Barcelona. My wife's heart belongs here, after seeing the masterpiece of Gaudi then walk on until we reach Casa Mila, worth strollin until finally you have to rest and start again, a beautiful place.

Great place to walk. One of the most beautiful and also busiest streets in Barcelona.A lot of old buildings with nice architecture,including the famous Gaudi's Casa Batlo and Casa Mila-La Pedrera,restaurants,expensive shops,cafes.One of its ends is in Placa Catalunya(Catalunya Square).
It'a real delight to walk here.

Big and wide. This street is full of shops and restaurants and also lots of tourists wandering around. Adding to this many busy local business people, and the atmosphere is quite hectic from time to time. Had lunch there once.
The Oxford Street of Barcelona. A street like no other in Barcelona. Many high street shops and restaurants and the Apple Store at No 1 is probably the biggest attraction.

The gran via/ Serrano of Barcelona. Great area to just walk around. Lots of name brand shops and restaurants around the area. La Padrera and Casa Batllo are all stops along the way on this street. Don't forget to look up at the buildings and walk around the streets around Passeig de gracia. The architecture on this street is quite beautiful! You never know what kind of hidden treasures you'll find behind the street. This is definitely one street on your trip in Barcelona that you have to see!

too much russians. Great area for shopping but extremely overcrowded, especially with russians. Although, all top ranked brands u will find there. Advice to visit Lotusse store - quality Spanish shoe maker1

The Beverly Hills of Barcelona. We were very impressed by the Passeig de Gracia. Our hotel was just one block away so we spent a lot of time walking down this street. It is a beautiful tree-lined street with excellent restaurants, shopping and a pleasant walking experience. Barcelona is such a clean city everywhere we went but it is especially nice down the Passeig de Gracia. The shopping is very upscale so that is why I titled my review The Beverly Hills of Barcelona. We were very happy to stay in the Eixample area of Barcelona and dined quite frequently on this beautiful street.
ritzy. the grand avenue of barcelona. expensive shops, restaurants, hotels. great place to check out. make sure that you see the pedrera and batllo while you are strolling around

Nice, but expensive. This is one of "The" shopping areas on Barcelona. The shops here are very high end- Tiffany's, Rolex, etc. It's a nice place to walk and people-watch, but be prepared to spend a lot in any store, shop, or cafe.

Unique boulevard. The spanish Champs Elysee with 2 major Gaudi´s works. Lot of nice cafes, fashion boutiques, metro stations, luxury hotels,... Once in Barcelona, you must walk trough Passeig de Gracia.

An exciting city road. This wide spacious clean road hosts many fabulous shops, museums, banks, restaurants- it leads to the centre of the city, placa Catalunya- convenient for the hop on-hop off buses

A great walk. This is the premier street in Barcelona for shopping with numerous upmarket shops, hotels and restaurants on the road or nearby. And -- the attraction of interesting architecture including a couple of Gaudi masterpieces such a the Casa Batllo and Perdera. Take a few hours to wander up and down the street - if the prices of the goods are too high, then you don't need to buy anything (we didn't) but just enjoy the atmosphere. We had lunch here a couple of times and although it's not cheap, we didn't think it was any higher than elsewhere in the city, and you get the bonus of watching the world walk by as you enjoy your food.

The fifth ave and Rodeo Dr of Barcelona.. Every high end store you can think of is located here. Gucci, Valentino, Guess, Ferragamo and many many more. There are many stores with something for all. Many restaurants and cafes along this street where you can walk the center of the boulevard.

To see later when work is done. With La pedreira covered, el paseo de gracias under heavy work, this is not the best time to visit. But the crowd are still huge which means that this avenue does not lose its magic.

One of the most beautiful streets in the world.. Beautiful buildings and shops, lots of people, many choices for lunch and other meals, trees, seats, beautiful pavement on the sidewalks, a wonderful place to be.

Impressive. One of the most emblematic avenues in Barcelona (especially because of the modernist buildings by Gaudi and other Catalan architects) and not to be missed. But I would not go there for a meal unless you have a specific place in mind. Some of the restaurants are quite a rip-off. I would look for restaurants in the streets that cross the Passeig de Grácia and also have a look at the Rambla de Catalunya next to it, which is even more beautiful.
Stunning buildings. A very nice area with beautiful buildings and original architecture. Take a walk or bike around, this area is worth visiting.
A charming street. A nice stroll among beautiful buildings, restaurants, and shops. Most of the stores are international chains ranging from mid-price to high end
Once of the best streets in town. Best street in town for going shopping , walk and see la pedrera or casa batllo , great restaurants and great hotels
Interesting street. There is not enough eyes to see all the beautiful buildings, shops and attractions when walking through this avenue.
high end st. it was a nice stroll, I took a walk just to compare it with our Rodeo Driver, many of the same stores, a nice walk I have to admit

nice but crowdy. if you're looking for Gaudi architecture, you will find there few of his famous buildings. if you're looking for shopping, it's the most popular street with shops, big brands etc.if you're looking for both - it's perfect place for you.

No toilets. Beware, it is difficult to find a toilet here. Best bet is to go to a mall - but there may not be toilets at every level, and no signs to find one. I could not enjoy passeig de gracia because I spent half the time looking for a toilet, and in the end gave up and went back to my hotel, tired and frustrated.
Lovely walk, lots to see. The Gaudi buildings are the highlight, of course, but there are many beautiful buildings along this road. And lots of shopping, too!!

Subway station/train station confusing. The Passeig de Gracia subway station is enormous and has entrances several blocks from one another. We thought we would be coming up across the street from the Casa Batllo, but were actually about 4 blocks away when we got to street level. We also took the train from there to Figueres. I suppose you can access the train from some points in the subway station, but we ended up going down from the street into a section that put us directly at the train. The first couple of machines we tried to buy train tickets from would not accept cash. We ended up having to go back to street level and find another entrance to the train station and try other machines.We saw some confused and tired travelers arriving with their luggage and completely disoriented when they got to street level. If you are arriving into Barcelona at this station, make sure you have a street map/app with you. Once you get to street level, the street signs are usually posted on the corners of the buildings.By the way, the subway system in Barcelona is wonderful. It's clean and efficient. We never had to wait more than a couple of minutes.
Lots of shopping. There are plenty of shops to choose from. There are also plenty of street side restaurants for a coffee and a snack. Don't expect quality meals though.
The Champ Elysees of Barcelona. This street is designer shop lined street but unlike champ Elysees has casa battlo on the same street. Good for some window shopping

Four words: Casa Batlló-Casa Milá. Just for those two architectural gems you HAVE to enjoy a good stroll at Passeig de Gracia. Plus there many beautiful buildings by other modernist architects other than Gaudí: Lluís Domènech i Montaner and Josep Puig i Cadafalch. If in a rush find the corner in which the three left their staple (la esquina de la discordia in Sp)... Plus there is fancy shopping too.
All the shops you need, fewere of the tourist traffic you don't.. Camper. Ah, Camper. And some lovely shops along the way! Some you know, some you don't. It's a civilised shoppers area.

Food food food. Some great restaurants and shopping if thats what you are there for. Spoilt for choice when it comes to eateries. One of Gaudi's houses was under renovation while we were there. I was thoroughly impressed with the cleanliness of the streets, especially after spending time in the UK.

Shop shop shop. This is the main shopping area. It's hustle bustle all the way at this place. It's the heart of the city, lots of bars, restaurants, shops etc. Great place to see how the Spanish do things.
exclusive. Reminded me of the Champs Elysees - beautiful wide tree lined boulevard with lots of expensive shops. nice for a stroll.

Beautiful walk. This is main shopping street in barcelona. Worth seeing the Loewe store from outside. Also there are several resturants and quite a few hotels on this road like casa fluster. Worth a walk on this road about 1.5 Kms long.
Central Location. Great area to shop, grab lunch and people watch. It's a popular area and tended to be where we switched trains a lot. Pop up, see Casa Bastllo and hang out!
Great shopping and window shopping. A beautiful street with beautiful buildings. However, as my daughter rightly commented, when you are in Barcelona, you don't go to Mcdonalds!
Very Beautiful street. The street is very wide and full of decorations and historical building that makes you wonder how beautiful was that street in the 19s

LOVE THIS PLACE. A very happening place! I stayed there during my Barcelona vacation. They have McD, lots of tapas restaurants and lots of shopping stores. But I must tell that the safety is not very good. Take care of your belongings. Do not leave them at the side or you will find them missing after a few good minutes. That happened to my friend and he was very lucky to have his things back, especially passport!

Designer shops and designer buildings!. Walked up and down this road to get back to our hotel each day!Some fantastic buildings and the architecture is fantastic. They're lit up at night too so make sure you go both day and night!

The luxurious street of BCN. Go through the Paseo de gracia street and see the beutiful architectural designs where ancient and modern meet. Take pics of the Gaudi houses (Batllo and Mila) and the other buildings you will see... Avoid eating there: It's expensive and not the best food in town.

Great place to shop. Plenty of upmarket shops for you to wander around, however what makes this place really special is the great selection of specialist shops. Fantastic cafés and restaurants aplenty, great place for an afternoon stroll even if you can't afford to buy a new wardrobe.StewartA
Lot's of Fun. Lot's going on, very nice, high end stores. Places to grab a bite and Casa Batilo and La Pedrera are on this street.
Nice Avenue. You can find lots of Zara's H&m's Mango's around the avenue. Nice for walking and shopping if you prefer to eat you have u skip the parellel avenue which is Rambla De Catalunya.
Great central location. This street had it all, lots of restaurants and shops, the block of discord, Casa Mila and of course Placa Catalunya, the center of it all.
Great Shopping Area. With 'local' access via Public Transport [direct from/to Sitges] - this area will suit all day trippers who want to shop / view the sights / dine and socialise.

Beautiful steet with shops and restaurants. I've been in Barcelona last here with friends. We had such a great time there! We's rented an apartment near passeig de Gracia and every day we pass through this street to go everywhere. Is a huge street full of big shops like Zara, H&M... and there's very good restaurants in the middle of the street where you can eat and drink and enjoy the view. There's some fountains in the middle of the road and during the evening they change colors. Suggested!
Good shopping. We went there for some shopping for my gf and we found plenty of places such as Zara, Mango, H&M, Bershka. It is good that everything is in there! Do not skip it to buy a souvenir!
incredible to buy. The most important and current stores of the moment, you can found in this emblematic street. There are a lot of restaurants for lunch and enjoy the shopping day.

Nice stroll. Lots of places to eat, drink and shop. Easy access metro stations to all parts of the city. Very busy be aware of the traffic lights, be cautious of bikes and cyclists even when its green.

Very fancy. Very fance, and if Burberry, Tiffanys and other luxurious brands are your cup of tea this should be heaven. Personally I felt a little lost, and could not get down to La Rambla fast enough.

Every building is a masterpiece!. I don't really care about the fashion stores, but the boulevard is magnificent with its architecture! It's a feast for the eyes all along. You just walk and look up on both sides, afraid you might miss something. Of course, while looking up, beware of pick-pockets! Luckily, we didn't see any but many locals warned us.
Shop,Look,Look. Pretty. Street to stroll and take in all the high end companies.Lots of shopping. Loved the palms lining the street.

Good shopping street although chains and high prices. If you're looking for something a bit different this is not the place to go. Although ideal for everyone looking for the mangos and zaras of spain! Quite high brow shopping too, although a wonder around the littel alleyways of gothic garantee a better insight into the charming city of Barcelona and will not fail to suprise with the discovery of constant gems. Some fabulous jewellry stores are hidden in the creases. Although some must-visit places on passeo de gracia like the casa mila. Personally i think it's overrated, plus you can get all those shops in most countries of Europe and more
Grace Avenue. It is a great street with wonderful boutiques just like Chanel, Cartier, Loewe, Valentino but also Gaudí ´s architecture with Casa Batlló and Milà

Fun, busy street. Pricey, but fun Street to shop and find tapas. The architecture is stunning, and there are a lot of other important monuments along the way if you stroll towards Plaza Catalunya and Camino de las Ramblas.

Fantastic Shopping. A stretch of street with intercepting alleys full of retail boutiques from luxury brands to high street fashion. Many cafes and restaurants can be found on the street to rest and recharge. If you have a deep pocket, this is the place to shop to your heart's content!

The buildings are classic. Great place to hang out and shop. As a tourist, be careful in big stores like Nike. They have professional people who pick people's pockets. The security cameras are just for show and are not live and the security guard claims he does not understand English when you complain that you have lost your wallet when you were paying. There are no lines to in front of the cash register and the store manager does not care. They are immune to this and and are not worried about the safety of the customers but are more concerned about goods being shop-lifted. I reported the problem to Nike in the US but got lip-service. The hotel concierge called the Nike store but did not have much luck.My advise is not to carry cash or your ID on you. Use a credit card if you have to shop.The local cops do not care and some of the police stations are not staffed with cops who speak English.This continues to be a big problem in parts of Europe and does put a damper on tourism.

Fifth Avenue of Barcelona. The high end retail boulevard going through the ritziest part of Eixample. You'll see all the familiar luxury brands as well as some of Gaudi's famous creations. Definitely worth the stroll at night as you amble down to Catalunya.

Shopping at Chanel. One salesperson (young lady with long black hair and red lipstick) at the Chanel store ruined my experience! She did not know the products well and extremely impatient!! I only asked to look at two bags (ended up purchasing one), it wasn't like I asked to look at every single bag at the store! She was also joking and whispering with the security guard while I was completing my transaction, unprofessional! Also I did not receive my VAT refund for the Chanel purchase, I had no problem getting the VAT refund for purchases from other stores in Barcelona and Paris! I still have the receipt but can't get in contact with anyone that can help!!
Beautiful boulevard, amazing architecture. All the Zara's and Mango's you desire, as well as more high end designer stuff. Don't miss out on the Nespresso store, it's gigantic.

High end shoppers delight. If you want, it can be found on Passeig de Gracia. All the high-end retailers have shops on this street. Also a great place to have a glass of wine and watch the world go by.

Beautiful avenue. Passeig de Gracia should not be missed. And it cannot be missed, especially if Gaudi's Casa Batllo is on your itinerary.Forget the fancy shops that line the streets (besides there are other attractions in BCN that will empty your wallet) and enjoy the beautiful architecture and contemplate on the fact that nearly every apartment in those buildings has a balcony (ahh what a luxury!). I would recommend to see the passeig both during the day and at night when it is lit up. It is definitely an experience and an atmosphere not to be missed.
nothing special. just a big street with big shops, bars were no cheaper than any toursity areas, so we did not feel it worth the visit of the walking

Great for shopping. this was one of the main roads in Barcelona that we visited and it was great for shopping that ranged from normal average priced shops to the upmarket shops like Armani and Gucci, So this caters for all tastes and wallet size.

Main street for city discovering and shopping. The Passeig de Gracia is somehow the Oxford Street of Barcelona. If you are fan of Shopping, you can start there. Accessible by subway (Station Passeig de Gracia, or Diagonal), you can start you down walk until Placa Catalunya visit the Cathedral and then the famous La Rambla Street (Bouquinera Market and Raval old city). La Rambla will lead you until Christopher Columbus Column and the Sea side). The Passeig de gracia is a good start to walk, do some shopping, main brands are there, also you can find there Casa Batllo and Casa Pedrera. Not far from Metro Station (Passeig de Gracia), there is a Tourist Information Office.
Nice but high priced.. Wonderful to take a walk at a sunny day and look at some Chanel bags or an Armani suit. But no route fr shopping if you do not have a Rolex around your arms.

The perfect evening stroll, or morning or whenever. Fifth Avenue, Rodeo Drive, Champs Elysee, all rolled into one. Shops, trees, magnificent architecture, al fresco dining AND benches for sitting and watching the world stroll by. Take the time to let time stand still and stroll this boulevard at different times of the day, with your camera (safely) ready to take photos.
Designer shopping. A wide boulevard filled with world renowned designers.some great little restaurants here and amazing architecture.

Beautiful architecture. The Passeig de Gracia would be the equivalent of 5th Ave in Ny or Oxford in London. The difference is that the original architeture has been very well preserved. and so you may see the windows of the great brands but they´re all contained into these incredibly beautiful buildings, some of them many centuries old. It´s always lively and full of people, with stores, bars and restaurants all over. It is one of the most beautiful avenues I´ve walked. Barcelona´s world famous architecture at its best.

Amazing. I arrived in Barcelona alone, at 17 years of age and I decided to explore. I took the metro to Passeig de Gracia and walked along the boulevard several times, admiring the weather, the buildings, the shopping and of course Casa Batllo. With the amount of cafes, shops and ice cream parlors, you can never get bored. In case you do, you can always walk down to Plaza Catalunya and hang out along La Rambla, or just spend time around the plaza.
Best shops in the city. Here younwill find the best shops of the city , all the best brands are located in here, you can also found casa batllo and the pedrera, worth the visit.
Another beautiful place in BCN. Beautiful area to stroll around. Recommeded whrenyou go visit attractions in the area. Quiet neighborhood
Cool place to walk and hang out. Big expensive boulevard in the heart of Barcelona. Many high end branded shops. Some nice restaurants off the main boulevard.

Skip La Rambla. Walking around this area is one of the reasons that you visit Barcelona. Broad, classic streets, elegant shops, nice food. It is everything that La Rambla is not. Thanks to all of the nice hotels and restaurants, it also feels much safer than some other tourist areas.TIP: Stay near this area. It is central to many things and it is an easy place to find a taxi.

It's a life style. P d G is a street and an area. It's very upscale and very expensive, but it's very rich and worth the time to see. My hotel (Marriott Renaissance-very excellent since I got it on Priceline for $122/nite) was very good. I ate at a great Italian restaurant around the corner-La Tagliatella-that was fabulous and made Da Greco look like Wendy's. I am 65 and bought all the jewelry I need long ago, but the shops are there and they are expensive. There's maybe the best McDonald's I've ever seen on P de G; I don't like their fare, but, unlike Amerika, they have heat espresso and baked goods. The Metro stop is on an interesting linea L3. Good to go.

Good for designer shoppers. Passéig de Gracia is definitely worth a walk since it has some beautiful buildings of architectural importance like Casa Batlo by Antonio Gaudi , Casa Amatler and Casa Mila. Casa Mila though was covered by scaffolding. The street has major designer and high end shops like Prada, Chanel, Mango etc. There is nice little shopping mall called Boulevard Rosa which is a good place for shoppers. The walk leads to Placa Catalunya where there is a nine storied El Corte Ingles for shoppers and they can get the benefit of duty free as well.

It's just a very long street, but a nice one. It's lovely and busy here and a great spot if you want to sit and people watch. Great to find somewhere for lunch (always a gamble) or grab a drink and just rest the feet for an hour or two. Towards La Rambla direction is mostly tapas or pintxos restaurants, etc. and then upwards toward Diagonal it has the really high end shops, for those of you who enjoy the therapy.
Fancy street. It's like the Champs-Élysées of Barcelona. Great shops, cafes, restaurants on the street. I'd definitely recommend walking around if you have the time.

For the high end shoppers. If you like the high end stores, this is the place for you. Both sides of the streets are filled with the chain stores and probably over priced restaurants. The two Gaudi buildings are the highlights and a few of the fountains. So if your looking for architecture, I'd say it's average. If you like expensive stores, this is the street.

Worth a walk. A shopping street with some great architecture, interesting restaurants and shops. It was a good stroll, well worthwhile. You can see the outside of Casa Battlo and also Case Mila if it's not covered in scaffolding.

shopping!!!!. Our hotel was located here - I felt like I was on 5th ave in NYC- all the high end stores. The restaurants had outdoor dining with heat lamps so you could eat and "people watch" I would recommend staying in this area. It is a walk to the ramblas,a walk to the gothic area. Perfect location!

"The Posh End with amazing architecture". The Oxford Street of Barcelona! Some fabulous shops and delightful restaurants with some amazing architecture. Visit in the evening to see the Gaudi influence illuminated.

Classy!. We always take a stroll up and down the Passeig de Gracia whenever we go to Barcelona. Everything about it is attractive and classy. Girls, the shops are to die for! Can't afford the prices? Doesn't matter a jot really -- it's fun to just window shop and gaze wide-eyed. There are the Gaudi buildings, magnificent hotels and great pavement cafes. It's fabulous! And even my husband thinks it great -- so, you see, its not just for the girls!!
Perfect for a stroll. Lots of tapas spots, restaurant and unique shops. If the weather is good, it's an ideal avenue to stroll, sip and nibble.

GAUDI, GAUDI, GAUDI!. Really can't get enough of this man, first thing I did when I got home was to buy and read an autobioraphy. Truly a genius and his works, very varied from the walkways at Park Gruell to the statues at Sagrada Familia nand then the houses around the Passeig de Gracia amazing!

Plan a long visit here!. Loved the opera house tour. Great to see behind the scenes and the beautiful rooms. Had a cake and coffee in the famous Opera Cafe opposite and a stroll in the fabulous market. Great shops. Lovely flower sellers. What's not to love?

Perfect for shoppers with nice taste!. Wonderful shopping street - clean, fancy and lively. Watch your bag though as I have heard that pickpocketers target this area. Perfect for those that want some retail therapy (high end style).

The heart of fashion in Barcelona. All famous brands for clothes, shoes, and jeweleries are located in this Avenue. The decoration of the Avenue is beautiful and wide pavements (sidewalks) from both side of the road can assist you to enjoy a carefree shopping therapy... The picturesque homes of Gaudi are also located in this Avenue and can be visited (a fee starting from 16,0 to 21,0 €/person is applied)
great shopping mile. Husbands get hold of your credit cards, you can spend a fortune here. Really nice shops, fashion, jewellery, beautiful shoes from Stuart Weitzman.
Great. Great place to go. Lots going on.The buildings are beautiful. Lots of places to eat and drink. Well kept and clean.

shops and walks. up and down, down and up. one of the most beautiful streets of the city, full of shops and movement. i do not recommend to take a beer or a coffee there, better go to Rambla Catalunya.
Beautiful street. It is a delight to walk around in this beautiful street. Just see the buildings is already a must view.A lot place of good drinks and tapas.
Nice avenue. This is an long, important avenue with lots of well-known, expensive shops, restaurants and cafes. Walk through it to reach many attractions, such as Sagrada Familia's Cathedral.
Wow!!. If you like serious shopping or just window shopping this avenue is a must!! Every designer shop you can imagine. Just off Plaza Catalunya.

Lots of shopping. Lots of shopping on this street with a lot of high-end labels. The biggest names in fashion are all here together with the sales from Zara and Mango. Its a very nice walk along the streets and far better than La Ramblas, great if you love shopping.

Standard, international luxury drag, with a couple of jewels here and there. The only redeeming thing about PdG is that it's in Barcelona. There are some old-world stores that speak to a different age (Bel, for example) and there's the lovely floor tiles and street furniture, but in effect this is another globalised drag.
Nice enough as scenery as you walk to Casa Batllo, but otherwise not a destination.

Shop til you drop!. Tons of shopping and attractions on this streets. Way to many restaurants to choose from so do some research before hand if you plan eating out. There are also a couple Gaudi attractions on this street.

High energy. We loved the energy on this street, movement, action, shopping, business. We stopped in Prada and saw a woman's purse for 2500 Euro!
