It was a museum for us, but there were plenty of women buying, some from Japan, some local.We had a great tapas lunch in a restaurant that seemed small at first, but had a huge hall inside packed with people.

High end shopping. The people watching is great along the Passeig de Gracia. This is the fashion district of Barcelona, and prices reflect that. If you are shopping for gifts, souvenirs, or just looking for a more affordable place to eat, keep heading toward the Plaza Catalunya and continue down La Rambla toward the port. Food and shopping is more affordable for the average tourist.
The Street of Grace. A very nice driveway with a lot of shops and people, lights and music that leads onto the Plaza Catalunya, worth the walk
Shops and crowds. Very similar to New York's 5th avenue with a ton of shops and lots of people. It's worth a stroll through, but there are better places to spend your time in Barcelona

Shop til u drop. This is definitely a hustle/bustle street...so many nice shops tho some very expensive....good restaurants along the way. Convenient for metro stops and nearby hotels. Gets quite crowded over holidays of course and also after work hours. Beautiful lighted streets

A wonderful walking andf dining area. The modernism delights; beautiful buildings; wide graceful streets and a wonderful ambiance make theis area so wonderful.We did the Modernisme walking tour which was really terrific and very interesting. So many little things we would not otherwise have noticed or learned, with a personable guide who was very engaging.The walking tour was great and is very highly recommended (included with the Barcelona Card; Euro 31 per couple otherwise).The area is superb both in daytime and at night - simply wonderful.

The heart of Barcelona. If you are looking to stay central, you should stay close to Passeig the Gracia. Amazing shops, nice resturants and for business it is in the middle of the city! Perfect for the ariport bus as well that leaves from Plaza Catalunya. I really love this place! It is an upgrade of Champs d"Elysee in my eyes
Wow lovely place to walk. really enjoyed Passeig de Gracia great shopping excellent things to do and see and really enjoyed walking it

Nice street, good shops. OK, forget La Rambla. If you just feel like taking a nice walk - this is much better street. If you want to do some shopping - this is seriously better street. All the buildings in the street are nice, great shops, cool people, cozy bars and restaurants...

Shops, more shops and great architecture. We have spent about a day walking up and down Passieg de Gracia to and from the city centre and our apartment in Gracia. I don't think there's a shop missing (I was with three women so I should know) and there are plenty of places to eat and drink along the way. The street has an almost stately feel to it given the architecture generally and the Gaudi masterpieces dotted along the street.

Great street, lots of shops and restaurants. It's easy to find, and you can spend hours on this street. There are several museums close to the metro stop, and you can take the rail from here to the airport.
great atmosphere. we walk this shopping street during the X-mas holidays. It was rally cosy and fairytally :-) The shops are nice and also great restaurants. Good metro access

Lovely avenue. I love Passeig de Gràcia. It's a lovely street, very elegant. There you can find most of the best shops, best designers and even nice bookshops. It is to me one of the nicest streets in Barcelona. You can find places to eat there too, elegant pricey ones or affordable quick ones too. Up to you but I'm sure you will enjoy it.
Nice walk, high-class shopping. Worth the walk to see high-class shopping Barcelona-style, plus stunning architecture including Gaudi's two houses.
beautiful shopping avenue. nice shops (some very expensive ones), nice atmosphere for a perfect shopping feeling :)loved walking down these street

Shop till you Drop. You can get everything here just think of Barcelona as London with the outdoor spanish atmosphere and good food also dont be put off by the pick pockets just keep your things out of eyesight.......we had no problems and the people were brilliant
Sales. Best shops, luxury and common shops in a few meters well mixed and combined with restaurants to have a great shopping experience!
Spectacular. Barcelonas high class street looked amazing with the Christmas lights and modernista buildings lit up at night.Lovely for a stroll and a coffee and great photo opportunities.

Beautiful Street. Full of designer stores, luxurious hotels and restaurants.
Even walking around it is entertaining. Its really chic

Good shopping street. we stopped by Passeig de Gracia often during our six days stay we enjoyed the big shopping centre that is situated there we loved it although the prices were a bit higher for items that we would usually buy back home in London overall Passeig de Gracia is central to us getting back to our hotel near Selva de mar...

Great place to people watch. Passeig de Gracia has several upscale shops, boutiques and restaurants; howevrr, there is something for everyone. You will find Casa Batllo and a couple of Madrid's Tour Bus stops. The architecture is wonderful and some of the shops are incredible.

Get the direct airport train from here. We only found out, by the skin of our teeth, the Passeig de Gracia train, as opposed to metro station yesterday. The train takes you direct to the aiport in around 20 mins.This is a beautiful road with the Gaudi house right next to the metro station. The bus V17 is very useful- takes you straight to Barconeleta beach. Make sure you have a travel card, like the T10, so you can metro and bus hop when your feet hurt!
Grand boulevard with lots of shops.. Great street and lots of class. Similar to champs elisie. Just walking up and down the boulevard is a lot of fun.
Shoppers Paradise. Fabulous shopping area, lots of choice for everyone and plenty of places to stop for Tapas especially for exhausted husbands.

Barcelona's Champs Elysees. don't miss taking a stroll down Passeig de Gracia! lots of designer shops, cafes restaurants and lights! Casa Mila (La Pedrera), Casa Batllo and Casa Ametller are also on that street. *Tip: start from Casa Mila and walk all the way down to Catalunya square! its very refreshing and beautiful, especially at night

What a street!. Our hotel--Mandarin Oriental-was on the Passieg, which might be one of the most fascinating streets one will ever walk--and make sure to walk it! The Gaudi buildings as well as the many other architectural gems are well worth an entire trip to Barcelona.
Fun, lively and beautiful shops. This is a must-do when in Barcelona. The people, the stores, the restaurants, the architecture! Take your time going in and out of shops. Starbucks a plenty.
Nice stores !. The place to find nice and luxury stores like Ferrarri and other fashions stores. A great place to spend money !
An amazing part of the city!. On this street you can go shopping in nice shops and also you can see some historical places! I really like this street :)

Buildings are amazing. What a great walking area! The prized street in Barcelona, this area has "wow" architecture and great shops and restaurants everywhere. Outdoor performers, street artists, and outdoor sitting in a "upscale" environment - a bit less touristy than Las Ramblas but with all the charm. Great for an evening walk and dinner.

Save money. Save your money and spend it somewhere else! This is the designer street, so if you are looking to spend a pile of cash then come here, but if you are looking to find deals...go elsewhere. This is a beautiful street to simply walk down, but little past this.Oh... 3 stars actually! The architecture on several of the buildings is quite impressive and something nearly everyone can appreciate. I would go here again simply to see the architecture on the older structures, it is quite splendid!

A beautiful boulevard. In a very fashionable section of Barcelona as you willfind out as every conceivable international fashion house is located here. Additionally, there are shopsthat are unique to Barcelona.
Luxury Shopping. Brands, designers, luxury boutiques... A spanish version of Paris Rue St Honoré where Haute Couture stores are one after the other..

Posh shopping. Reminded me of that scene in 'Pretty Woman' where she tries to shop on Rodeo Drive and they won't serve her - all those names that we wish we could warrant going into, have shops to die for along this street, in fact it was a highlight just looking in the windows decked out for Christmas. Main through bus routes and metro terminals, La Pedera (casa Mila), casa Battlo and station stop direct from el Prat airport. Eat off the main street for better value - if money is no object eat and shop on the street.
Awesome. Totally takes your breath away, didnt have time to go inside because of ques, get there early, but just walking around the outside of this church is awe inspiring.

A posh thoroughfare.. Sided with chic fashion shops and nice restaurants, this is a very nice place to walk and breath the "air" of upscale Barcelonian lifestyle. However, the prices in the shops are accordingly high.

Barcelona's Grand Boulevard :-). The main shopping street of the city with brand shops...mostly for tourists, Barceloni do their shopping in many other places, but not here. 2 famous Gaudi buildings are here. Many good hotels (some even affordable as Eurostars Barcelona Desing or Sixty Two)

Got Money?. Every name in high fashion has at least one store on this fabulous boulevard. The wide, wide sidewalks are full of people. You can see some beautiful clothing, jewelry, and shoes all along the Passeig. Sidewalk restaurants complete the experience. We did walk over one block to another less wide street with more reasonably priced merchandise and restaurants. We even found a cobbler that makes custom shoes for men, unusual in my experience. Didn't buy any though - with exchange rate!

Lock up your credit cards. This is where the Spanish like to wonder up and down and for good reason. The place is full of designer shops and 2 Gaudi properties.If designer shopping is your thing you will not be disappointed there is every designer shop imaginable but don't expect it to be good value for money.The Gaudi house is on this road but costs something like 28 euros admission and you will have to queue at busy times. We just took photos from the outside at that was free.A great place to walk and look but overall leave the credit cards well locked up.

Wonderful relaxing area but be aware.. Wide boulevards , beautiful shopping area leading to Las Ramblas and place de Catalunia, great to sit outside and enjoy a relaxing drink while people watching, However Do Be Aware That the Thieves and con men still operate I this area ,which can spoil a perfect day if you drop your guard.

Nice, but expensive. This is like the 5th Avenue of Barcelona. It's very pretty and much of the architecture in the neighborhood is breathtaking. It is loaded with expensive shops like Chanel, Louis Vuitton, so caters to people with more money. I found the restaurants on this street to be pretty bad in general, serving tourist-quality tapas at high prices. To eat, I recommend making your way into the smaller streets to find better food. This is a great walking street and fun to visit, but not as charming as the Gothic Quarter, for example. At Christmas, many of the buildings on the street are brightly lit and it's pretty glorious.

Full of designer shops, but take time to visit the Gaudi dragon house and appartments. This is one of Barcelona's lovely wide streets, lined with trees. it houses the top designer shops, all with beautiful window displays, as well as tapas bars and restaurants. It is a lovely wall, but take the opportunity to visit the Gaudi dragon house and the Gaudi appartments further up the road. Both truly amazing.

Best walking street in Barcelona. The Passeig de Gracia can be reached by the metro of the same name. This street is fascinating with Gaudi's Casa Mila and Casa Battlo. The Hugo Boss store has unique architecture as well. There are many wonderful shopping opportunities to suit all price ranges. Some of the stores include: Zara, H & M, Pull and Bear, and many designer shops and boutiques. One of our favorite restaurants is La Bodegueta which has great meals of the day for 12.5 euros. It is crowded with locals. Notice the elegant lamp posts on the street. Another popular restaurant, La Rita, which is just off of Passeig de Gracia near the Casa Battlo, has a line waiting for the restaurant to open at 1:00. They have a fixed price daily special.

Best part of Barcelona. Definitely I would stay there when I go back to Barcelona again.The street is elegant.The stores and restaurants are better then the ones in Las Ramblas. It is not too crowded that you can walk.

Expensive. They neighborhood is filled with top end shops. The Gaudi buildings are incredible to look at from the street. The fee to enter the buildings is about $20.00 per person. That means if you visit two building with your partner you have spent $80.00 on what is better appreciated from the street. It is true you can get to the roof of each the buildings and look down on all the people who had the common sense to save their money.

Beautiful Boulevard, especially with Christmas lights. With so much of Gaudi's buildings, Passeig de Gracia is beautiful any day but with Christmas lights in the evening it's breath taking beautiful.Very high end stores but nice window shopping :-)

High-end Shopping & Fabulous Architecture. As we stayed in the Eixample District, we walked along Passeig de Gracia every day. It's a lovely area, with wide sidewalks, high-end shopping, and fabulous architecture. As other reviewers have noted, make sure to look up and around, otherwise you'll miss some beautiful architectural details. For an absolutely wonderful view up and down the Passeig de Gracia, head to the top floor of the Hotel Casa Fuster. We had stopped by the hotel one afternoon, and the bellman strongly advised we go to the rooftop terrace. We were thrilled with his recommendation, as the views were just fabulous!

Very busy even late evenings!!!. My first and only visit till date was many months ago and it was a fantastic experience taking a stroll on this street and around its neighbourhood. Even the side alleys and small passages that forked out from this place had a very chic feel to them. It also allowed me to get a feel of the city and its vibe. Overall a must place to visit if arriving for the first time.

Great shopping. All the high street shops you could ever wish for, but make sure to look up and around as well for some gorgeous Spanish architecture and even Gaudi's Casa Batllo is on this street. Passeig de Gracia very nicely connects the center of the city with the slightly more northern neighbourhood Eixample which is laced with nice hotels and fabulous restaurants.
A great walk to enjoy. The avenue is a wonderful place to expereince Barcelona and also shop among its extensive array of fine stores. Restaurnats are plentiful and also among its side steets.

Gaudi and Shopping. This is certainly a road full of interesting buildings including two of Gaudi's most famous Casa Batllo and Casa Mila. It is also a shoppers dream, it has all the designer shops you could need as well. Sit outside to enjoy a coffee, lunch to tapas and watch the world go by.
Great shopping street. Great busy shopping artery with loads of designer shops and stunning buildings - toddle up from Placa de Catalunya and then go back down the Ramblas de Catalunya

Nice strall, buildings and... shopping!. The best way to combine a beautiful walk, seeing Gaudí and other interesting buildings and shopping at local stores like Zara, Desigual etc or the most exclusive, luxury shops.Nice atmosphere, beautiful Gaudi-style benches... I always start my visits to Barcelona in Passeig de Gracia

Indications of wealth. My wife and I stayed in a hotel within a short walking distance from here, so we walked the whole length of the street, crossed the road to the other side and walked back. We had also done this at Champs Elysees in Paris and Unter den Linden in Berlin, in the past. There are excellent buildings and expensive shops to see on this street in Barcelona. We stopped at the Casa Batllo, to visit the inside of the place. Then, we walked to Casa Mila to have a look at the outside. We also had a look at the Loewe house.

Shopping at its best. This is a fantastic shopping experience. It has every major fashion brand. It starts with more mainstream brands such as Zara and Mango. The higher up you go, the more high street it becomes. Start at Zara and end at Michael Kors & Stella McCartney.

A road with interesting buildings. We decided to go along the passeig the Gracia as we knew there are Gaudí building on it as well as some nice shops. We chose this street on our way the the Sagrada Família. The buildings were beautiful (I can tell you they are beautiful all over Barcelona) and the shops interesting as well. When in Barcelona, you should at least see this street once.

See it from the HOHO. You need to experience the Passeig de Gracia area. We prefer markets and bargain shopping to name brands. But it is still interesting to walk through the area. If you are short on time, see it from the HOHO bus and spend your time in the neighborhoods that you like best. We prefer the historic areas with narrow streets and tiny shops and businesses.

Place to buy Versace:-). The street where you'll find all the gratest fashon designers' shops. Elegant and crowdy place in the center of the city. Not for loners or when looking for to get lost in the city:-) Heads up when strolling because besides the boutiques, restaurants and banks you will also find buildings such as La Pedrera-Casa Mila, Casa Batllo, designed by Antoni Gaudi, Casa Amatller and Casa Lleo Morera project Lluis Domènech i Muntaner and others such as La Unión y el Fénix Enrica Sagnier and Villavechia.

Great shopping, fun location. Although I certainly can't afford half the designers on this street, it is fun to window shop- and there's plenty of other shops to check out as well. This is a "happening" street, with plenty of sights and restaurants.
moderate. This is basically a huge avenue with clothes flagships has prada or Vuitton. Apart from that, while walking through it you'll find another great works of Gaudi.
Shopping. It is a very big avenue plenty of restaurants, boutiques and hotels.Excellent avenue for walking and shopping.On the same avenue you can find both buildings designed by Gaudi.

Good for branded goods shopping. Passeig de Gracia is a major thoroughfare of Barcelona that links to Placa de Catalunya, the heart of the city. Both hoho bus operators ply along the road. This stretch of the road offers good branded goods shopping opportunity. All well-known brands can be found here including the local Mango and Zara. A large 9-storey departmental store Cortes Ingles is just at the end of Paaseig de Gracia. Staying near this area gives you lot of convenience in terms of eating, drinking and shopping opportunity.

Architectural marvel, commercial absurdity. In the midst of ingenious architecture, the commercialism of hideous corporate sponsors have infiltrated what would otherwise be a lovely experience of a thriving thoroughfare. It has turned the culture into a frivolous enterprise, in which a giant store featuring coffeemakers has become a centerpiece. A disgrace!!
Love Barcelona. Barcelona and Passeig de Gracia are beautiful. I liked it much better than Paris and it was much cleaner. Friendly people, lots to see and mucho upscale shopping.

To shop here you need a big overdraft. If you like shopping and have a bulging wallet you will love it. The high end shops are amazing BUT there are many small shops/cafes and restaurants hidden just off the main street. Well worth a look

Extravagant High Style. Just for window shopping and people watching this street is worth a few strolls. This is where you will find Casa Batllo and La Pedrera by Gaudi. Every big luxury label has a shop front on this gorgeous, wide, historical avenue. My husband and I had a cup of coffee, a tea, and two pastries and it ran us about $25. Move off the avenue and down a block to save about $15.

Beautiful shopping street. This avenue is nice to visit while in Barcelona, mind you that all of the designer stores are there i.e: Gucci, Louis V. Armani... and all in the most admirable architectural buildings with the most sublime ambience. Loved IT!!!!

shoppers Heaven. A casual mayhaps uninterested stroll along this impressive avenue may well become an inspiration for the non-shoppers amongst you. Designer shops and boutiques from all the big fashion houses and a lot of smaller locally known designers are spread throughout the length of this road. The architecture alone is worth the walk of roughly half an hour each way, inspirations of Gaudi line the street as well as other architectural wonders.
Nice high-end shops. If you like to shop for designer brands, this is the place to be plus its so close to theother toyurist destinations like the Barri Gotic, Plaza Catalunya and the Las Ramblas.
Excellent for walking and shopping!. This street is always nice to visit while in Barcelona: a great number of brand shops and admirable architectural buildings - You'll surely love it!

Best shopping. Every shop you could ever want is on this street. Beware though that they are the really expensive shops. If you are looking for more boutique type stores this is not your street. If you want Gucci and prada, shop here.

Bustling high end shopping street. This was the main thoroughfare that my partner and I walked to get to Las Ramblas and were impressed by the quality of the designer stores and chichi eateries. Well worth a look.

A great shopping experience. If you are able to walk quite well you will enjoy a trip up one side and down the other of passeig de gracia, the main shopping street in Barcelona. All the big named shops are there, Gucci, Louis V, etc,etc. But remember you are in Barcelona, everything is expensive. Just try and enjoy the ambiance.

shop til you drop. Passeig de Gracia is an excellent place if you want to shop til you drop. Word of warning take plenty of money as it is full of exciting designer shops. either way its worth a browse just to see how the other half live.
Shopping, shopping and more shopping. What can I say, four forty-something ladies on a weekend away - by golly we shopped and this was the place to do it!

gracia passage. this special place in Barcelona is indeed special because of its translucent,eerie,magical,legendary,aura.anyone visiting it will immediately be transported back in time,to another page in Spanish history,and most especiaaly in Spanish history.the history in this place seems to be twofold: one is the sheer beauty of such place in history which is described in such vivid terms,the other is the special atmosphere.

Barcelona's Champs-Elysees. I knew nothing about Barcelona, when I started to research it for our trip. I was holding my breath in the airport van as we drove down this street as to whether we had chosen the right location. Beautiful street in a very central location. Considerable research did pay off.
Nice boulevard. A must see when visiting BArcelona. Nice mixture of shops, restaurants, people watching. especially on a sunny day or even at night. Nice and green and good for a stroll

Best to catch a glimpse from an open top bus. Busy, touristy, lined with shops and lots of traffic. Highlights are Guadi's buildings La Pedera and Casa Batilllo. If you are looking for a cheap place to feed the family then Lal Qila is couple of blocks away from La Pedera. Serves a mixed bag of international food. Nice quiet place, not too expensive and the food was ok. Seemed popular with locals during our lunch time visit.Apart from admiring Gaudi's buildings, I don't believe this area has much to offer. Placa de Catalunya with it's fountains would be a great hang out spot but it is spoilt by beggars and gypsies.

Beautiful boulevard!. One of the main arteries through the centre of Barcelona, and home to both Cassa Battlo and La Pedrera, as well as some amazing street lights, benches, restaurants and shops, as well as the many motorists of Barcelona who don't seem to pay much heed to red lights!

Beautiful Avenue!. We wandered down the Passeig de Gracia in order to view the distinctive Modern looking buildings situated on this street. There are also many high end shops located on this avenue. Two intriguing buildings located on this street, that are a must see are Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. Enjoy!
nice stroll. great boulevard to walk up one side and down the other. Two of Gaudi's buildings are on this street. Lots of shops and lovely architecture.

Great walking street. We stayed at the Majestic Hotel, on the corner of Valencia and Passeig de Gracia. Loved walking up and down the street, stopping at cafes, shopping in some fine stores, being amongst the people who were also lovin' it.
Very exciting street to walk in. I liked having many brand name shops as well as restaurants and several metro stations.Did not like the people who are roaming around asking tourists for money.
location. Has everything, for high end stores to restaurants.Most of the street cafes are mediocre.But area is close to everything

nice walk with good local restaurants nearby. I didn't care much for the street itself because we didn't have any intentions to go shopping but it's a nice walk if you have time. Also, our hotel recommended a popular local restaurant on a street nearby with the most amazing food ever! we had such a great lunch there. I don't remember the name of the restaurant but I definitely recommend asking your hotel for recommendations on good local restaurants because it's definitely worth the experience.

Shop, eat and relax.. Start from Placa de Catalunya, walking along this elegant street, full of shops, restaurants, cafes, wonderful houses and palaces, hotels, fountains. Here is the Casa Batllo and Casa Mila /la Pedrera/ two wonderful house made by Gaudi. After a big walk relax in a good restaurant terrace, and watching the people. Lot of luxury shops. Very pleasant place.

Touristic but fun. Every one says you cannot leave Barcelona without walking along the paseo de gracia and so we did. Plenty of tourists walking around and many fun things to buy. Highly recommended for an after lunch walk. Great tapas places along

Nothing all that special here. Though Rick Steves talks about how all the high muckety-mucks lived and still here, I didn't find the part of the street I walked down to be particularly interesting. There was the outside of the Casa Batlo to see, but the Champs d'Elysees has it all over this street.

Very chic and elegant avenue. Passeig de Gracia is one of the major avenue of the in Barcelona. You can find anything to want for shopping or eating. There are most important shopping and business areas, containing several of the city's most celebrated pieces of architecture.
Wide and wonderful. This is like Bond Street transported to a balmy Spanish City where the pavements are wide and cafés are welcoming. What a treat
Great for people watching. Ton of the usual expensive shops. Great for people watching. I wouldn't suggest eating right on the street, walk in a block or two to save

the champs elysees of Barcelona. very clean, enjoyable place where to go for shopping. all big luxury brands are there. man say Champs Elysees is the nicest avenue of the world: they might want to consider Passeig de Gracia prior telling this.

Big avenue to walk in while window shopping. Great and big avenue that starts at Plaza Catalunya and goes all the way up, if you wanna shop you should definitely go there! Just walking in this street looking at the architecture is amazing. There are the Casa batilo and the other one in this street, enjoy!!
Interesting. A nice place to walk and spent few hours relaxing in one of the many small restaurants, either for tapas or just for a glass of sangria!!!

We couldn't get down the street!. If you like looking at beautifully done shop windows, it's hard to get down the street. Our hotel was on the street and everyday when we went out, we just couldn't make it down the street without ducking into oneofthe stores. It just made us giggle, but we loved it!
Better than la Rambla. Head here if you like your shopping (shops like Mango, Zara, etc). much more enjoyable than La Rambla.
beautiful stores. this area is sort of like a 5th avenue! upscale stores, a nice walk to take, you must go if you're in Barcelona,

Tourists, tourists, tourists!. The day we had gone here it was some sort of holiday and festival. So the streets were packed and busy and full of tourists. Lots of stores around, but everyone kept telling us not to eat there cause it was pricey and the food quality was not worth it. But we did go back to shop there again, still busy, and crowded, but lots of souvenirs to buy.

great location for a hotel in Barcelona. Passeig de Gracia is about 5- 8 minutes walk from Playa De Catalunya, where you arrive on the airport bus, so not too far to walk with a case etc. its a wide avenue with trees in the centre, which softens the views of the buildings, and make it an attractive place to walk up and down and window shop, altho' you would need to be feeling flush to go in and buy anything in the rather expensive shops there. there are several Gaudi houses either on the street e.g. Casa Batllo, or nearby, and other Moderniste houses e.g. Caso Amatller, which is next door. You can get into the foyer of this one even tho' it doesnt look open to the public, as its split into apartments, but just push the door and go in, the concierge didnt seem to mind. Passeig de Gracia is well placed for a metro connection, and about 10 mins walk to the start of Las Ramblas, where most of the 'street-life' starts in the early evening. Our hotel, Hotel Granvia, was very well placed on Passeig de Gracia and a great place to stay, see separate review.

Beautiful. This is one of the most elegant streets in Barcelona. Full of elegant expensive and non so expensive shops, you can see beautiful buildings, impressive balconies and Gaudi's signature every where.

Beautiful boulevard. We were fortunate to stay on this beautiful tree-lined Barcelona boulevard full of outdoor restaurants, designer shops and spectacular Gaudi buildings such as Casa Mila & Casa Batillo. If you are visiting either or both of these Gaudi buildings take time to stroll along this boulevard even if you don't visit the designer shops or eat in the restaurants. There are bookstalls just up from Placa de Cataluyna selling a range of books mostly in spanish from crime fiction to architecture ...but it all adds to the atmosphere, reminiscent of parts of Paris but with a definite catalan vibe.

Stroll. This is one of the main streets of the old part of the city, and adorned with beautiful buildings (a few Gaudí!). Even the benches and lampposts are pretty! It is wide and spacious, and houses a number of first class stores. So stroll and shop!
Best At Night for The Sights!. Can get very busy but well worth a visit. Stunning shops. Some very good resturants and not always as expensive as one would think.
Looks like Paris. Take a stroll along this lovely Eixample street. Wonderful Modernista architecture and beautiful flowers along the way. Note the Gaudi benches and lamp posts.

window shop. A beautiful wide street filled with lovely hi-end shops. Greats for breaking up the touring and sightseeing. Have lunch at one of the street lined cafe's and watch people go by. So close to all.Great to go during right before siesta time ( some stores close between 2-5:30)

Just Shopping. It is just a shopping street where you will find those big brands like Bottega, Chanel, Loewe and LV etc. Prada was closed not sure if it was under renovation or closed for good. Personally I prefer Madrid for shopping as there was more shops as compared to Barcelona

Good shopping. If whike in Barcelona you feel the urge to go shopping, you'll find what you need in one of the shops lining Passeig de Gracia. Even if not ionterested in shopping, just strolling in Passeig de Gracia is an experience not to be missed.
Shoppers delight!. If you love to shop, this is the place for you... So many spanish brands to choose from. (Ie: Loewe, Adolfo Dominguez, Desigual, Custo Bacelona, Carolina Herrera)

To the heart of the city from Diagonal. Very big avenue full of Gaudi buildings (so keep your head up high), cafes and restaurants, boutiques. One of the main streets in the city and you should definitely take a walk over it.
Favorite!. One of the most amazing walks you can ever take. Fashionable, trendy and full of things, stores and people to see.
Luxury. A safe and lovely part of the charming city, where you can leave your family do the shopping all day, and they can't get lost.

Clear plenty of space on your camera. Very walkable. Beautiful architecture everywhere. I took many, many pictures. The Gaudi/Casa Batlo is in this neighborhood. Schedule at least 2 hours to see it; more if the line is long. Many good places to eat. Bring plenty of money though.

Looks and feels like Park Avenue or 5th. A beautiful avenue filled with all the best high end boutiques. It is easy to picture the Spanish Bougeoisie promenading at the turn of the century. If you are looking for an upscale retail fix this is your spot, and the Gaudi exteriors along the way are an added bonus..

Enjoyed the night life. Walked around the area several evenings. Wonderful architecture especially at every crossroad. Colourful fountains. Lots to do. Eat, browse stores. Full of people enjoying themselves. Less crowded than Las Ramblas. The best of outdoor Barcelona at night.
A beautiful place. Fountains Avenue, with shops and restaurants and cafes - a chic place to relax and pedestrian travel. For convenience, there is a metro station and many bus stops.
Beautiful architectural walk. This is en route from la rambla to la sagrada familia. Full of cafés, shopping, and architectural marvels (many if which were built by gaudi himself)

Interesting old neighborhoods.. If you can, staying in this convenient area affords pleasant dining, great atmosphere, lots of intimate lodging, stops for cava or a caffe, and exploration to many nooks and crannies, as well as access to the major sights.

Fine Tree Lined Avenue Of Modernista Buildings. Great place for a stroll. Many of the best buildings of a century ago and tourist sights to see line this road. There's a main multilane highway down the middle, then rows of trees either side, with side access roads for the buildings. The street lamps are also in a very distinctive "modernista" style to complement thebuildings. This is Barcelona's Champs Elysee cum Fifth Avenuewith shops typical for the area. There are many cafes andrestaurants if you want to take a break.

Browse and Stroll. We stayed in Barcelona for three days prior to a cruise and definitely plan to return for a much longer stay. This boulevard is very convenient to other attractions and has numerous restaurants, bars, boutiques and department stores. We loved taking our time exploring the area and drinking reasonably priced sangria and eating inexpensive tapas.

Great shopping district!. Best of the high street and high end retail stores. Also some great restaurants and bars. I used a city guide to help me around Barcelona but if you haven't got time to do some advance reading, start with Passeig de Gracia, you won't be disappointed!

Nice Walking and eating. I Stayed in this area for 2 nights after a cruise and It was a great location and very convenient. Very close to the subway and to La Ramblas. I loved the Gaudi's architecture in this neighborhood and felt very safe.

Art in Midst of Shopping ... .... Stayed in the area for 3 nights.It was great and convenient.Very near to La Ramblas. Amazing Gaudi's architecture in midst of shopping street.Luxury brands are mostly found in this area. But range is very limited.
Nice walking and eating places.. We walked and shopped and eat and drank. So fun! We toured Gaudi's La Pedrera was amazing. Great views and well worth the money.
Great area. We stayed 2 nights in a quaint B & B we found on airbnb. Lots of restaurants and shops nearby. Easy to get around and not too loud, like Ramblas. I would stay in that area again.
Long and interesting street. lots of lovely shops and interesting buildings along here. Had a lovely time walking along here with all the stalls selling books and other things

really nice chic street. With the gaudi batlo and pedreira buildings - besides many other beautiful ones. Fancy shopping also available. Supposedly the most expensive street in barcelona. nice to walk at.

A beautiful and trendy boulevard. This street is filled with beautiful buildings and outdoor cafes as well as upscale boutiques. Several of Gaudi's famous apartment buildings are on the Passeig fe Gracia so it is also full of tourists taking pictures and waiting in line to go inside.
Impressive street with lots of the impressive architecture. Lots of snazzy shops and ornate buildings along, also great transport links on the street for the train to the airport and metro.
iMPRESSIVE!. Here you can see Gaudi's work, as well as the pavement blocks. Busy street and very interesting. Better to have a guided tour.
window shopping only for us. Lots of high end shops that were beyond what I could afford but nice to window shop and dream. Gets very busy in the evenings.

Just a big shopping street. It's a big, wide avenue with lots of traffic, lined with high-end stores. Of course, it's also where you can find two of Gaudi's major buildings, and is also a direct way to get to the neighbourhood of Gracia. If you're into high-end fashion, you'll love it.
great for shopping. fab place if you want o go shopping or have food or just a coffee, well worth walking to from the Ramblas.
Like the Champs Elysee in Paris. Beautiful boulevard. Beautiful shops, great people watching. Trees, architecture to die for, outdoor restaurants, just walk it and all it's magic will unfold.
Gaudi and high end shopping. pleasant street to walk down after visiting plaza de catalunya. many shops and beautiful Gaudi architecture

Chic and enjoyable. We actually stayed not far from here, and so walked up and down this area quite a bit during our stay. It is filled with mostly high-end designer stores such as Cartier, Tiffanys, 5 star hotels and places that specialise in gentlemens tailoring. Nonetheless, it is a fun place to stroll around and enjoy, even if you're not in the market for a Tiffany bracelet :) There are lovely fountains and cafes lining the streets, and about midway through is "Gaudi's House", which is beautiful from the outside, even if you're not going in for a tour or concert. Worth a stroll.
Barcelona's 5th avenue. Great place for shopping or people watching. Make sure to at least stop by Gaudi's buidlings on the walk.

lovely buildings. If you take a peek inside some of the buildings, you'll be rewarded with some Moderniste work in glass, beautifully decorarated halls and old elevators. From the outside you also get to see some great buildings, the most famous of which are La Pedrera and Casa Batlló by Gaudi (the building on the left of Casa Batlló is also quite beautiful). For those who like couture, you'll find Carolina Herrera, Escada and shops of that sort along Passeig de Gràcia.

Nice place to walk and shop. I prefer this over la ramble because it's a nice atmosphere and good place to shop, and it is much classier than la ramble, there are no people trying to convince you to buy souvenirs from them; also the gaudi style buildings (including case battle!!) along the street make it a beautiful place to walk. there is also a nice park for children to play in
Champs Elysee of Barcelona. Going for the branded clothing...this is your street! ... and you have some nice Gaudi architecture buildings along...
Gothic Architecture and Luxury shops. As the subject line says, this road leads to the gothic quarter and has great architecture and luxury shops. Nice for a stroll in the evening.

Something for Everyone. What's not to love on the Passeig de Garcia. It has the right mix of shopping, cafe's, restaurants, art, history, and architecture to mention a few. Yes, there are several high end shops, but a great mix of other more affordable shops. Restaurants tend to be a little more on the pricy side should you like to the privilege to people watch outside. We felt comfortable walking day or night, never felt unsafe. Make a point to at least go once.TIP - Everything and I do mean everything (shops) is closed on Sunday's. Plan accordingly.
The Fifth Avenue of Barcelona.. A beautiful wide boulevard with every imaginable shop and lined with sidewalk cafes and bars perfect for people watching.

Impossible to avoid!. Whenever in Barcelona, Passeig de Gracia to me is a MUST DO! Strolling around the lovely avenue, it's beautiful and mostly upperend shops, one cannot come to this charming city and ignore passingby once more! Though I read in one review that it is not very "Spanish",it would surely depend on what one would consider being Spanish. ModernistSpain, is definitely a big part of coming to Barcelona, so to me it is very Spanish.The architecture, not only of this specific avenue, but all of the zone, is amazingand it's like walking through an architecture museum, just walking around blocksand blocks of amazing constructions. All are different and full of detail, especially onthe façades and hallway entrances. A huge JOY to delight in! By all means, spectacular!

truly graceful!. a haven for shoppers and fashion enthusiast... and a heaven for those who appreciate Spanish modernism - where you could, for example, view the Pedrera and Casa Battlo almost at the same time..watch out for those stylish tiles of the street..especially when it rains!postcard perfect!
Best pedestrian street in Barcelona. Absolutely charming street with bustling cafes, bars and stylish crowd. High end shopping and a tremendous amount of people watching.

Expensive, but worth a stroll. This is one of the premier shopping streets of Barcelona and all the big names are there. I enjoyed it as an architecture walk as the buildings are so fabulous. Garudi's Casa Batilla and Casa Mila are within four blocks of each other on this street.
Nice area. We went through this area with our rented Go Car and then returned on foot to see the individual buildings. I liked the architecture and the atmosphere.
just Beautiful!. Every corner promises a new discovery and photo opportunity. Make sure you walk the length and take your camera.
Nice stores. Very good promenade in the heart of Barcelona. If you like fancy stores there is the place to be. Also, all the famous Gaudi houses are there. really nice.

Good Place to Stroll and Look. We were there on a Sunday, and I was impressed that all the stores were closed. It didn't matter. The designer stores would have been highly priced anyway. We still enjoyed the walk--between the architecture and the window displays, it's worth going there just to look. Everywhere I walked in the area, I was amazed at the architecture and the way the buildings are well preserved and cared-for. Don't miss Gaudi's Casa de Pedreras, but there are many other sights to see as well.

Passeig de Gracia is colourful and amazing and it has the most prestigious boutiques. Among all the shopping attractions el Passeig counts with, one of the most interesting is the wonderful La Pedrera, built by Gaudi. From my perspective is one of the purest buildings of the famous architect which in addition has a nice terrace for breakfast or drinks at reasonable prices.

Loved it. This is not only a fab shopping area, with the most amazing buildings but an amazing place to spend the eveningLots f lovely restaurants and right in the heart of everything with easy transport linksGreat place to people watch

Shops, restaurants and some Gaudi stuff. The Gaudi is good (great, even), the shops are expensive (Tiffany's, Vuitton - you get the idea) and the restaurants are alright. Never got food poisoning once and felt lighter afterwards thanks to so much being taken out of my wallet ;)
Good shopping street. Lots of high street fashion shops such as .Zara, H&M and - especially - the Spanish chain store Bershka with very cheap and fashionable clothes for Young people

Designer Shops Galore!. If you're looking for Hermes, Chanel, Gucci, YSL, etc...or less expensive shops like Benetton, Zara, Mango and H&M, Pg de Gracia is the street for you.Our apartment rental was on this street (Apartment 64) and we felt the location was ideal for our city break. Most tourist sites were easily accessible on foot in less than 20 mins away, as well as markets, restaurants and loads of shopping!
Nice street. Take a couple of hours to do this street. Designer shops, restaurants you have it all. You buy good stuff in this very long street.
European Charm. We loved this are of the city - it oozed European charm and character. Just walking and taking it all in was our favorite part of the trip!

Ok place to visit in Barcelona. If you like shopping, this is the place for you, but you need to be ready to walk a bit to go through the whole street back and forth. Should be a good place to visit during your trip to Barcelona.

Street of Dreams. The Tour de France comes through this route (I was there for the Tour in 2009 - it came and went in a flash!) and near Placa Catalunya is the fabulous Navarra Tapas Bar. Over 50 choices and it is hard to limit yourself to only a few. Casa Mila is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site "Works of Antoni Gaudí". and an excellent representation of his architecture (also Parc Guell and La Sagrada Familia.)

wonderful mix of architecture. Nice place for a walk and enjoy buildings of different design but armonized in a good way, respecting trees.there you can find good restaurants, shops and everything you need
Shopping area.... a lots of designers' labels located, with many many travelers.... you may find out most of popular brands in there as well as the restrautants....
Street of brands. this street is full of excelent brand shops, you can buy everithing there, you also can find the best bank BBVA branch there

Great shopping in Barcelona. It's not the same as Madison or 5th Aves in NYC but for shoppers it's a food afternoon's worth of window shopping. Not to miss is Loewe. If you're in need of shoes or a new bag and don't want to be just another person inLouis Vuitton then this is the place to shop - although don't get me wrong - the Louis Buitton store was very nice.

ancient lanes - great walkthrough. This area of Barcelona, makes you feel great, you walkthrough all the areas in passage de Gracia and see different different buildings. you should spend time in daytime or even evenings and a nice lovely stroll. Please carry a umbrella there may be a slight drizzle.

A busy walk. Worth a walk to see some of the buildings and landmarks you pass. Beware of the pickpockets, with all the crowds they love to work here. One of the thoroughfares to many attractions, but personally not much of an attraction itself. But one of the things everyone mentions about Barcelona, so why not combine it with a visit nearby.

Interior Design Fans. Amongst the many attractions of the Passeig de Gracia you should absolutely set aside time to visit the Vincon store. Its legend "Crazy Since 1941" barely does justice to this fab shop full of products from high end and classy, through quirky to downright off the wall. All wrapped around a really unique and friendly atmosphere. Whether your interiors taste is Harvey Nics, Heals or Ikea you'll love a stroll around here. No pressure to buy from friendly and glamorous staff but you'll definitely be tempted. Don't miss going out into the open space which backs onto the Gaudi designed building next door. Happily I'd spend all day here. Open 10:00 to 14:00 and 16:30 to 20:30.

Commercial artery of Barcelona.. Beautiful architecture abounds. It's Gaudi's backyard. Major shopping artery of Barcelona. From Cartier to Mango, they are all here. Even Stella McCartney has a shop there. So are many fancy hotels. Lots of tapas bars and much less crowded than La Rambla. Nice area to take a stroll before of after dinner.
Must see. Passeig de Gracia is pretty much like Via dei Condotti in Rome or Via Montenapoleone in Milan. It's a must see area also because Casa Batllo is there.

Good atmosphere. Good atmosphere and there were a lot of shops for us to visit. The people there were very helpful and most of them helped us find our way back to our hotel on our first day of arrival.

the barcelona champs elysees. a nice clean and uncrowded shopping street that runs north of the mobbed ramblas. a lot of very nice stores and a starbucks at the end if you need a place to relax. this is the place to go to if you need a break from the crowds.

Paris like boulevard with shops and plazas.. The architecture in this area is amazing. Modern, many small balconies on the buildings. Barcelona is modern, well laid out city with plenty to do and a vibrant night life.

Gaudi Way .... Around the corner from out hotel ... The Fifth Avenue of Barcelona with better architecture and Gaudi's works. Fun and easy to stroll with many places to stop and drink or eat as little or as much as you want.

Lovely shopping and restaurant area.. Some of the nicer restaurants are found here.
Shops are great to walk around but some are a little over priced so be careful.
Check out Viacon the first floor is amazing everything is displayed in an apartment style so you get to see what fabulous architecture looks behind all the facade.
Walk of brands. The street is packed with places to visit, shop and eat. A must do while in Barcelona. It is centrally located and is accessible via all sorts of public transportation.

Shoppeeeee. A line of IB(International Brands) and the back bone of Barcelona
u can find Casa Batlo and Casa Milla on this road.
Nice shops, beautifill Modernista houses for Gaudi and others. Nice street to walk on. Saw the beautifull houses such as Casa Battlo on the outside. Visited Casa Mila on the inside. Don't miss it.

A nice stroll down a beautiful street. Wonderful way to spend an afternoon. Many shops and restaurants to visit. Sit on a terrace and have a coffee (espresso) or lunch. The sidewalks are large and easy to walk even at busy times. The architecture is fascinating to look at even if it isn't your "thing".

Take a stroll. People. stores and restaurants. Lovely architecture and fine shops. However, the stores you find here are not unique, only expensive. Designer shops you could find in any large cosmopolitan city. Restaurants cater to tourists. Better to go off the main street to find local little places to eat.

A walk on Passeig de Gracia is an absolute must.. If one street had to be named the 'main' street of Barcelona, this would be it or may the one leading to Placa Espanya. Why I say its a must to take a stroll here:1. You see so many state of art buildings on both sides of the street.2. Its like a walk in Paradise for Shopaholics. :) There are high street brands' outlets on this street.3. Casa Batllo and Casa Mila are this street. So, if you cannot fit in the trip to the mentioned houses don't be sad, just take a walk on Passeig de Gracia, you will not only be able to see both the 'UNESCO World Heritage' buildings but also so many other beautiful and stunning buildings, like the one adjacent to Casa Batllo.4. There are numerous and fantastic looking cafes on this street. They are little pricey though.5. Its so lively, I though it was so much better than Ramblas.One suggestion:1. Casa Batllo and Casa Mila are just 500m apart, so if you have reached one and are feeling too tired after all the walking, please don't chicken out, just walk a little more.2. If you have a provision of being dropped by cab/Tourist bus somewhere on the street, choose to be dropped either at Casa Batllo or at Casa Mila. That way you will need to walk a little less.3. We chose to go there late in the afternoon, around 1:30, we spent almost 5 hours in Casa Mila and Casa Batllo. We were completely exhausted, so headed for the beach to relax. You could do that too. There is a Metro station a few meters from Casa Mila, you could take Metro to the beach, you will need to change Metro once.

Lively. The main street is very lively whether you are there during the day or in the middle of the night. Restaurants are open really late as the standard dinner time is much later than other countries (locals eat dinner at around 10:00).

The Champs Ellysees of Spain. Like any European city. There is a main road where all the high fashion stores are situated. In Barcelona,this is Passeig de Gracia.It's great! It's viby!But expensive!Avoid eating in the restaurants on the road.They are extremely expensive and charge a premium of 20% for sitting outside. Casa Batlo and Casa Milla are situated on this road.

All the famous and luxury stores. This is the luxury mile of Barcelona. Here you can find all the famous chains with their flagship stores. Worth to take a stroll and walk along, feel the atmosphere. Here also the Casa Mila, the famous house with Gaudi design is located. Also a number of smaller (and because of the good location more expensive) restaurants and Tapas Bars are located here.

good walk down-hill. forget the bus tours, start from Fontana metro station on Gran de Gracia and keep walking down hill all the way to Passeig de Gracia and enjoy the buildings or the shops if that's what you are looking for.

Designer Shop Heaven. The road itself is a few miles in length heading towards the Gracia area of Barcelona. But the central stretch from Catalunya Square for about a mile is lined with beautiful buildings, hotels restuarants and shops.

Great shopping. The fifth avenue of Barcelona -- lots of high end designer boutiques and restaurants line this world-renowned avenue. A block off on Rambla de Catalunya was our favorite restaurant we dined at on the trip, Ceveceria Condal.

Class. Take some time out to stroll at you leisure, down this elegant avenue. There is wonderful Architecture to look at, High Street Designer shops (hang on to your wallets, gents). There are some nice places to sit for a drink, and something to eat. Monchos is very good.

Shopping & Dinning at Barcelona. If you are wondering where are all the popular or high-end brands, this is the place. A very central road to walk with numerous shops and pretty nice restaurants to eat. Along the road, you will find Gaudi's famous architectural constructions Casa Batlo and La Pedrera plus the A.Tapies Foundation. Walking towards south, you will find Placa Catalunya and little further is the old town with the cathedral, palace of music, la rambla and much more...

My most beloved avenue. The fifteenth time I saw Passeig de Gracia was several months ago when I had a 30kg luggage and a few hours between planes. Even if I had already seen it another fourteen times, I just could not prevent myself from strolling around admiring Gaudi's casa Mila and Batllo, Puig y Cadafalch's Casa Amatller and Muntaner's Casa Lleo Morera. Delightful!
Very posh quarter. Very posh quarter, Classy, some high end shops, and just a nice place to stroll around, quiet yet not so much affordable place to grab something to eat...

Designers all the way. I stayed on this main thoroughfare but was not overly impressed by what was on offer. This is a road of designer shops and restaurants and if that is your thing, you will be in heaven. The only attraction for me was the accessibility to Casa Battlo and the Pedrera, otherwise there is not much to get up to in this area for families.

A street with high end shops. Would say that anyone who visits Barcelona will most probably end up on this street at some point during the trip. High end shops and over priced restaurants with normal tourist type foods. Worth a stroll down, day or night and some of the shops worth a wonder in to with a nice little boutique market half way down the street.... At the end of the day it's a street with shops on it, high end shops....
The street of fashion. This is the street to be seenHere one can find all of the designer shops and upscale restaurants.It's busy day and night and is great for people watching
Great shopping. So many stores to go to, everyone who enjoys shopping will have a blast there. There are also a lot of restaurants where you can take a break and rest your feet.
MONEY! MONEY! MONEY!. If you have the money and like the finer things in life, well this is the street for you! Also a great street for browsing! Cartier, Chanel, Gucci...

Great Shopping. Rivals Rome and Paris in terms of designer shops. Easily accessible from anywhere in Barcelona either by metro or taxi.Whether shopping or window shopping all European and a few Catalan designers can be found here.

Station. Not sure if this is an attraction or not because it's where you get off the airport train, if your hotel is CBD. Make sure you work out exactly where to get back on the underground, because you'll be coming out to street level and you'll have to locate the entrance to the train one. It's all underground.
Shopping!. A higher quality of shops than on Las Ramblas. Great architecture. Easy to reach from Las Ramblas or the Metro.

Shops!. Depending what end you start at - I started at the top and worked my way down towards the sea. Starts with small cheap independent shops and graduates to more mid price well known shops, Mango, Zara and H&M for example. You then come across the high end stores like Gucci. Mid priced places dotted between the high end ones. Lovely to stroll down and do some shopping (and window shopping in the designer places!). Plenty of benches to rest on and places to eat / drink.

Most beautiful street in Barcelona. In a spending mood??Paseo de Gracia makes you feel good!!Hermes, Louis Vuitton, D&G, Armani, McGregor, etc etcThey are all there to make your credit card smoke :-))
Worth a stroll. Beautiful architecture, especially the "Block of Discord" including Gaudi's Casa Batilo. (Casa Mila is also on this street). Great place to stroll and have a glass of sangria.
One of the main streets/faces of Barca. Walked every day along that street and every day we found something new and interesting to explore. There are several famous sightseeings-works of Gaudi.

Stunned. My wife planned the whole trip and I did not do the usual reading ahead. From my ignorant perspective, I thought that Goudi was a famous guy who died maybe 5 or ten years ago. On the night time tour (highly recommended), the guide mentions that Goudi was working on this "at the turn of the century"....1900 not 2000. What a visionary! It was great.
Shopping, people watching, sites. This is the place you want to be, for forget about Las Ramblas. All the high end stores you want and Gaudi designs are on this street.

The it place. This is a nice boulevard with great shops and restaurants. I enjoyed walking up and down, eating out and shopping at Passeig de Gracia. I also liked how clean it was considering that so many people pass by every day.
Don't waste your time.... ... unless the reason you went to barcelona is to see luxury shop such as Cartier or Ferrari... This is typical the kind of place I don't want to go to when I travel abroad.

Great place for shopping. Very nice place to shop. All brands are there from Chanel to Burberry, Gucci, Yves Saint Laurent, Michael Kors... You can find it all here; in addition to shops like Zara, Mango, Desigual... You can spend the whole day there, time passes so quickly for shopping lovers

classy street. Great for trendy shops, cafes and bars. Shop from basic Zara to extravagant Channel and Cartier! Nice place to people watch.
Lovely buildings- try exploring some of the side streets off Passeig de Gracia to get a real feel of Barca

Same like everywhere. We did not like it so much, this "Paseo" is not caracterisic for Barcelona although it has some of the most impressive buildings there. But we like more the Rambla and the small Street of Barcelona.

Very nice central street with amazing buildings. This street was very central for us because we used the metro stop almost every day. It is amazing to come out of the metro in the evening and see the the houses lit up.
The buildings along this street are not to be missed both in the day time and in the evening.

the metro stop near our hotel. Not only did we take the metro from this location, but the Gaudi house and others were great fun to admire. We ate at an outdoor restaurant on this street. Tenorio...it was fine for paella and the free cava. But it was the spot to sit outside that made it special.

So much to see!. A must to visit ...so many shops to visit and wonderful architecture. Extremely busy when we went and with five of us all wanting to see different things - we were there a while. Expect to have very sore feet... but well worth it!

Keep your credit card home. No, seriously, there are so many shops and boutiques in this street, that if you travel with your wife, you are in a serious trouble. So is your credit card. Be careful guys, this shopping avenue can empty anyone's pockets:)
Lovely!. Very nice neighborhood to walk, explore, eat and specially SHOP! Expect to be exhausted if you're visiting with heavy shoppers !
Gaudi's world. An excellent walk to see the work of Gaudi and the other Moderna architects (Block of Discord). Down a little farther is great shopping and the Cathedral.
All about the Gaudi. I'd avoid this as often too packed with us tourists, though of course Casa Batllo is on it and that is awlays worth seeing

Upmarket Barcelona. This area is busy like all of the other areas in the tourist precinct, but has a nice atmosphere. For people who can afford the high end brands, you will be in shopping heaven. There are lots of interesting places to eat along the way, and a couple of Gaudi's works are found here. Easily reached by metro.

All the best shops. The hop on hop off bus takes you here and if your after a nice meal or all the top brand shops this is the place for you. Quite touristy and not cheap but lovely street with some amazing Guadi buildings you have to see if in Barcelona.

Great Place to stay. I love this area and would always recommend staying here. It has all the boutique and designer stores around, lovely cafes and places to eat. You can walk to La rambles (if your fairly fit and young) and if you really want to push the boat you could even walk to the beach. There is pleant of public transport to take you around and easy to get to Port Olympic - where all the bars n clubs are!

Great for shopping. Very nice place to shop. All brands are there from Chanel to Burberry, Gucci, Yves Saint Laurent, Michael Kors... You can find it all here; in addition to shops like Zara, Mango, Desigual... You can spend the whole day there, time passes so quickly for shopping lovers

Shops!. Good if you are interested in shopping and hitting higher end labels. Shops vary from NIke, Zara, Mango, Apple, to the posher, more designer labels like Chanel, Gucci etc. Good to see for tourism and for shopping but in hot summer can be pretty crowded
Shopping paradise.... This street is absolutely beautiful, the architecture, the spirit, everything! Loved walking and shopping there))

Just walk along !. To experience the city , take a walk down this road starting from Plaza Catalunya on a nice summer afternoon. You can also travel in a bus sitting on the rear higher side to get a different perspective of the street. Lots of places to shop from and good cafes lined up to enjoy a break. A good way to feel the pulse of the city and experience it's grandeur in its entirety.

nice area :). When we visited Barcelona we stayed close to this area. It is very central, with a lot of shops where you can enjoy shopping. It has a lot to see and it is always moving, you will enjoy walking around. It has also Gaudi buildings which you can enjoy :) Enjoy it :)

Brilliant shopping. Upmarket shopping area, really fantastic if you like Chanel, Gucci etc don't overlook the shopping arcade on the left halfway up just past Casa Batllo. some really great quirky little shops with some really funky clothes and jewellery. some great street front tapas stops to eat here too. i bought so much i had to buy an extra suitcase to get home. loved it!
lots to see. Great shops, plus if you like Gaudi & architecture, this is a wonderful road. Metro stop is disabled accessible

If you want a bit more upscale than La Rambla area shopping...... Nice afternoon shopping away from the craziness of La Rambla, Parte viejo, and other crowded tourist spots. Dont get me wrong, there were plenty of tourists, but a much calmer atmosphere. Though many of the stores were the same as back home in USA (chanel, burberry, sephora), I still found many unique stores that I havent seen in the states. Found some nice things, decent quality (from what I can tell) at good prices. Morgan is a clothing store with cool stuff. Sales woman was very helpful and patient with my broken Spanish. Tascon for shoes. And I've never seen a Zara so big. Many of these shops are on perpendicular blocks to P de Gracia, or on P Catalunya. Was a nice walk in neighborhood afterwards for dinner. Very safe at night (or so it appeared to me).

Rather boring shopping street. Rather boring shopping street, but shopping fancy stores isn't really me...
-There are a few Gauidi houses there, and "modernisma" facades, see them and get to Raval :-)

if you can buy whats in there. its good to enter the expensive store in this street just to look to find the best peace of clothes to buy if you have the money and check the prices real quick and then here she come , on of the sale staff trying to see if she can help you and then your are on your ownthere are a couple of Gaudis houses in the street you can look at , it will take you 2-3 hours to see everything on this street

great shopping. Like everything about this fashion street. Amazing shops and tapas. A must when in Barcelona. Gucci, Louis Vitton, Chanel...and a range of coffee shops and tapas bars. And the street is so wide and airy so a pleasure to walk around
Fun walk to see architecture. Gorgeous architecture, Gaudi at his best. Amazing stores, cafes and people watching. Find a nice outdoor café and see the world pass by.

HIGH RENT SHOPPING DISTRICT. Beautiful street lined with designer stores is great for window shopping and checking out the latest fashions. Take a break in one of the pretty sidewalk cafes and great tapas bars. It makes for a nice afternoon.
Best Shopping Avenue!. Best Boutiques of International Designers and Cafes... You can spend your whole day walking without noticing!!

great shopping & Gaudi architecture. A staple of Barcelona with something for everyone, with Catalunya Plaza at the bottom, stunning and interesting Gaudi buildings, and the best shopping with a big range to satisfy everyone's budget.

Gracious Passeig de Gracia. What is there not to like about Passeig de Gracia? From the Plaza Catalunya to the Diagonal, outstanding shopping on both sides of the avenue, amazing restaurants, and art nouveau buildings to satisfy the most discriminating Gaudi fan. My favorite stores are, of course, ZARA, Massimo Dutti, Adolfo Dominguez, Tous...all made in Spain and great buys not to mention exquisite design.

The 5th Avenue of Barcelona. If you like upscale shopping and a nice urban atmosphere, Passeig de Gracia is for you. Our hotel overlooked the street and just a block from Casa Batllo, the Gaudi creation that makes a fun afternoon visit too. La Pedrera is also there. Plus, if you're on Passeig de Gracia you have excellent access to public transportation and a cool walk to Segrada Familia.

My favourite street in BCN. Whenever I travel to Barcelona, I love to walk on this street. For me, it is like 5th Avenue or KIngs Road. It is wide, has some trees, some restaurants & bars and some of the best Spanish & international clothes shops. And La Pedrera ... brilliant!
Nice for window shopping. Great place to window shop, and also people watch. It was close to our b&b so were on it a few times. You can always notice something new each time.

Fashion for everyone!. Passeig de Gracia is the place to walk and shop, many luxury labels.It is home to some of Gaudi’s masterpieces (La Pedrera and Casa Batlló) Dont miss the ceramic benches and the amazing wrought-iron lamp-posts. i love the shopping!!

Barcelona's Rodeo Drive. High-end shops...everywhere. You can buy pretty much anything there. And one of the Gaudi houses is there. Numerous restaurants too. Everything from gourmet to tapas to fast food. We stayed at an apartment there for three days after our cruise and didn't see half of it.
Nicest area of Barcelona.

Shopping and people watching. Great place to grab a seat and have a drink whilst watching the beautiful people going past!
Also the shopping area of the city and you can pick up fanrastic bargains.

A sublime experience. If you are into shopping, this is the place for you. A seemingly unending stream of wonderful shops, with lots of bars and cafe's to rest for a while... A great place to also sit and watch e world go by.

Best shopping in Barcelona. We shopped here on Saturday afternoon until the evening and the store are excellent and for all budgets and for all ages. You find the flagship stores for many brands and the fashion is top. The avenue Passeig de Gracia is elegant and you can watch the people pass by when sitting in a café. The Gaudi houses are also here which makes it very special.

Barcelona's Champs Elysee. Passeig de Gracia is like the Champs Elysee of Paris with plenty of shops and restaurants. It was a lovely stroll down from Casa Batllo, going into whichever shop that caught our eyes and resting in a nice cafe or restaurant when we needed it.

High street shopping. For those who prefer to shop at the common high street shops then this would be your thing. However for those who want something different and more "local" then a visit to the el born and la riberia area would be more worth your while

A tourist walkway. You must and would not miss this as you will be passing by this walking area and go to the Gaudi's Casa Ballto. We were in Barcelona from 21.06.13 on our first day. When we arrived and got transit from renfe to this metro stop via the airport, most of the guide book said we could get off to this metro station and our hotel was at the next metro stop by changing to L4. However, we found we had to pass through a long underground pavement and it seemed under constructions. We felt hot and bit frustrated as we had carried big luggage. Thus, we looked for the other way at our return journey and found we went to Barcelona Sants was much convenience, especially when we carried a lot of things back. Although few more stop of metro, but the transit and up and down the metro saved us a lot of time and energy, you could also take Barcelona Sants rather than Passeig de Gracia as we did not know how long the constructions would be finished and you can get rid of the long underground pavement.

chain stores, nice stroll. some boutiques but mostly chain stores. our hotel was situated centrally on this street and it is an easy walk to better shopping and strolling nearby on the parallel rambla de catalunya
vibrant. We stayed just off it, full of designer shops, cafés bars. Just walk up and down it a few times but make sure you look up as there are some wonderful buildings along its lengh.

a little touristy, but take a stroll. As others will tell you, of course, watch your pockets when you're in any crowd. Having said that, we never felt unsafe and though the horror stories may have been a bit overrated. We were two women traveling together, and we walked it at night and during the day. Both times were crowded (mid-March) but not unbearable. Just use normal caution and you'll be fine.

Can't miss the grand boulevard of Barcelona. Even if you're not in Barcelona for the shopping, you cannot miss window shopping in this region of the city. Also home to Gaudi's Casa Battlo and La pedreira (you should visit at least one of these!), his tiles and benches along the street - you really get a sense of the rebirth of the city from walking this stretch of the city.
Great street to visit. Opportunity to visit an up market street and shops. Do look above eye level and check out the architecture.

The heart of Barcelona. Well, Passeig de Gracia is a place you'll have to go through if you want to visit Las Ramblas, the iconic place in Barcelona.It's a great place to walk and you'll see a lot of beautiful constructions, some are historical, some are just brand new.We loved to be there, and it most certainly cannot be missed.

A taste of Barcelona. This elegant boulevard has magnificent examples of modernist architecture, some Gaudi jewels such as Casa Battlo and La Pedrera, and it is the perfect place to walk up and down and feel as elegant as the city!
No bikes. It is better to make it walking in order to see the shops of all new mode. Take. Meal in a good restaurant and enjoy a pleasant walk
GREAT SHOPS. As well as all the designer shops, not to be missed if you have a big wallet. You will find Gaudi buildings which are a must to visit. Lovely buildings all along the Passeig de Gracia.
Great shopping. This is a GREAT upscale avenue or shopping...especially after June 30th when the summer sales hit with a vengeance.

Not worth the crowds. Yes there is some fun architecture, but go one street over for a better and less expensive and less crowded shopping experience. Better yet head to el Born for the best most intimate shopping.
Passeig de Gracia. Excellent area to walk and explore. Came upon a Gaudi house while wondering around. Excellent cafes and restaurants to sit and people watch
Classy Boulevard. The Passeig de Gracia is a wide, tree-lined avenue with upscale shopping.It may not be a 'destination visit', but is well worth seeing just for the beauty of the locale.

Shopping? It's here. This is one of the most known avenues in Barcelona. You will have a nice walk there, for sure. Big avenue, with lots of stores and usually crowded. You will find a couple of iconic places from Barcelona here as well (like La Pedrera).
Shopping Galore. Nice road to stroll down with shops and shops and shops with a few eateries and coffee shops. Worth a few hours if you enjoy that kind of activity.
Favorite area in Barcelona. I love walking around this area. So chic, so beautiful, so cosmopolitan. So much nicer than the very touristy La Rambla.
Nice street. Nice street with lots of posh shops on it, definitely worth a walk down. And nice buildings again to look at.
Shoppers paradise. Incredible strolling boulevard filed with incredible shops, fine restaurants and incredible coffee shops. A wonderful place to explore and spend a sunny afternoon.
Mind the thiefs. Felt a little unsafe here - lots of beggars and street crime. Beautiful street but something needs to be done about the problem
Architectural is wonderful. Considering that two of Gaudi's homes are located here it is well worth the trip. The shops are all top designers and if you have money to spend this is the place for you!

Great place for a stroll.. Lovely wide street full of designer label shops and lovely old buildings. Tip...if you don't want to be tempted to spend money go on a Sunday as nearly all the shops are closed!!
Gracious boulevarde. Strolling along under the trees is a treat, looking at the designer shops, restaurants, and smart locals who parade along this lovely street.
Very pleasant boulevard. Good place to take a stroll, day or night. Much more relaxing than Ramblas. Lots of cafes, bars and designer shops, also some Gaudi architecture.

Much better than La Rambla. Though the prices were much higher here than La Rambla, I enjoyed it so much more. Crowds are thinner and well if there is a Gucci then you know pricing is higher.
Two Gaudi buildings, Sangria and Bellt are right there

Diverse inspirational architecture. Its lovely and amazing but really so crowdedFull of all sorts of inconsiderate pushing tourists Hope to go back and revisit!!! Well worth seeing but just ard to see properly
Fantabulous. An amazing street to go around shopping and have fun. A definite up-scale posh market place with good crowd unlike the ramblas.

Grand boulevard. It can be described as the Champs Elyses of Barcelona.
Grand boulevard with beautiful buildings and shopas
A nice walk. A nicely arranged avenue lined with visitors' attractions and branded shops. Good for shoping, especially for ladies ^^.
Beautiful Stroll. This is a lovely street to appreciate Barcelona's architecture and shop/window shop. It isn't such a long stretch, and is worth the walk!

Great for strolling, viewing and shopping. Passeig de Gracia is an incredibly long street that runs through the center of Barcelona. The architecture of the apartments along the street is superior. So many beautiful buildings! The shopping is very upscale and it is lined with many beautiful trees. The street lamps are something to see as well. The are influenced by Gaudi and exquisitely designed. Be sure to find your way to the Passeig de Gracia.

Impressive. Like the rest of Barcelona this strees is architecturally inspiring and a must see. The shops along here are fantastic, and a must for any high end shopper. The streests off this street and the rambla Catalonya (parallel ) are a more affordable option but equally as Michael shoppers haven. Shoppers and browsers will not be disappointed

Great walk and shopping. Our hotel, the Mandarin Oriental, is on this street. It is an easy way to get to other parts of the city. Also, there are fantastic shops along this street. Great fun just to stroll along and people watch!

What a beautiful street!. This street was very close to our hotel and we walked down it several times during our trip. Great shopping and beautiful building are just some of the highlights this area has to offer!
Gorgeous. I really enjoyed walking down this street elegant and quiet with plenty space for walking, with lots of luxury shops, cheerful and very clean. I hope to return here soon!
Fancy stores. I was more impressed by the 2 Gaudi buildings than the high end stores. Looks and feels somewhat like the Champs Elysses or 5th Ave.

SATURDAY SHOPPING!. Sooo busy on a Saturday but fortunately a very wide and long street, so manageable. The Spanish department store, El Cortez Ingles is so old-fashioned inside and crammed with stuff, there is no pleasure in trying to shop there. Leave it out unless you just have to.

Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue combined. This stretch of avenue in Barcelona ranks up there with the finest shopping destinations in the world. A casual stroll up and down the Passeig is a delight for either high end shopping or just people watching. Once you are finished here you can move over to the Ramblas for a parallel experience and smaller boutiques.
Great shopping possibilities!. This is the endless shopping street of Barcelona! You can find all the biggest brands, such as Louis Vuitton, Prada, Gucci...
