Beverly Hills & Milan in Spain. If you are ready to spend some cash, while viewing some of the most marvelous buildings in Barcelona, the Passeig of Gracia is for you. All the high couture stores are there, but so are the beautiful buildings by Gaudi. There are many cafes to sit and relax, while enjoying a refreshing beverage

Loved Barcelona and the Passeig de Gracia!. Beautiful area - great shops and restaurants. Very convenient to The Renaissance hotel and a wonderful walk from there down to Las Ramblas - Loved Barcelona!

Forget Las Ramblas!. I spent hours walking this vibrant beautiful street. With its amazing buildings, great shops, restaurants and buzzing ambiance, my entire holiday could have been spent on this street. Dont forget La Pedrara and Caso Batllo, just quietly existing and impressing along tourists and residents :)

Perfect for shopping. Very nice street, with high end stores, but also a ZARA, Mango, HM etc. Also there are 2 Gaudi building, we didnt have a chance to go in as the line was too big. But it looked nice from the outside.

a great street, with sophisticated shops and choice of chain restaurants and even some Gaudi to look at!. Walk down here to get to Pl Catalunya and the start of La Rambla. Lots of Zara and Mango stores! Feels non-touristy and upmarket.
Want to go back again. Fantastic shops, clean and I would go back! There was a great variety of this shops ranging from local Spanish shops to international chains.
The Place to stay. My wife and I enjoyed staying near this famous street. We enjoyed the food, music, and the people. The only other city streets that compare to this one is Paris

A nice walk. Strolling up and down the Passeig de Gracia is a nice thing to do. Best if you start from the Plaza Catalunya (north end of La Rambla) and then walk one side up...and the other one down.Of course, other major cities have similar avenues, but it's still an interesting thing to do...even it doesn't beat 5th Ave or the Broadway.You'll pass the usual major fashion and clothing stores, lots of shops and of course many cafés and Tapas Bars. Many places also have outside tables, to watch the world go by. Unluckily we caught a grey, cold and rainy day.Besides that, there's also a lot nice architecture to look at, like Casa Amatller and Casa Batlló. It's a good stroll to do and something for everybody. Of course we would have enjoyed it even more on a sunny day.Wanna know more about my trips? Check my profile (where you'll also find my website).

Fabulous stroll. I love this street. The architecture , the shops, the beautiful fountains and shady trees make this such a pleasant walk. Why not start in Gracia neighborhood first and walk down Its designer heaven and a peaceful walk. Relax take it all in an sop have a cafe and pastry. Enjoy
Shopping!. Good for shopping if you like high end products or designers. Also you will find Casa Mila and Casa Batillo along the road! Whatever you go for you will enjoy it rain or shine!

Barcelona's answer to NY's Fifth Avenue and then some. A stroll down this avenue is a must for any visitor to Barcelona --- the varieties of architecture leave one far more impressed than at least this visitor could have anticipated.
Beautiful. We walked from the La Padrera house to the Plaza Catalunia. Stunning Architecure, first class elegant shops and a lot of pepole. Even the street lamps are uniqe. Don't miss it.

a lot of high street fashion and local boutiques. A nice street to take a walk, shop and people watch. The streets are paved with Gaudi's hexagon tiles. The smaller streets around Gracia hold some of the best boutiques and restaurants!

Enjoy the architecture. So I ignored the fact that I couldn't buy anything from most of the shops but I enjoyed the walking down to Placa de Catalunya. You have Gaudi's houses and much more, well worth absorbing the history, art and general openness of the area. There's more light and air, then the crowded narrow streets off Las Rambalas.

skip the ramblas. Passeig de Gracia is an elegant and fashionable street with loads of very high end stores as well as trendy affordable ones. Gaudi building is only one of dozens of fabulous architectual building next to one another, next to one another, all the way up and down the long street.

Most Fashionable street in Barcelona. Iff the plaza Catalunya it's lined with high end shops selling luxury brands and some stunning examples of Gaudi's architecture. Some linear bars and coffee shops to take a break. If you are not up for walking drive down the busy street.
Champs-Élysées of Barcelona!. Beautiful shopping street, although it’s quite expensive. You can find brand names, specialty shops and of course – Zara!
Our first hotel was in this area- very luxe. Great shopping , from Hermes to Zara--not as carzy-touristy as the centtal La Rambla area, but within waling distance. I'd stay in the area agaiin
The Rodeo Drive of Barcelona. This is a feast for the eyes, with prime examples of all of Barcelona's top Modernista architects represents\d, as well as all of the most well known designer shops.
busy,busy. Two of Gaudi's masterpieces are located there. Also shopping, and wonderful outdoor cafes. It's a beautiful avenue with old and new combined..

The most elegant street in Spain. We enjoyed a warm sunny day just strolling up and down this street. The shops range from Chanel and Loewe to interesting small boutiques. There are some seriously good restaurants along the way as well.
Saw it in passing. We did a lot of walking in Barcelona and we passed this several times but it just didn't grab us or arrest our attention very much. Nice architecture on the outside.

Beautiful for walking and shopping.. Loved Gracia for the top notch shopping (even if just window shopping), taking in some architecture, Gaudi sites, Turista bus starting point, and even a Starbucks if you should want a Barcelona mug and a cookie.

Gaudi Central. If you come here to see the works of Gaudi, as we did, there is no better location. We are half a block from Casa Batllo, the blocks from Casa Mila, walking distance to Sagrada Familia. Great coffee shops and fun window shopping.

Ideal place for shopping. Lots of shops. You can walk through the passage and find everything you need to buy together with admiring the buildings, cosy balcons with flowers and stylish people. Lots of metro and bus stops in this passage.

Great shopping. Love, love, love this stretch because the major Spanish retailers are there - Zara, Massimo Dutti, Purificacion, Adolfo Dominguez, Caramelo, Desigual...etc.. If you're here for the shopping, this is it if what you want are the regular Spanish retail brands. But be warned though, not all the salespersons in the shops are friendly nor helpful towards Asians. Strange that they do not see the need to establish good public relations although they're in the retail business. Expect that the most polite request in English can result in a hostile and less than friendly response from them. Having said that, there were service staff who were especially helpful and nice. One such example was this sales lady in the Bimba y Lola shop situated along Carrer de Valencia. She was a refreshing exception. Wish there were more of such nice humble people around.
Love it!. I could walk up and down this street and shop till I dropped! There are so many stores that I wish I had more time to visit them!
Fifth Ave Ne York. This is similar to Fifth Ave New York,USA. First class stores,Brand names clothing. Safer to shop an close to Metroand tourist bus. Very clean place
Great shopping. Nice to stroll down this street and shop..Bring lots of money!! The Stella McCartney boutique is really nice...

It was great. I loved this tour. It is self navigating(audio tours available if you choose) . You see majority of the stadium except home locker room. Staff is helpful. The bar is cheap. I had a wonderful time

top shopping. this is an up market shopping area with buildings by gaudi to wonder at as well. My favourite shop was Bel a ladies and gentlemans clothes shop. I liked every item on display in the mens window which is really exceptional for me. Unfortunately with the chic and stylish offerings came hefty price tags, I lingered and returned twice but the items remain just a pipedream and still in the window.

Busy, busy, busy. Lots going on all the time. Tour and airport busses leave from here. Nice pavement cafe's. At the top end of Las Ramblas with lots of small side streets. Two lovely water fountains but unfortunately millions of pigeons that are fed by the tourists and are in plague proportions, causing the cleaning department (which do an excellent job) a lot of work.

My new favorite neighborhod. This is our second trip to Barcelona but our first time to visit this area. What a classy and lovely part of town. We went twice we liked it so much. Great places to eat and shop and walk to take in some really great buildings. Next trip here I think we will have to stay in this area.

Passeig de Gracia. Long road with a lot of shops, eateries and everything in between coming on this street. The subway and trains meet up here, shuttle buses to the airport pick up here, there's plenty to see and do here and it meets up with La Rambla here. Word of warning, it seems as if Monday is a common day for some of the shopping to close down, so don't be disappointed if there's less shopping involved
Great shopping area. A great place to shop, good bus & metro links. It is mainly the luxury end of the market shopping still it's nice to look. Well worth a look if you have the time.

Shopping!. We enjoyed this area and we consider it as one of the best streets in Barcelona to shop. There are many shops including the luxury ones to the normal ones. There was H&M, Zara, Mango, and many more. The luxury ones included Chanel, Saint Laurent, Gucci, Burberry, and Caronlina Herrera. You can also stop to eat when you're hungry in McDonalds. Its a very beautiful street with many shops!
Style. Wide modern and very stylish avenue with excellent shops and numerous food and refreshment establishments. The buildings are a dream for those interested in fine architecture and design.
Very busy Road. Very busy reminds me of the center of Londonbut good place for connections to the Metro and train lines

Outdoor shopping at it's best. First of all, it's a LOVELY street. It's not just the shops themselves [mostly luxury/high-end with moderate shops in between] but the mix of old world architecture interspersed with modern facades and lots of greenery. Even if you're not much of a shopper like us, it's worth a stroll.

A long and wide street. Good place for a walk in the centre. Casa Batlio, Casa Amatller, Casa Mila (La Pedrera), Casa Lleo Morera, some souvenir shops can be found here. Also Bus Touristic and City Tour doble-deckers stop here (near La Pedrera).

Passeig de Gracia Barcelona. I will say its the posh street of Barcelona. It starts with Apple Store. And continues with Gucci, Zara, Diesel, Desigual, Burberry, Adidas and the only Puma store in Spain. Also Casa Mila and Casa Amatller. And of course McDonald's with McCafe.
Shopaholics only. If you enjoy high end shopping, this is the place to be in Barcelona. There is some interesting Gaudi architecture to look at for the rest of us!
Great shopping Area. If you want to do some shopping on a higher level, this is the place to be. Very helpful people and nice wether makes shopping here a delight.
Window Shopping Only. With every designer shop you could think of in one street be prepared to max out those cards! Also with a mix of bars and restaurants and plenty of Gaudi architecture.

Good selection of designer shops. Certainly one of the main shopping areas to visit with a large selection of shops, hotels etc. Also has some stunning architecture if you take the time to look up .. including the Gaudi museum with its amazing roof chimneys.

Stunning Street. Barcelona really is a beautiful city. And this street really highlights it. Wide avenues, wide footpaths, trees, the patterned tiles on the footpath, the buildings and architecture - you must stroll down the street! Of course it is full of shops you will see anywhere else but keep an eye out for a few Gaudi buildings here and there!

Expensive shops. All the bug designed names can be found here along with many palaces designed and built by very famous architects. The Hop On Hop Off buses travel this route extensively. It is filled with many tourists and nice restaurant patios.
Excellent shopping street. You can spend the entire day shopping as you walk down Passeig, starting at Diagonal all the way to Plaza Catalunya.
Great. Using the metro , this area is great for shopping , very busy so keep your hands on your wallet ..... Pickpockets are renowned here

Cafes, modernista and beaux art architecture, and a bit of shopping. You cannot miss the fabulous Gaudi mansions on the street, but the other architecture and the ambiance (rather Parisian) make a strolling afternoon here a must-do.

Great if you love to shop. This is a nice place to go for those that like shopping with many high-end boutiques to choose from. It's a good idea to take comfortable shoes as there's a lot of walking up and down the street. A plus is that Casa Batlo and La Pedrera Familia are on this street, and there's some nice restaurants too.
a metro station. I know it is not the metro station , but it is a very crowded station , you can visit there gaudi houses , 2 of them and nice shopping area

Lovely stroll!. Many shops, bars, cafes etc, lovely to stroll along. Can recommend Tapa Tapa and QuQu restaurants along Passeig de Gracia. Also, of course, come here to see the houses of Gaudi. Great architecture. Can just spend an hour or 2 wandering here and taking it all in!

Nice, classy street. Most probably you will enjoy a short walk in here if you are a Gaudi fan. On these street you will see Casa Batllo, Casa Mila and other impresive buildings designed by other famous architects of Barcelona.

Worth it just to see Gaudi's Casa Batllóand Casa Milà. Would definitely recommend a visit along this street if for no other reason than to see Gaudi's Casa Batlló and Casa Milà . There are even more architectural gems to be found as well in the Eixample district within easy walking distance of Passeig de Gracia. It's worth a morning or afternoon just walking about the area to soak it all in. The shops are nice too if you have some money to blow.

Wonderful architecture. Two fabulous buildings side-by-side (one, Casa Batllo is literally fabulous, as it depicts the tale of St. George and the dragon in architectural metaphor) and a third at the end of the block. Absolutely mandatory during your visit to Barcelona!

Shop till you drop. Our favorite stores are Apple and El Corte Ingles. All the flagship clothing stores etc. Passeig de Gracia is lovely, tree lined with great bars and restaurants too. If you love to shop, shop here.

One of the most beautiful streets in the world. Top designers, lovely sidewalk cafes, great food, and lots of people watching are the attractions that bring crowds to de Gracia every day. There are two Antonio Gaudi properties on the street. When in Barcelona, I always stay close to or on de Gracia because of its central location and wonderful ambience.

Luxury shopping and walking area!. Gathered luxury brands as well as a big Zara store. Two outstanding Gaudi's buildings nearby.Restaurants are classic and well appointed. Although price may be pricy. It is great to even window-shopping and just take a slow walking here. Do wear comfortable shoes when visit here. It was very enjoyable walking from here all the way to Catalunya. If you enjoy cycling, this is the city for all bike-lovers,too!
Nice shopping area w/ Gaudi's works alongside.. Looks like most luxury global brands are all here. Good nice walk along the "high street" which go all the way to the seaside/ old harbour.
The modern retailers fit right in with the classical architecture.. Love walking down the street with many architectural delight. Camera is a must to capture the creativity of the sights.

Vibrant Area. Striking architecture to see as you walk de Gracia. Lots of shopping and restaurants in the area. I enjoy seeing all the people obviously from different parts of world, visiting just as me.

Errr - Shops. Some wonderful architecture but surrounded by incredibly busy roads and really just full of shops. If that's your 'thing' then this is the place for you - but there are many more interesting places.

Brilliant shopping!. Brilliant for shopping, the shops stay open until about 9pm. A lot of them are quite expensive but some are more reasonable and there are some lovely restaurants, where you can sit with a glass of wine and watch the world go by.

Elegant !. An amazing street...very classy and the shops are something certainly not to miss. This is the best street in Barcelona (in my opinion). Expensive but very tree-lined..do not miss a walk through this street..

Great shopping as long as you have good credit scores. Walking up and down on each side of the Gaudi avenue on a good day is entertaining. Make sure you leave your credit cards at your hotel or else the Mistress will challenge your credit scores
A mad shopping opportunity. There a hundreds of stores from high end to affordable almost overwhelming. Great people watching which was a source of endless fun.

The place to be. It seems this is the place to be to meet locals and visitors alike. The place is jumping and became my starting point for all the other places I wanted to visit, including the Plaza de Catalunya for the buses and Casa Batllo. I did not do any shopping but I did notice the presence of many shops on both sides of the avenue.

Great shopping street. Just above Placa de Catalan (above the Ramblas) lies this wide avenue with good shopping (multinational brands but also some local stores) and some good restaurant either side. And with Gaudi buildings scattered along, it is a great BCN experience
Passseig de Gracia - a Must. lots of wonderful shops.... and great for people watching, coffee places, restaurants etc. Best area
Get lost in the Gracia district. Get a good map, wear good shoes, bring supplies and save a day for this one. Prepare for one good shopping day.
Main shopping street. Lots of things to see here. Seats to sit and watch the people wander by. Two of Gaudi's most famous buildings as well. Some international shops and cafes and restaurants.
A Busy city street. Lovely walking down here in the sunshine. Lots of beautiful shops to look at and plenty of people watching

The Barcelona version of NY's "5th Avenue". Stayed in an apartment nearby, so was here nearly every day. Main thoroughfare with the best shops and outdoor cafes. There's even a gorgeous McDonald's where you can have a terrific cup of coffee and sit outside and people watch right across from Casa Batillo.

Stay on this Street for a wonderul area!. This street is very busy, and filled with high end shops. The Antonio Gaudi Casa Milla & Padrera are located on this street as well. Atmosphere in the area is wonderful and we loved touring the museums. Wonderful food and friendly area. Metro stops are convenient to navigate anywhere in town. Many people carrying bags and shopping, so it felt safe. Just keep your personal info in a safe area and be wise and I hope you will enjoy as much as we did!
Upmarket barcelona. The shops in this street were really upmarket but there were a few less expensive shops and lots of nice places to eat.
Great Prominade. A great showcase for Catalan architecture and home to seveal great Gaudi works. Lots of places to rest up and water as well. And shopping--big strength.

Classy area. OK, it's a major shopping thoroughfare but well worth a visit if youy have some time (and money) to spare. As you walk along make sure you look up at the architecture. That is amazing and so very easy to miss if all you look in is the shop windows!
Classy. Enjoy a walk through this great looking avenue. It is filled with posh shops and some of Gaudi's masterpieces like La Pedrera and Casa Battlo.
Got off at this stop and found so much architecture. just wondered around without a guide book and found so much - lovely people, cafes and places to stop and admire
S H O P P I N G!. Yeah, you know it. It's the shopping place ^)Also of course it offers gorgeous architecture of Gaudi but be ready to wait in a line!
Nice area. One of the good places to eat in the city, plenty of choice of very good restaurants for every taste.

Shop'n'meal street. This street connects the old area with several other touristic attractions. It is also a nice shopping area. But most of all you will enjoy the amazing architecture both during day and evening and will hardly resist one of many unique bars and cafes. We were lucky to book a hotel in this area.

Great Shopping but not cheap. Stroll from the Diagonal down to Plaza Catalunya taking in the shade , tapas bars and top name shops. You will need a credit card and a good bank balance on this wide sidewalked 'Paseo'. A lovely walk down to the plaza where you will see two of Gaudi's most famous buildings and so much more. Watch your wallets and handbags as there are some thieves about, but not to take your mind of this wonderful moment of your holiday.

Barcelona´s Oxford St.. It´s quite nice walking through this avenue. I felt like walking on Oxford St (London), and I think in both cases worths the experience. Going to Passeig de Gràcia has to be part of a travel plan to Barcelona.

The place to shop in Barcelona. If you like luxury items, which I do, such as Christina Herrera clothes, etc. And among these boutiques, two or three of Gaudi's buildings. What more can a tourist ask for?

Famous shopping street. Passeig de Gracia is the most famous shopping street in Barcelona, full of luxury boutiques and nice restaurants. Also Gaudi´s famous buildings La Pedrera and Casa Batlló are on this street. Street is easily accessible from Barcelona metro (stop is called Passeig de Gracia)
High end city. Hide your credit cards, every high end store in the world is here that one can imagine and then some. Also can take the metro to the end to Tibidabo to see the city from the mountain
Class. One of the classier parts of Barcelona with excellent shops, restaurants and hotels. Highly recommended if you're accustomed to the finer parts of cosmopolitan cities.

Elegant with Historic Architecture. Broad Passeig de Gracia is lined with elegant pisos and establishments from around the beginning of the last century. The centerpiece are two splendid buildings by Gaudi, Casa Batllo and Casa Mila. We enjoyed strolling the Passeig from Placa de Catalunya and visiting Casa Mila.

Great for shopping. Great place to do a bit of shopping or relaxing with a coffee if you're tired of walking around. Not really a cultural tourism place (except for a couple of Gaudi houses). Spent about 4 hours here when I went on a 3-day trip and that was sufficient. Much quieter and less touristy than Las Ramblas or Gothic Quarter.

All the shops you need. Could not keep my wife away from this place! She loved it, and found the sales, especially at the end of season were great. A local friend of mine told me the end of season sales are about 1/3 price to clear the stock. My wife took full advantage of that, buying lots of winter clothes, for our upcoming Southern Hemisphere winter! Also check out the side streets, plenty of bargains there as well.
Wow....shops. This street is brilliant...like Regent Street but you have space to walk. The buildings are stunning and the shops are even more stunning
Main shopping area. This is the main shopping area of barcelona, you can spend the whole day here or just window shopping. All of the high end brand can be found here
Shopping. Walk through from Plaza Catalonia to Passeig de Gracia and went into some of the best brands shops. Is a nice walk for a end of the day.

Tree lined avenue of luxury boutiques. Reminiscent of other European shopping avenues it provides a range of fashion options as well as coffee shops for resting the weary legs. Most famous luxury brands reside there as well as affordable main stream stores so all will have something that appeals.
When not shopping then either strolling or relaxing whilst people watching is also enjoyable.

Shopping Haven. Its purely a shopping place, if u wanna empty your wallet a bit and earn a bit of bags of your shoulder, its the perfect place to be. Along with the fountains, numerous restaurants, cafes, street food and the spanish architecture, its an all in one place.

Hopping street. Although you probably won't find many places to shop unless you're planning on spending hundreds of dollars at the numerous high-class stores, walking up and down the street is very fun. There are a lot of stores and cafes and the occasional Gaudi building! The restaurants are much more expensive than some equally good or better restaurants just a few streets off this touristy street.
Good for walking and people watching. Its not La Rambla but its got a good vibe. We ambled up and down it marveling at the architecture and just enjoyed the atmosphere.

Shopping Heaven. What should I say? For the girls (for the guys too maybe), this is a shopping heaven. A long street, full of shops. Everything is available here from luxury products, e.g. Cartier, Loewe to the normal one, e.g. Zara, Mango, Bershka etc..
Shopping, Dining, People Watching. The Passeig de Gracia is the center of the action -- shopping, fine dining, cafes, tapas bars, Gaudi and more Gaudi. The best hotels. It's a world class boulevard.

Too expensive for my taste. Most of the shops are either not my taste or too expensive for my taste. I would recommend window shopping if you can't afford to buy anything. I had an eye for a pair of shoes at one store but was not prepare to pay 350EURO for a pair of sneakers that my kids might wear for a season and then grow out of them. I would not miss out on the Nespresso concept store.
Where the top boutiques are. Here you can find all the top brands boutiques from around the world. Nice restaurants , and for sure casa batllo , a must that you have to visit.Nice hotels aswell.

It was a nice day in the park. The park itself is of course very nice and liked the musicians playing over there. The only thing what we do not like so much when you wish to buy something else from the people who sell that they keep on pushing.

Wonderful walking and window-shopping. This is the upscale boulevard of Barcelona -- very chic, very elegant -- a great place to wander, window-shop, and drink coffee. (We had our coffee in the cafe attached to La Perdrera, one of the Gaudi buildings, and it was a great place to people-watch.) The whole area is great -- street after street of early twentieth-century apartment buildings with great detailing and, of course, the Gaudi buildings (including the ones on the Diagonal, which intersects the Passeig). One day we met friends for lunch at Citrus, which was expensive but excellent. Another day we had lunch at Bar Mut (ditto).
Passeig de Gracia is a great walking path. Interesting architecture and wonderful shops/restaurants - definitely the pulse of Barcelona without the chaos.
Lots is happening. Very bussy street, lots to see and follow. We liked walking around, but dis not spend enough time here. We'll definately go back
A Window Shoppers Delight. A perfectly delightful street for an evening stroll. A shoppers heaven. Not to mention a visual cornucopia-- neo-classical and modernism architecture collide and abound.

Nice street for luxury shopping!. This is a great and big shopping street if you are looking for brands like Louis Vuitton, Chanel, Gucci, Burberry etc. It is a lot of people and you will find two houses designed by Gaudi in this street. If you go to the end of Passei de Cracia, to the Catalunya square you will find the tourist information (big signs, so you won't miss it) and you can claim the tax refunds if you are a non EU member.
Nice, but not really a sight. It's a nice street with many cafes and restaurants, not really a "sight". Good for breakfasts and coffee breaks.

Chic and vibrant and so much to see. I love this avenue passeig de gracia. Start from plaza cataluyna at the apple store and walk up. Many tapas bars and restaurants and chic designer shops but the best of all is the casa mila,la pedrera and the casa batllo. A great place for a stroll

Shopping and exercise. If you want to get away from all the little alleys that offer a large variety of shopping possibilities and want to let the tourist hang out for an afternoon and see all the big brands, the Passeig is a good opportunity, also as it is a large street that is also packed with side streets you'll get lots of exercise and won't have any regrets having a large paella the same night.

A good reference of Barcelona. Nobody can visit Barcelona and say that was not there! Passeig de Gràcia is an introduction of a Gaudí and modern city. La Pedrera and La Casa Batlló are two MUSTs of the Barcelona Culture in the visit of this avenue, but also the boutiques and nice exclusive shops like Rabat...
Nice to Walk; Expensive to Shop. Nice architecture and cityscape - worth the walk even if you are not a shopper. From the streetlamps to the sidewalk - the surroundings are interesting.
DON-T MISS IT. If you want to see unique things- buildings from the modernist period or if you want to take a stroll on the boulevard or go shopping this is the place

Main road of Barcelona. This is one of the major avenues in Barcelona and one of its most important shopping and business areas. At 5 kilometres, the wide boulevards strewn with traffic add to the feeling of opulence with designer shops, hotels and restaurants.There is also Gaudí's architecture such as the La Pedrera and Casa Batllo. This was the stopping point for our tour bus and we walked to the main square and then on to the Ramblas.

Great central boulevard. We chose our hotel due to its proximity to Passeig de Gracia. It's a very central place with lots of public transportation options as well as in walking distance to La Ramble and El Barri Gotic.
Free walking. This is the area you can walk and see free Gaudi s masterpieces from external and many other structures that would amaze you!

Modernismo Pure. One of the most important areas in Barcelona, an excelent example of the architecture and design in turn of centuries. Space, great design, luxury shops around, but also paces for stop over for ordinary turists. Don't miss it.

One of the world's most cosmopolitan rides. The "Passeig de Gràcia" is one of the streets of Barcelona where you can enjoy important buildings (Casa Batllo, Casa Mila, Casa Morera), luxury hotels (Mandarin, Majestic, Casa Fuster), boutiques (Furest, Gucci, Chanel , Bel, and a long etc), designer shops (Pedrera, Vinçon), jewelers, restaurants with little star, but attractive, terraces in the street or on the top floor of hotels like Hotel "Comtes de Barcelona", movies (Comedia) .... in short, is worth a visit.

Gaudi's Work. Learnt a lot about how Guadi worked at this apartment block. He was described by one of his tutors at architectural school as either a genius or a lunatic. Can't be any doubt that he was a bit of both. His ideas were incredible.

Classy & Cosmopolitan. Very wide boulevard - high end retailers at one end gradually becoming more high street as you head towards Plaza Catalunya. Fantastic architecture. Shame we don't have an equivalent in London.

Oh my legs!. Longest street ever with all the designers you know and want but can't afford. Went into Vincon- a furniture/interior shop- the biggest shop ever and so nice but so can't buy anything there, so expensive. But the streets are nice with lovely shops and obivously has casa mila and batillo so must go!
glamorous. glorious street and buildings ! many cases are placed on sides of this street like casa battlo and mila , gaudi's magic works
Impressive street. Lots of impressive buildings - don't forget to look up - just hold on to your bag. Lots to look at - top deck of the sightseeing buses best place to get the best views.

Worth a visit. This area is very high end- interesting view as it is different to some of the other city streets, it reminds me of an american designer road. Very pretty when the sun is shining. You will find some designer shops, places to eat and some of Gaudis architecture.

Wonderful experience. shops galore line this lovely area, but if you're in the mood to spend bring your credit card!! Cartier, guess and tommy Hilfiger are just a few of the high end names you'll find!
Great to walk down and people watch. Also don't miss Gaudi's casa batllo.
Loved it
Rodeo Drive of Barcelona. Lots of high end shopping. Easy walk from Plaza Catalunya. Home to Casa Batllo & Casa Mila. I love the stone benches at the bases of the street lights!

Rivals the Champs Elysees. This is an amazing avenue with shops lining each side that rival the finest, most famous streets in the world. The shopping is incredible, the architecture is stunning, and there are tons of food choices. The street is full of energy.
Love this part of Barcelona. Such a busy road, but with loads to see and places to shop and eat. Great to have a wonder down on the way to Las Ramblas

You feel you are on 5th Aven in NY. When you heat this Street you will feel its warmth and big glamour, just like 5th aven in New York City. Put on your best outfits but wear nice sneakers because you will walk a lot!.While there you can go Tapas, shopping at the best designer shops like Channel. Famous mandarin Oriental hotel is also located on this Street where you can stop by and have a cocktail in its Bar!.

Expensive lane. If you want to shop till you drop with an unlimited budget then this is where you need to go. Think of all the high end names that you know and you will see them on this road. We walked along here on our way from La Rambla to the Sagrada Familia Church. A very long yet rewarding walk. There is a lot of architecture to admire on the road. I took a lot of pictures. For example, Casa Batllo and Palau Baro de Quadras. A very nice walk.

My favorite street on Barcelona. Eixample district is the heart of Barcelona tourism, and Passeig de Gracia is one of the most famous streets in this district. This street has some of world-famous attractions like Casa Mila and Casa Batllo by Gaudi, Casa Amattler towards the left of Casa Batllo and some other buildings with art nouveau architecture. We got lucky because we stayed near Eixample district, and got to see these amazing buildings 2-3 times!!

Excellent range of shops, felt very safe. We walked the Passeig de Gracia every day and night and felt very safe the whole time. Lots of shops (amazing Nespresso store!) lots of cafes and coffee shops.

High street fashion - Gaudi architecture. Love this street for its Gaudi street pavement, ancient street lighting, the Perdrera, Casa Battlo and lots of High Street fashion (Chanel, YSL, Armani, ...) and a lovely design shop with an awesome interior and outside terrace on the 2nd floor (Vinçon). Wish I could live on that 2nd floor!

Shoppers Paradise. Truly a shoppers paradise! We bought Zara sweaters and Mango shirts, This long avenue of high class shops with globally well known brands will whet the appetites of shoppers. Euro spending will hopefully help the economy of Spain in Passeig de Gracia.

Shop, Shop, Shop & Look-Up. A beautifully wide avenue with all the Glitz of a shopping street in many major cities both Europe & USA. The street lamps are metal works of art. A pleasant entrance to Rambla
Cool. A very good way to start knowing the city. Very large and a lots of point of interests make this path a must-to-know touristic point.

Credit Card Zone. Be careful - here you can spend a lot of money a get a bunch of marvellous products. Enjoy shopping in this area and relax in the many restaurants - some of these equipped with Michelin stars.

ELEGANCE MADE AVENUE. After a walk through the Gracia quarter, with it`s charming streets and squares, you can take down the Passeig de Gracia. Or you can take it up, after a visit to the Gothic and the Born quarters. Along this magnificent avenue, as well as a lot of shops, including famous local and international brands, you'll find some of Gaudí's masterpieces, and other jewels of the Catalonian architecture.

very nice street to see. This is one of BCN's very nice streets.It has some good shops as well as traditional tapas restaurants.It is highly recommended to go there and eat in these small restaurants.
I loved this street. This street had everything. Really nice shops, magnificent buildings and good restaurants. If you walk on it towards the north, you will see Casa Battlo.
an avenue. the passeig de Gracia has all the stores that you find everywhere,One thing worth looking at is the lamps and benchs from Gaudi
busy neighbour. you can find many cafes restaurants and brands shop in that area like las rambas but not overcrowed.
Shoping. My wife and I spent a perfect afternoon shoping in this lovely street!!! And also you can have a rest in a terrace under the sun...
Visit the magic fountain!. Check the schedules, but seeing the magic fountain choreographed to fun music is a great way to relax before dinner!

Clean street with many shops. I liked the street as the pedestrian walk way is wider than normal streets. Many shops (upscale brand shops, cafés and inexpensive clothes shops) and also two of the houses Gaudi built. It was just close by from my hotel so we walked up and down many times. I recommend you to walk down the street when you're in Barcelona.

avoid if you need to switch from train to Metro. when we arrived in Barcelona, we decided to use public transportation to get from the BCN airport to our hotel along the L4 metro. After all, in possession of a T-10 card it costs a mere Euro for the entire commute. I had chosen 'Passeig de Gracia' as the hub where to switch from the Renfe train to the metro because it seemed to be the most convenient. Since the PdG station is undergoing some major construction (from May 12 for ca. 16 months), it was hard to switch having to leave the station, looking for the metro, going downstairs again; all with luggage. (Returning to the airport this morning, we avoided PdG and chose Clot instead. No sweat!)Also, beware of pick pockets at the PdG metro stop since it is a major hub. The metro was pretty crowded, I tried to make my way in, suitcase and all. I had my purse around my neck and shoulders. Some woman tried to block my way. She had a coat over her arm. I then noticed her touching me. Under that coat she was trying to open my purse. I slapped her on her hands and she left the metro. I was even more careful after that. Left everything at the hotel; took passport copies with us and only one credit card and a little money.

Don't miss Gracia. We walked up the passage de Gracia and carried on . You then get to Gracia with it's village feel and bohemian shops. We found a charity shop full of bric a brac which has been open fro fifty years. It is all run by volunteers. The people were so friendly and I bought a lovely picture which the people at the shop wrapped with such care that it made it home without a scratch. This area gives you a feel of the real Barcelona.

AS GREAT AS CHAMPS ELYSEES IN PARIS. Am I overreacting? so please take a stroll on "Passeig de Gracia" in Barcelona. You'll find the very best fashion designer stores, fancy restaurants, Gaudí's landmarks and, as I'm used to saying here, life! so much life that's impossible to be in a bad mood :-)
Nice area. Very accesible by Metro. Went for the Gaudi buildings. Didn't care for the shopping. Amazing architecture. One of a kind. Worth the visit!
Posh shops and Gaudi houses. Lovely street to walk down - wish I could have afforded to go into Tiffany & Co!! Seeing the Gaudi balconies was great - magical.
Nice, spacious shoppingstreet. Some very expensive shops. Many restaurants, but beware of 'touristic traps': not good food at hig prices. But a beautiful street to take walks
A must in BCN. Gaudi, tapas bar, nighlife and more. Be aware that the best time to visit is from 3-6 pm. After that, streets, restaurants and attractions are crowded

Very expensive. Lots of designer shops - went in Mui Mui and were massively outnumbered by staff. Many of the designer shops were deserted. There were some cheaper shops Zara Mango etc. Stradivarius had a sale on and got some fantastic bargains

Indulge yourself in this avenue of glamour. This glamour avenue is the main artery to all the Barcelona and if it's shopping you like then you won't be disappointed. We were lucky enough to be there when the January sales were on and got some excellent bargains.
A great street for wandering. Marvel at the architecture (not just Gaudi) and look in the interesting shops (eg Vincon and Camper)
Designer heaven. If you have a limitless credit card burning a hole in your pocket you'll love this street. From one end to the other you'll find every Designer shop you can imagine
The shopping and expensive bar center. Definitely take a walk through here. It´s a very nice boulevard filled with stores like Louis Vitton and Prada and great bars along the way.

A Beautiful Stroll Through Barcelona. An easy way to see many of the most wonderful things in Barcelona--shops, houses, markets, artists, and restaurants. Take a stroll down the Passeig de Gracia at any time during the day and you are bound to see something interesting. Once you arrive at Plaza Catalunya, walk over one block to Las Ramblas and continue your stroll through the historic part of town.
Atmospheric. Everyone should go here at least once - soak up the atmosphere - look up as well as ahead so as not to miss some of the historic architecture.

Fifth Avenue of Barcelona. My experience of the massive street was pretty superficial; I was overwhelmed by the amount of people everywhere, designer stores, and restaurant tourist traps. During the quieter parts of the street, I was able to open my eyes and realize that the architecture is so unique and magnificent, but most of the time, I was too concerned with trying to not run into people or get pickpocketed.It's definitely a shopping haven so bring your money and your passport (to get a refund on tax if you're a foreigner, of course!). However, do your research if you want to eat on the street...there are way too many restaurants to weed through.
great walk. this is actually the way through Guadi houses and some other modern miracles to the Sagrada familia. beautiful, full of great shops of the most know names

Magnificent Mile or Fifth Ave. Fancy designer stores and touristy restaurants - nothing unique about any of them (except for La Pedrera and Casa Batllo). You can't tell if you are in Chicago, NYC or Barcelona.
Take your credit card!!. Close to Paza Catalunya, there are plenty of good value tapas bars and all the expensive designer shops.

worth the view. think of 5th avenue, oxford street, champs elyse, milan this is the equivalent of barcalonas fashion corner, but with very artistic buildings in view, nice and open plenty of boutique shops and places to dine and even sit on the benches ans watch the world go by.

Open your eyes. We enjoyed our time on Passeig de Gracia which is a busy thoroughfare. As others have noted you need to look beyond the expensive shops and search out the authentic tapas restaurants and bars. The architecture is amazing if you take the time to look as well. We were not fussed by the expensive named shops; these are two a penny and can be found anywhere.
Great area - high end definitely. Very similar to Paris here - lots of nice shops and Gaudi museums - wonderful cafes/food. Would recommend Tapas 24 in this area - great food and ambience.

Shop and eat.... Go to Passeig de Garcia if you want to buy. something...Zara, Pull & Bear, Mango, El corte Ingless and more. Full of Tapas and Paella restaurants.Try Txapella Restaurant. If you are lucky try Ciutat Cundall tapas. very busy... Enjoy.

Look up or you'll miss it!. Where else can you walk in a few blocks and see such amazing architecture that was way ahead of its time? You're always looking up and surprised with what you will see. We passed by this street routinely on our four days in Barcelona and saw something unique on the buildings each time we were there.

Elegant wide avenue. Here for Casa Mila and exterior of Casa Batilo. Elegant with designer shops and what appeared to be nice restaurants. However, apart from the Gaudi houses did not really investigate.

Exquisite avenue for window shopping. This is certainly one of my favourite shopping areaswhenever in Barcelona. Besides the beauty of the avenueon either side, there are lots of trendy shops and amazinglybeautiful buildings to look at. Most side streets are also well worth going to. In all, very breath-taking! Nothing to envy Parisor any other cosmopolitan European city.
Busy road. This is a busy touristy area, full of expensive shops and equally expensive cafe's. Not very spanish.
Amazing shopping. I always love to head to Passeig de Gracia for the best shopping in Europe. Not only does it have fantastic shops but a great range of bars, cafes and tapas places.

high class shopping. a great area for money people , high brow brands galore .
if planned right you can save on walking , using a combo of public transport and forward planning

Buy stuff, again.. Well, every city has a shopping street (Via del Corso a Roma, Champs Eliseé in Paris - no idea how to spell it -, 5th Avenue in New York). This is the one in Barcelona. Big, spacious, happy people. lots of shops. Don't miss it.

Great area to wander shop and eat. Full of high end stores and restaurants. Not necessarily very pricey. Enjoyed a couple of hours wandering around. Lots of sales in January! Not as crowded and touristy as the ramblas. Also great transport up and down this road takes you from the mountain to the sea, basically!

No visit to Barcelona is complete without a passage to Passeig de Gracia. Imagine going to Paris and not visiting Les Champs Elysees or New York and missing a visit to 5th Avenue. No visit to Barcelona is complete without a visit to Passeig de Gracia.With the broad Avenues lined up with some fascinating architectural buildings housing top notch brands,a visit is worth while even for window shopping.I was particularly interested to see Gaudi's extraordinary legacy dominating the architectural map of Barcelona namely his two famous buildings on this Avenue : La Pedrera also known as Casa Milà and Casa Batllo.
Le carrer d'Or. This is one of the streets of the Quadrant d'Or. It's a big avenue with beautiful buildings like La Pedreda and Casa Batllo. It's nice to visit, to take some photos and to lunch.

Spend many an hour and many a Euro on this street!. Wonderful shopping experience. Don't forget the road parallel, Passeig Catalunya is also beautiful and lined with shops. Also Mango outlet store with uo to 80% off just a few streets down. No 37 Girona. Post Christmas sales nearly killed me! But my oh my - the Spanish shop assistants have to be the most unfriendly in the world!

Great place for a stroll if you like city-life.. Take your time and see the heart of Barcelona. The are a couple of Gaudi's buildings (must see), your usual shopping (LV, Gucci, Hermes, etc.) and some great restaurants/tapas bars.

good job i do not live here...........i would end up bankrupt!!. could not believe my eye's when walking up this never ending street.............so vibrant,full of culture and life. not to mention the fantastic shops restaurants and bars. it is a really nice shopping area and you can get to it easily by the metro. it also has a few parks further up for the children.many of the shops are at the high end spec but they do have other high street shops. the buildings are beautiful and its hard not to stop and look up in ore. its a huge street very busy as you would expect but well worth a visit if you enjoy shoppping............but take plenty of euro's and buy something nice!!!

Beautiful Xmas lightning. The Xmas lightning at Passeig de Gracia was spectacular, imitation chandeliers in every block, all the store windows fully lighted and with Xmas decorations, and the people slowly walking the avenue, absorbing all its beauty, was wonderful.
Nice piece of art. This is amazing building just off the road. That road is very vast and ends on a sort of a big square. I like it very much.

A key location for metro transportation. Beyond the features of the area, this is a very important metro location where you can go to so many places. I cannot recommend the Metro highly enough and particularly this stop. You can buy 10 tickets for 10 Euros. It is a bargain and is very easy! For the price of one cab ride, two people can make five trips.

delight for all.... Brilliant street running down from Diagonal Metro to Passeig de Gracia Metro.You can reach here by metro L3 or L5 at Station Diagonal or by metro L3 at Station Passeig de Gracia.This is one stop for everyone, from food to cloths, architectures to hotels everything is available. Best plan would be to have a cheap and best hotel Casa Gracia booked which is on the street itself with easy access to the street and its holdings.When you stroll from Diagonal metro towards Passeig de Gracia Metro, you will find brilliant Gaudis architectures in between turned into museums and restaurants like Casa Mila. Big brand shops like Louis Vuitton, Escada, Hugo Boss, Bimba n Lola and Gucci are also on this street. Hugo Boss has an amazing visual appeal from outside.For local food you can try Tapa Tapa restaurant. There are other american coffee and food outlets as well on the street in case you dont want to try local food.This is a must visit and you will never get bored during your stroll or stay. Its advisable to book a hotel on this street to enjoy it the most. Also from 2 metro stations on this street you will find easy access to other attraction of Barcelona. For Ex: for Park Guell take L3 from Diagonal towards Trinitat Nova.Or for Sagrada Familia take L5 from Diagonal towards Vall d'HebronOr for Barceloneta beach take L4 from Passeig de Gracia towards La Pau.

Architect's treasure. Walk along this famed street, and you will not only spot some of Gaudi's famous buildings, but other Catalan architects who really have such genius and imagination that you can rarely find elsewhere. Definitely worth a visit!

Excellent early evening stroll. If you want to take a stroll, window shop, buy or simply people watch then this is the street for you. High quality shops, wide pavements and lost of well dressed locals. Good way to pass an hour or two before dinner.

Main shopping thoroughfare. This street was a fun walk at night. Lots of restaurants and tapas bars, as well as coffee shops and lots of high-end shopping. A great place to spend a few hours, window shopping and people watching.
Shopping, shopping, shopping. If you are looking for shopping, you will find everything...Nice area also for dinning... Do not leave Barcelona without visiting Paseo de Gracia!

Nice walk and a spot of sightseeing. It might be a fair walk up from Placa de Catalunya but it would be difficult to get lost! Many boutiques and top designer shops like Emporio Armani and Jimmy Choo. There are also tapas bars, cafes and restaurants but make sure you look at the menu before seating yourself as could be quite pricey! Overalll worth the stroll for a spot of sightseeing.

Broad way to walk, but just like another. Nice street to walk, many stores, definitely for you if you are the brandy type. Only difficult to find a nice restaurant. We ended up in Qu Qu becuase I felt like having some simple tapas, not a good decision. All the expensive streets in the world looked like the same bucause they consist of the same brands. This one is a bit different due to the two famous buildings of Gaudi. But apart from that, it's just another New Bond street or Monte Napoleone.

Trendy, expensive, touristy, and very cool!. You can tell this is the more expensive area of Barcelona, the Luis Vuiton, Ferrari, and Rolex shops sort of give it away. This expensive vibe is also felt in the restaraunts and bars here. Quite overpriced, but the food and service of these bars and restaraunts reflect the high prices. Be sure to check out the amazing architecture as well, some very cool Gaudi buildings on this street!
High end shopping and interesting architecture. It is like other upper level shopping areas like Madison Avenue etc. In addition to the shopping is wonderful architecture including work of Gaudi.
an expensive shoping street. Other than lots of expensive shops, not much else to see. The Gaudi buildings all require entry fees.
Different seting. A huge boulevard full of nice shops and comfortable hotels with centenial trees on the sidewalk.Famous tapas bars on the surroundig.

A shoppers Paradise. Every major brand is on this strech of road, but even if you are not shopping, there is a such a granduer to this boulevard from the wide street, to the beutiful buildings on either side, two of
Gaudi's building are on either side.
Barcelona's Magnificent Mile!. A beautiful wide avenue filled with beautiful architecture and shops. Really beautiful with the Christmas lights and decorations. Perfect for a holiday stroll.

A Hive of Activity. Being central to Barcelona this place was alive and humming, even in December.n ice skating rink was set up nearby and was a great delight wacthing young and old escape.Justr stand on the street corner a while and watch everything happen around you. We even saw a bank robbery (we think?)where the ploice swarmed in from all directions and within a minute there were about 20 police cars all parked on the street and pavement outside of the bank and not long after someone was drgged out of the bank and taken away.Certainaly a sight to see.Xmas decorations are fantastric in this area also as they are ion many other Barceona streets. A must see area.

Nice. Good range if shops....not too overwhelming or busy! Everyone is out to enjoy the sights, grab some food and chill!Although i did look twice for the sephora make up store and was unable to locate it!

Great to hear its history from the open-top tour bus. Passeig de Gracia is a very attractive avenue in Barcelona, that leads to the beautiful Placa de Catalunya (Catalonia Square). It is an affluent area with many designer shops and restaurants. The amazing Gaudi-designed Casa Battlo and Casa Mila/ La Pedrera can be found here, which are fabulous and must-sees when visiting fabulous Barcelona. The open -top tour buses travel along here, and its great to hear about the avenue and architecture's history.

shopping at its finest and most expensive. think Madison Ave, rue de Faubourg, Rodeo Drive -- and then put it in Barcelona -- add amazing architecture, including Gaudi's, and put it on the most beautiful street imaginable. Just bring lots of money!!!!
Keep walking up La Rambla. Bustling, vibrant area of Barcelona. Lots of cafe's and restaurants not to mention the Gaudi architecture. Some small boutiques also.

A gem many might miss. If you go to the Pl Catalunya, La Rambla, Barre Gotico etc you may well miss this fantastic shopping and dining "Boulevard". So far as I know they don't make anywhere the fuss about this about some other stuff in the city, perhaps they keep the best to themselves, crafty Catalonians...

Great area of Barcelona. Our hotel was just off the Passeig de Gracia. It's a great street with lots of designer shops, and two Gaudi buildings, we visited Le Perdrera. This is also just a short walk to the Ramblas for the tourist shops.
Exciting street. It's is an exciting street if you like architecture. Not only the buses, but also the street lamps are worth the visit. Both sis of the street have interesting houses to visit.

Shop, shop, shop til you drop or your wallet gives out!. This is one of Barcelona's high end shopping streets, with the likes of international names (Chanel, Tiffany, Louis, etc.) and local high end jewelry stores dotted with tapas places, wine bars, hotels and must see sights - La Pedrera and Case Battlo. Go to shop (or window shop) and soak up this lively boulevard.

Place to come to for shoes. This is where I found some of the best shops for shopping, in particular shoe shops in Barcelona. I was able to find a beautiful pair of shoes (my souvenir) while enjoying an afternoon wondering this impressive street that has a mix of great shops and some buildings designed by Gaudi in it.

A fun loving place for all. If you want to shop-till-you-drop, this is the place. Also the walk around is absolutely stunning with one of the best architectures and buildings. Cafes and restaurants are plenty. In short, its the happening place in Barcelona and one shouldn't miss it
The 5th Ave. of Barcelona. If you like to shop while traveling, this is the best place to find the most recognized stores in the world. Also, you can see some of Gaudi's masterworks.
Shop till you drop. You can do some serious damage to your credit cards in the amazing shops along this street, but you'll also pass a couple of Gaudi's buildings along your way.

Posh shopping district with historic buildings. Passeig de Gracia is essentially the posh shopping district with historic buildings. Essentially hosting brands like Armani. There are plenty of photos to take of the spectacularly designed historic buildings and it's a pleasant street to walk along and do some window shopping or if you have plenty of money, some designer brand shopping. Additionally it's right in the centre of town, so you are bound to pass through there at some point on your travels, even if you were trying to go and visit other tourist sights.
Fantastic area. Filled with wonderful bars and restaurants. Every location is easy to find with some of the fab local mapd available.

Decent Afternoon. Started strolling up during the day and walked back down once it turned dark. I think it was more beautiful at night with the christmas lights and all. \
Plenty of quirky little boutiques if you are willing to travel the smaller lanes but ardent shoppers would not be disappointed by the high end boutiques as well.

Stunning architecture. You have to walk the road twice... at night during Christmas time it is so spectacular and romantic...
It is more than just Gaudi;s houses and benches (not designed by him)....

very popular boulevard. This is a very large , clean and very populat boulevard in Barcelona. And It's filled with shops of one side and the other
is very safe at night.

Great for shopping and restaurants. If you are a fan of designer brands this is definatley were you will find them, there's gucci, Burberry etc etc, also great for restaurants with loads of choice from fish to steak and so on.
Lovely. This is a beautiful part of Barcelona to ramble and stumble upon so many interesting places, definitely worth visiting.

An Avenue to discover. We stayed in one hotel in this avenue and it was a very good choice. Walking here was very interesting. We found nice options for shopping and restaurants and bars. For shopping there are options for every pocket, same for food. If you want a breakfast, fast food or nice restaurants you won't be disappointed.
Hope to be back soon.

shop your heart out. If you enjoy shopping and eating, passeig de gracia is the place to hang out. We were lucky enough to have two weeks in barcelona, but if we'd had two days I would have wanted to stroll this avenue and eat out at one of the restaurants. We made an impression on the stock levels at the Camper shoe store, which is a spanish brand. Contribute to the local economy where you can! you get something and the local economy gets something, all good!
Cosmopolitan. Great selection of shopping and restaurants (try Botafumerio for seafood). All the main designers are located here----and VAT refunds make shopping better than the US.

Wonderful location. My hotel was located on Passeig de Gracia (Casa Fuster) which was the perfect location for great shopping and amazing dining. My first night in Barcelona coincided with the Shopping Night in Barcelona where the stores stayed open until 2 am and the streets were filled with food, music and great values. Lots of late night fun!

Really nice street in Barcelona kind of like the fifth Avenue of the place. On one of my tricks to Bursun I stayed at a hostel it on the street. It's a very nice street it's clean it's safe and has a lot of shopping. However if you're visiting from the United States I wouldn't go spend your money on one of the expensive stores on the street. A lot of the products are available back home and you can probably get them for much cheaper without paying the high prices that you see in Europe. The street also has one of the Gaudi houses. And the street also leads into Plaza Catalunya. It's a central place to stay in Barcelona

Go on Xmas season. And around the evening, that way you can see all the lights they have set up on the street.
Shops are high scale, except for the occasional casual ones. But it is definitely worth the time.

awesome street with outdoor cafes. this is the ultimate dining experience in Barcelona, you have to do this at least twice a day! it's such a beautifully designed street with a breathtaking atmosphere, you'll find any reason to sit and enjoy life and watch the people passing by.

My favorite bullevard in Barcelona. To walk up or down passeig de Gracia is allway lovelly. There are 2 modernist buildings of Gaudi, the Majestic and Mandarin hotels and some of the most exclusive boutiques of Barcelona

all the name brands. all the big namebrands and then some are available , no different to really any other big city shopping parade. wide pedestrian walkways and still pretty architecture. Gaudi houses a little further up-perhaps a 10 min walk from La Ramblas but the area has less charm than La Ramblas

Expensive Stores & Restaurants. Mostly overpriced stores that Americans can buy cheaper at home. The Champs Elysee of Barcelona. We did find a fantastic Italian restaurant El Greco in Passeig de Gracia which we highly recommend and enjoyed seeing two Gaudi buildings on the street.Lots of beautiful decorations for the holidays and celebratory activities for Shop Night Barcelona- which was their Black Friday. Just off Gracia on Provenca is a cute shoe and tote store Kokua which features super comfortable ballet flats and totes inexpensively made in Spain (with a Hawaiian name?!)

High Class Brands. This is the street to go for you that want to buy expensive and high class brands. Not like Las Ramblas where you find a lot of cheap items for souvenirs, this is the serious item only. You can find a lot of stores here. Gucci, LV, Massimo Dutti, Coach, etc.This street also crowded with restaurants and cafes, so if you dont like shopping, at least you can enjoy some of the Spain tapas here.Must visit!
Everything in one Street. You name is it has it.. Shops, Cafe, Metro station, walk the full length towards the Caterdral, it worth the walk
November 22. Shopping nite. Had no idea. How fun. Ballerinas ! Free cava discounts and drinks at Different shops. Great atmosphere in the city

Good for shopping and people watching. Rivals Michigan Avenue, Bevely Hills, etc. All the high end stores as well as others and great shopping on the streets crossing it as well. Slick pavers line the sidewalks and the city sprays them down each night (it seemed) so if you're out early in the morning walk carefully!
The 5th Avenue with a Barcelona architecture . Go, buy(or not), look up, look to the sides, look down. This is the real street you want to visit in Barcelona.

Shopping. Loved this street. Our hotel was half way up and we were so close to all the wonderful shopping. Also close to Plaza Catalonia and Las Ramblas. We were close to Casa Batilo and La Pedreara. Best city ever.
Gucci, Pucci. A long beautiful street full of fantastic architecture and very expensive shops inter spaced with tapas bars and good sandwich shops.

You Need a Big Fat Wallet. OMG what lovely shops! If only I'd won the lottery!!! We spent a very pleasant few hours window shopping, using the apple products in the largest Apple store in the world and drooling over Fernado Alonso's 2011 F1 car int he Ferrari shop. The Gaudi houses are also amazing and it's worth taking 5 minutes out to stand and stare - just beautiful!
shoppers paradise. has it all in one street all the designer shops and restaurants to match a great area, make sure you have good walking shoes

Barcelona's Regent Street. If upmarket shopping and interesting craft is your thing spend a morning exploring this wonderful street. It's much less tourist infested than the Ramblas or Barri Gotic - lots of prosperous Catalans on view. It also has a plethora of sidewalk cafes in which you can watch the local ladies parade their charms. I particularly liked Vincon for quirky household stuff. There's also a huge Apple store and plenty of expensive designer stores.

Beautiful strip. I think I accidentally called this area Gran Via in other postings, but realised that's Madrid, oops, this is the place I meant, lots of shops and lots of Gaudi's goth buildings on this strip. Its lots of walking too.

Just walk!. When you walk in the Passeo de Gracia you feel special! Such beautiful stores,everything so elegant and you don`t feel crashed.On the contrary you feel very well.Just sit and have a café there.Just watch La Padrera.That`s enough for your eyes!I really love BCN forever!

Great if you like high-end shopping. This area is full of expensive stores. There is some interesting architecture from Gaudi and Guell, but other than that it is a typical high-end shopping district.

Expensive shopping for those who love it. Excellent thoroughfare, facades of old buildings especially those of Gaudi, were fasinating. Non-shoppers, but the convenience and pedestrian friendly wide streets, wide sidewalks, made Barcelona A-1 in our book
Hotel. We stayed on Passeig de Gracia and walked it many times. Lots of high end shops but also other shops as well.
Fashions. Many cool fashion stores with all the big brands, good parking facilities underground, walking distance from the Catalunya
Beautiful boulevard!. This was near our hotel. A lovely street with ,any choices of cafes. We enjoyed Divinus one evening.

Good Place to eat at Barcelona - Passeig de Gracia. Excellent place to go. Lot's of eatery and shopping. You didn't even know that the building that you are suppose to look out for is actually sandwich in between some shopping malls! Only can take photos from the opposite street. This place, there is a nice restaurant that serve good spaggetti and food & cheaper than Ra Ramblas. It's call the Divinus. Black umbrellas along the walkway and just around the corner of Emporio Amani shop.
Great Area!. Nice main street with tons of shops, restaurants and cafes. It was a starting point for many of our explorations.

a shoppers delight. Wonderful shops,beautiful boulevard, all the prestigious stores are located here.Spent a rainy Sunday shopping here during a thunderstorm,and it was the first day of the sales rounded of by a large glass of red in the beautiful Torres wine shop.Very relaxing lovely room and of course had to purchase one or two bottles.

the high st. if you are familiar with london or your a londoner then the best way to describe this street is that it's the Sloan st of Barcelona. has all the designer shops and two of Gaudi's Houses. I would recommend staying at the majestic which is smack in center of this st.
Wow. The buzz!. The sites and the buzz make this a must destination. Every brand label is here. Get a map and wa the city, every corner reveals new amazing views

Puts the Champs Elysees in the shade. This wide, cosmopolitan street is lined with high-end shops, attractive cafes and restaurants and gracious buildings. The street is clean, and full of people from all over the world. There are virtually no street traders or itinerants. The police have a visible presence and you feel quite safe. Strolling here in the evening is delightful. The atmosphere is relaxed and civilized and everyone just seems to be enjoying life.

Scenic route. There was a lot to see on this street, from the Gaudi buildings and other modernist architecture to the Chanel store. The promenade has a very open feel due to the layout of the intersections.

Gorgeous Area.. Our tourist bus left from this major street so we were up and down it many times. It's a beautiful area of landmark buildings including Gaudi's, wide avenues &many trees. Our hotel was a short walk away and we enjoyed being in this neighborhood.
Some luxurious shops amid Gaudi buildings. Quite an experience walking up this fascinating street. Not only the Gaudi buildings, but also a wander into some the expensive shops too!
Very Impressive. One of the most exclusive location in Europe. Tens of designer shops and a number of upscale malls. Very wide street with many nice restaurants with terraces and cafes.
Shoppers Delight. Anything and everything you desire is on this street. Channel, Cartier, Gucci, you name it. Stores for every size wallet. Let's not forget the best Zara's I have ever seen.

High street wide avenue. All major shops can be found on this long and wide avenue in the very center of Barcelona. you can reach it by underground train or bus! right before the El corte Inglès department store you will find a busy bar/inn called Navarra where you can enjoy an apéritif or lunch!
Shopping. If you want to window shop, or shop for real, this is one the places to do it in Barcelona. There are no shortages of cafes, bars and restaurants either.

Felt like being in Paris or NYC. Although this is Spain, when you walk around, it has a very metropolitan feel because of the wide streets, and the name-brand shops that are scattered throughout (LV, Gucci, etc). If you are in the area, then you should try and visit the Block of Discord. Some fascinating architecture to see.

Lovely Boulevard in the middle of the city. Our one week rental apartment was on Passeig de Gracia right beside the water fountain. It is an amazing street to walk any time of the day or night. It takes on different personalities depending on the time of day. 2 of Gaudi's masterpieces were right up the street. Also picked up the hop on/hop off bus on this street.
love it. Passeig de gracia its to just watch the world goes bywhile seat outside the cafes love the Cristobal Colon statue,acroos in the beautiful marina and the bridge for pedestrians
Great place. Lots of good restaurants, many shops, close to rambla de catalunya which has more restaurants and specialist food shops.

fashion avenue. we stayed in the Hotel Sixty Two on this beautiful street. The shopping is unmatched and the restaurants nearby are excellent. A great place to walk around and see the beautiful people

A must to complete the Barcelona experience!. A buzzy and happening street with great shops, tapas bars and of course a couple of stunning Gaudi buildings to remind you that you are in Barcelona. Large flagship stores of Zara and Mango and also Cortes Ingles down the road..one doesn't have to go anywhere else for shopping.
Great Shopping... and Gaudi. People watch, peek into the expensive boutiques, wander down the road and see another of Gaudi's works. So much to see here!
Old part of city with great charm. This is where the locals congregate (and many live) - lots of beautiful old squares; cheap restaurants; unusual shops

basic tourist trap!. I thought this was going to be some amazing stroll down a famous road in Barcelona. Turns out it's just one long shopping street with plenty of tourist stuff to buy!! Don't bother unless your into shopping. Plenty of other stuff to do.

Feels Very French. Be sure to take an hour or more and walk this street. Best to walk at night as it comes to life with the stunning street lights and restaurants in motion. Bring a tripod for night photography. The Gaudi surprises are easy to pick out as are the Art Nuevo examples. Head off shopping after your walk..

Great street to get the overall feel of Barcelona. This street is full of high end shops, great for seeing all the fashions. There are plenty of restaurants with outdoor seating for relaxing and taking in the sights while enjoying a glass of cava. Gaudi's building are situated along this passaig so the architectural aspect is amazing.

don't leave without taking a walk in this street. There are two Gaudí buildings in this street and there are also many other beautiful and strange buildings whose architects tried to match the level. There are also a few beautiful shops.
Wander down the side streets. Centrally located, I walked up one side and down the other, then the next day went down the side streets too! Interesting shops and arcades.

Nice way to spend an afternoon!. If you get off at Gracia metro station and take a walk down via augusta and then towards passeig de gracia it is possible to enjoy a number of Gaudi attractions including Casa Batllo and Casa Mila.

Nice walk.. Nice to walk around, lots of nice shops and restaurants. Though I would highly recommend getting a moped to move around (parking is a breeze). Definitely go check out Casa Batllo while you're around.
The best safe street. Like in Champs Elisee in Paris, In Paseig de Gracia we can enjoy all time, day and night, spend a very good time. Excelent!
Passeig de Gracia. A nice stroll down this avenue checking out the archtecture and the shops. The metro stop is near the major sights to see.

Get your wallet out. If you have a bottomless wallet this is the street for you. All the designer stores are here Chanel,Gucci,Prada,Loius Vitton etc. the architecture is stunning with Gaudi masterpieces. the tour buses go down and stop here.
Evening Visit. Last night we went to see the spectacular light and music show at the Gaudi e museum what a spectacular event.
Expensive shops. This street is a main avenue that has lots of pricey shops and tapas places. Nice for a stroll to window shop and perhaps have a drink in one of the outdoor cafe tables.
Shopping. Walk along Passeig de Gracia and you can combine sightseeing and shopping. You can also find some nice places to have a coffee or lunch while you are in the center of everything

Incredible architecture. If you're into architecture, spend some leisurely time here. Interesting stores and great restaurants as well. If you have the time, branch off onto some of the side streets, which also have interesting buildings. We enjoyed this street much more than Las Ramblas. If you are vegetarian, there's a great, reasonable buffet called the Granja Vegetariana.
Shopping, people and tapas. Always something to see and do, along with some of the Gaudi architecture. If you plan on dining don't be in a rush because the pace of service is slow!

Passeig de Gracia. Our accommodation was on Passeig de Gracia. It is an amazing Boulevard, the most gorgeous place to stay....Apartment Sixty Four, was outstanding both in its location as well as it welcoming, premium hospitality. From our balcony we could see Casa Battlo, the 'life' on this street was at our fingertips. It is at the top of Las Ramblas, so again, geographically Passeif de Gracia is perfectly situated.

Great atmosphere. Loved strolling up and down the Passeig de Gracia and the whole Gracis area. Wish I could afford to buy in some of the designer shops (€200 for a very ordinary pair of flip flops) but it doesn't stop you looking, does it?

World class shopping. But if you live in other major cities, the shopping is not terribly unique (no boutiques, for instance)
But the wide sidewalks, trees and cafes make for world class people watching.
Take a Walk. Take a walk along this street lines with buildings of unique and fantastic architecture and design. Waling the length of the street will take at least half an hour, so wear good shoes.
5 star shopping. If you want a 5th avenue in Barcelona go here. All brands are visible. Also beautiful architecture. A delightful walk!

long walk. found ourselves on Passeig de Gracia after a dissapointing visit to the John Lennon plaza. We walked right down to the picasso museum from here. Long walk and lots of window shopping along the way. Nothing amazing.
passeig de gracia. beautiful boulevard to stroll down. you pass the Gaudi masterpeace,s of Casa Mila and Casa Batllo all the was down to Placa De Catalyuna. even more impressive at night.

hellasview. All the main stores / desingers and luxury stores are located in Passeig de Gracia.Very easy to walk , large and very clean pavements. I also liked the street lights designed by Gaudi and the coffe places around with good and value for money coffe and cakes

Barcelona's Fifth Avenue, Spanish Styhle. There is a wealth of shops and stores in this area - quite spectacular and a lot of them are Spanish. Make sure to visit El Court Ingles, which is sort of like Marks and Spencer, complete with a grocery store in the basement. You will see lots of high end boutiques and brands, but Spain's brands, such as Camper, and Mango are in the area as well. And it's just one turn onto Las Ramblas. There is also a huge square with fountains where the Barcelona Tourism offices are, where you can get Metro and tour tickets.

Exclusive shops. Nice for window shopping! Wide pavements and interesting buildings with plenty of pavement cafes to watch the world go round. Most shops are luxury goods but worth the walk for the architecture.

Lively. We stayed in a B&B just off Passeig de Gracia, so ended up walking up and down very often. A lot of the top boutiques are located here as are some interesting buildings by Gaudi like the Pedrera

Energy required for this 'ramble'.. A great wide wonderful street but there are so many places to see along the way so that by the time you get to Casa Mila, you are exhausted. The Metro station is huge ... felt like we were walking for miles to find our train.

Brilliant for a holiday shopping session and walk. The clothing boutiques and shops along the long Passeig de Gracia are wonderful for an afternoon of shopping. Loads of shoe shops to help keep you busy too. The top end was the most spectacular. The street is full of beautiful buildings and on one of the corners is the Padrera, a famous building by Gaudi.
This is 5th avenue and Rodeo Drive. If you like to buy things to show the world you can and have more Euros than sense, this is the place for you.

The Best is here!. Unless you're staying at W Hotel by the Water, I recommend staying here. You're steps away from the Gothic Quarter but are right in the middle of the best Food and Shopping. Think 5th Avenue meets Europe. Elegant boutiques and fine dining establishments line the street.

Big name shopping. We wanted (and found) the Apple Store here, but it seemed all the big names had a presence in the Passeig and streets leading off. Beautiful architecture complemented the window displays (remember to look upwards as well to capture carvings and detail).The Metro and RENFE stations are HUGE and one can easily get lost and/or footsore. Hint:allow plenty of time for interchange.
Dream of lottery win. Lovely walk dreaming of going in the stores Gucci, Jimmy Choo, D and G ,Chanel etc.Nice to sit for coffee and people watch
