Nothing special. it's like a mix of corso sempione and corso buenos aires in Milan,Italy.if You miss it,You don't miss anything special

Attractive neighborhood.. Passeig de Gracia is a spacious, pretty boulevard littered with plenty of Gaudi attractions, restaurants, cafes, retail stores, swanky boutiques, hotels and more. Spend no more than two hour strolling through before proceeding to other attractions. If you enjoy people watching, this might not the best place to do so.
Wonderful shopping. Amazing shops and cafes and great for people watching. I especially enjoyed shopping in te Camper shop and a bar called Navarra.
A walking experience. It was truly enjoyable to walk de Gracia in the evening before dinner and grabbing a quick bite/coffee and lazing around. Enjoyable and relaxing.
Not just great shops. Besides the shopping the Passeig de Gracia has great buildings and lovely squares. Perhaps less well known than la Rambla but has as more to offer.
Everything is there.... This street has 4 main Gaudi houses, the bus to parc Guell (24), a metro stop, train to figueres (dali museum), and lots of shopping and restaurants

Great for shopping but have a large wallet.. I loved looking in the shops. Gucci, Cartier are all in this one street. Best shop for quirkiness is Vincon they sell everything from stationary to kitchens but it's all unusual stuff. Torres showcase wine bar is worth a visit. You could spend all day sampling the wines. Inside is a wine lovers sanctuary. Spend the morning shopping in this great street and the afternoon watching the shoppers from one of the many bars.
Lovely street. There are some fantastic shops, though expensive. It is also a great place to people watch. It is noisy, and busy, but also pretty.

Shopping. The stores are amazing, expensive but so worth it to visit. They are open late and very helpful. The street is lined up with all the stores you are already familiar with but show the latest fashions.

Fifth avenue in Barcelona. If you are interested in high end shopping this is the street for you. This avenue has everything from shopping to eating. It is also a great place to sit and people watch when you get a little tired of being a tourist. The people of Barcelona are a delight.

The real deal. Was a great place to walk and visit. We had the chance to due shopping while enjoying one of the most lively streets in Barcelona. Most of the world known brands are in Passeig de Gràcia, including the new Apple Store.

Beautiful architecture and window shopping. Much to explore here--loved the architecture, especially the stretch of modernist houses. Each one is different from the one next to it. The details are amazing. I also enjoyed window shopping here, so many fancy designers in close proximity (I wish I could actually afford to shop here, maybe in the future...) There was a Ferrari store with a lifesize cutout of Fernando Alonzo, we are huge fans, so this made a fun photo op.

Incredible Shops. The Barceloneans have style and the window displays are definitely influenced by the modernistic roots. Also shops with good prices right beside the most elegant and expensive shops in the world.

Great Window Shopping. Great street / area to walk around. You can tell that this is a very nice neighborhood. Great window shoppping and architecture. They also have a really cute food / pastry shop in the area called Mauri. Great chocolates. If you walk around this area it's a great time to see the famous La Pedrera (cas mila ) and Casa Batllo Gaudi attractions as they are all here within minutes of each other.
Most beautiful street in the world.. Arguably the nicest street to walk in the world. The beautiful architecture, great shopping and fine dining found on this street is unparalleled in my opinion.

Enjoy a stroll up this street. Less busy and brash than Las Ramblas - this street has some very exclusive shops on it, some fantastic architecture ( Casa Batllo, La Pedrera) along it and some pleasant bars / cafes ( and not all that expensive either given the location.) Also if you go to the streets running parallel to it there are even more reasonable places to eat and drink. All of the surrounding streets are worth a wander.

long street of overpriced stores. If you are a shopper go for it otherwise skip it. I do not shop in those stores at home why would I there ... and you will be on it at some point anyway since 2 of the Gaudi houses are there!

A great stroll. After a visit to Guell Park, ride the Metro to Diagonal stop, and emerge for a stroll along this beautiful avenue. La Pedrera, Casa Batlio, Casa Amatller, Casa Lleo Morera appear as you proceed downhill toward Placa Catalunya. Beautifully detailed classical buildings house premium shopping.

wonderful shopping and historic area. very vibrant area of the city. There is so much to see and do. I loved all of the architecture. It was a bit crowded, but I did not mind as the whole experience is a feast for the eyes.

Barcelona's Rodeo Drive and Champs Elysee Rolled Into One. Even if you are not into buying and wearing Designer Labels, you still must walk along the Passeig de Gracia....for the experience and some great architectural gems. It's a wonderful place to sit and have a drink and watch the people go by. Lots of restaurants with tables on the sidewalks...and they don't all serve the same tapas, etc....so read the menus. There's a really fabulous department store to check out with designer duds at more reasonable prices, too.....Ingles de Cortes. And the Zara store is one of the largest I have seen anywhere, with a gigantic selection of fun and trendy clothes. There are a couple of famous Gaudi buildings as well....and the Guell turns into a nightclub at night, with a cover charge. We passed on it this time, but I think it would be a fun way to see it at night. This street is crazy busy all day and night.

Expensive shopping street. All the designers on this street you can think of, Gucci, Louis Vuitton, Hermes, Chanel etc. However, no Prada yet! Store opening soon and it is only available in one department store, Corte de Ingles in Maria Cristina. I did not bother to check it out so this is information given to me by one sales assistant in another Corte de Ingles. They also have Tumi, Rolex, Tiffany & Co. The Bus Turistic (city sightseeing bus) stops on that street as Casa Mila (La Pedrera), one of Gaudi's works is at the top of the street.
The Champs Elysees of Barcelona. Although much smaller, it is a nice street to walk in and shop if you are into designers and labels. Lots of old beautiful buildings and expensive hotels
nice area. just generally a nice part of town and some good music bars however as i am a guitarist myself i was a bit dismayed that it was all bash, bash, bash and no finger picking.

The Champs Elysee of Barca. we saw the police chasing refugees, one got hit by a car. That was not the most enjoyable experience what with two young teenage girls in tow. Still it is THE place for those global lables like Louis Vuitton if you are not sick of it by now, you will be when you have finished roaming this street...
very nice and posh. I loved shopping here. I'm a die hard designer fan so I absolutely loved shopping. it is a posh area, even the Mcdonalds is posh i tell you.
Ramblas. This could be also called a rambla. Its one street full of stores, its a nice area to see people, tourists have a cup of coffee and do your shoppings.
So elegant. Our hotel was just there and we had the opportunity to walk by the Passeig de Gracia, a wonderful area to enjoy walking and shopping.

Main street for architecture lovers. This street has all the major houses you see on the post cards and books about Madrid (La pedrera, casa batllo, etc.), as well as some small shopping areas. Definitely worth walking through it!
Shopping galore. Great area for high end shopping and people watching. Nice cafes along the street to sit have a coffee and relax.
High end area. This is the part of town that if you are looking for the high end shops and places to eat you should go. It is very nice and exploring the area is always fun.

Shopping, Gaudi and wine. One.main shopping streets and also the street of Gaudi architecture. Many very expensive brands have they shops on this street. I liked the Gaudi buildings (3) and would have liked to go in, but the queues were too long (and also prices quite high). But they are worth seeing from outside. Torres winebar is worth visiting. A very good selections of wines to taste in the bar or to buy by bottle. A nice stret to have a lazy walk and have a look around.

Stroll the Passeig de Gracia. I am not a shopper so that will explain the rating. If you like designer and brand names this is one of the streets to shop. The architecture all around is great, you are in Barcelona after all. Not many restaurants on the main drag.

Like it here. Everytime I go to Barcelona, I start my visit here, this long avenue has a great atmosphere.Whether you are visiting as a tourist or want to do some shopping, there is something for everyone, as you will find so many shops here, but also a unique architecture and Gaudi's houses.
Urban cool. This street is the rival of any high-end urban environment. From art to dining to retail to sight-seeing, it is all here. Wear comfortable shoes and take it all in.
Shopping as many as you can. On passeig de Gracia you can find al sorts of shops. The designershops ( D&G, Chanel,.. ) the mainstream shops ( Zara, Mango,.. ) and i'm sure a lot of local shops to.
Famous. Highly indispensable location for visitors to Barcelona. Extremely busy and central, lots and lots of shops
Luxury Passeig de Gracia. You can not miss this. It is a famous street for shopping and nice for window shopping. Not for the average tourist, Louis Vuitton and that kind of stuff.
You want it, they got it. If you're looking for different items made in Spain, its there. Some expensive, Some reasonable. Get your gelato here. A great place to walk and people watch.

Nice area. Stroll amid these buildings, take a glass of wine - relax
Central Barcelona - mainline trains and underground metro network have a sub street level station
rodao drive of barcelona. the stores were great if you have lots of money to spend, prada, dior, burberry and so many more love to look
Beautiful and clean. Enjoyed it, very modern with high end shop (although we don't shop there it's nice to see) and great restaurants. Definitely worth a visit.
shopping. The best and most expensive stores found in the city are seen onthis block. It is very easy to travel to other areas from here as well. It is well lite and nice to walk in the evening.

Shopping heaven. We have been enjoying looking in the clothes shops, perfume shops and book shops along this street. You can stop to have a coffee to relax and recharge along the street. The buildings are also amazing. If you love shopping then be sure to go shopping along passeig de Gracia.

Shopping Nirvana for Luxury Brands. If you want Prada in Barcelona this is your street. Note that very few of the shops are actually local designers, most of them are worldwide name brands. Prices range from expensive to ridiculously expensive. Luxury goods only, but the architecture, scenery and beautiful people to watch are worth a stroll!

Fabulous!. A great shopping boulevard with top drawer shops and great resturants lined up forever. We spent a lot of time on this street both shopping and eating. It is beautiful, filled with life and people. Go there.....
A feast for the eyes. Take Worth Avenue, Fifth Avenue and Rodeo Drive, put them together and you have Passeig de Gracia...Add some Five star hotels and you have Barcelona, lol

best street shopping in barcelona. high end and medium end brands are all available on this street,not to mention loads of tappas restaurants.very busy in the week until 5pm.great to sit and just chill and watch the passer byes.lots of desigual and zara stores on this street

Look up as you walk along this street. Nice place to mix architecture, culture, fashion and food. I stayed on this street and was blessed with the availability to everything. Be sure to explore the back streets and Carveries for some cold Spanish beer.

Bling, bling!. Take your time and amble along the Passeig taking in the Gaudi buildings and all the amazing shops. Don't be tempted to go in - you really can't afford it but, wow, what an afternoon stroll! try the Cafe Viennese in the hotel Casa Fuster along the way for a touch of 'Vicky, Christina Barcelona' style.

Don't miss it and go early. We went here just to catch the tourist bus without realizing how beautiful it was with its fountains and Romanesque statues. Lucky we took the time to enjoy it and take lots of pictures while we were there around 10:30am because when the bus returned us there later that evening it was absolutely mobbed with people, locals and tourists alike. Go early to get the best shots!
posh shopping area. lots of high end shops and abounds with eateries. You will also e able to appreciate all the buildings in this area
Margaret. Tree lined, packed with shops from designer to souvenir.Busy and full of atmosphere - great.Many many restaurants and eateries.
impressive street. The Casa Batllo is located on this important street. Walk along and imagine the place full of wealthy merchants houses in the C19th.
Nice for a look. Amazing street just to sit and watch the world go by, from a pavement cafe. Gaudi works are everywhere. Plenty of designer shops.
Shoppers paradise.. A pleasant stroll up and down the wide shopping street that is Passeig de Gracia. All the big names you could wish for.

beautiful wide shopping street. designer shops mixed with 2 beautiful Gaudi buildings. Going up the street brings you to Gracia area which is much less touristy and so very good, down the street brings you to the Gothis quarter and the waterfront.
Ideal for shopping. Ideal for shopping, especially for lovers of exquisite brands! There is a great opportunity to combine shopping with a tour of the magnificent buildings of Gaudi

Barcelona's Swank. Passeig on both sides is large, upscale and home to every important designer store A to Z. There are many cafes and restaurants to stop and relax or people watch.It is a convenient avenue with close access to major metro stations (Passeig de Gracia and Diagonal). Compared to La Rambla which is located parallel one block away, Passeig is busy with great transportation and interesting architecture.

Great Shopping and great architecture!. If you like shopping, just plan to spend a week on this street. Fabulous. And in between spending, take a look up at some of the most uniqui buildings in the world.

Great shopping street. The Passeig de Gracia starts at Plaça Catalunya and continues up to the Avinguda Diagonal. It is home to the famous Casa Batllo and La Padrera buildings as well as branches of most of upmarket stores for clothing, jewellery and shoes interspersed with restaurants. It compares with Bond Street in London and is one of the main arteries of the Eixample district. Don't miss the Rambla Catalunya that runs parallel to Passeig de Gracia one block west. A street with a distinct village atmosphere with exclusive shops which you can access through the Bulevard Rosa shopping centre; distincly different to the other famous Rambla that runs south from Plaça Catalunya to the waterfront.

Perfect for shopping and people watching. A very comfortable place to stroll, view architecture, shop in the many shops (designer and regular stuff like H&M), sit at a cafe, or just sit at a public bench. I'm pretty sure the people are better dressed and possibly better looking on this street. Called the Rodeo Drive of Barcelona. What's not to like?

upscale area. if you need to be located in the nicest area, this would be it. but I have to say it is a large sprawling city and maybe not really as interesting as other areas. every city has an upscale area, and most of these shops can be found in them all.
Fancy. The fifth avenue of Barcelona a nice walk to see all the fancy stores . seems to always be a busy street and there are not many benches to sit on
Trendy location. The area is surrounded by blocks of designer stores, Tappas and tour attractions. Loved it. There was nothing not to like except the temperature of 90 degrees and sticky.

Barcelona's Bond Street. If you don't want to spend your euros, leave them in the hotel. This elegant, tree-lined boulevard is lined with designer shops guaranteed to have your credit card flying out of your wallet like iron filings to a magnet. And if that's not enough, it is also the site of the stunning La Pedrera, arguably Gaudi's most beautiful building.

Tourist Shopping Heaven. Now this feels like 5th Ave in New York or Champ E'Lysees although it might not be as high end. There are tons of shops, restaurants, cafes and Gaudi-designed houses such as Casa Batllo on this major street. You should go up and down just to do some shopping and admire their architecture.

Great shopping street!. Reviewing this street only because our hostel (Equity Point, which I highly recommend) was on Passeig de Gracia. I would equate it to Fifth Avenue in NYC, the street is filled with designer stores along with high street ones as well, like Zara and H&M. Casa Batllo is also on this street, which I recommend visiting!

5th Avenue. This is just like 5th Avenue with one building designed by Gaudi and another right next to it designed by another architect of Gaudi's time. It was meant to be a competition of who had a better design. Other then that, if you have the money you can shop there or at least window shop like we did.

the elitist place for shopping in barcelona. best street in barcelona... you can find everything you need (hotels, shops, restaurants, boutiques, site seeing)
most of boutiques located in Passeig de gracia like LV, YSL, Prada, Bottega, Armani herms and many many more
you can also find great hotels like Mandarin, suites avenue, majestic and omm hotels.

Nice, but its just a street.. This is average, unless you love high end brands, and I don't really. It had nice architecture along the way, but so do most streets in Barcelona. I only walked in this area on the way to somewhere else, so maybe its just not for me.
Good for people watching. Very busy, very touristy, but great for people watching and getting a feel for the city. Walk down the middle when you can.

Shopping, Shopping, Shopping. Visiting Barcleona has to involve a walk down the passeig de gracia. Definitely more for the women, but shopping always is. Decent Nike and Adidas outlet and maybe the odd one or two boutiques for men, all depends what you want. If into the D&G s of the world the this the street to visit.Some decent cafes and restaurants on this street, but as it is location, location, location, your paying the costs for such, when you can get just as good food and coffees just off this street. Food and drink wise it is more tourist than local, meaning frozen foods etc.. There is the odd authentic Spanish restaurant on this road.Shopping and sitting back with an overpriced coffee watching the world go by explains this road.

Shopping!. If you love Chanel, Louis Vuitton, Bulgari and Gucci, this street is for you... I found the Stella McCartney store and loved browsing in this iconic fashion house. I thought I would be intimidated but felt totally comfortable, as the sales representatives were most cordial.

Great Street. We were staying in a hotel right on Passeig de Gracis. This street has loads of shops , bars and restaurants as well as two important Gaudi buildings , Casa Batllo and Casa Milla. At one end you have the Placa De Catalunya with it's impressive fountains and entrance to La Ramblas. As well as the main chain stores there are also little shops especially off the side streets. Close by Casa Batllo there is small group of shops in a mini-mall with an entrance on to Passeig de Gracia.It would be possible to spend the whole day on this street eating ,shopping and sight seeing!
High End shopping and restos. Great for simply walking...a large commercial street that showcases high end boutiques, connecting to Place Catalunya.

great feel of the city. great walk to feel the life of the city and great for shopping.
This street introduces you to classy restaurants and also to fast food vendors.
very lively

SHOPPING!. Excellent and expensive shopping street with sites to see. Plan on breaking your pocket book here as there is just about anything you could want. If you want cheaper shopping, go South of Plaza Catalunya.

Nothing like this in London. Faboulous!. I'm a londoner, born and bred and I love my city. I've been to all the great shopping streets in central London and elsewhere, but in my honest opinion this beats everything we have to offer in terms of the total package - great shops, amazing architecture and plenty of places to stop and eat, Passeig de Gracia has it all. You'll see architectural masterpieces from the likes of Gaudi and be tempted to spend your money in the many shops and restaurants. Then spend the evening at Placa (near La Rambla), take pictures, enjoy the atmosphere.
Great clothes shopping. Here you will find something for every budget (H&M and Mango, to Louis Vuitton!). Good variety of tapas bars and cafes.

I f you love walking tours. If you love walking and discovering the essence of cities you must walk here there many of Gaudis buildings on this routeit has all types of shopping available and cafes and taps bars to eat and people watchbring your credit card as there are too many places to spend your money
lots of shopping. if you love expensive shopping this is the place to do it! bring your credit cards and comfy shoes! lots of eaterys nearby aswell

Bring your credit card. This is a nice stroll, but the upscale shops are mighty tempting! Go to shop and people-watch, not to sightsee. The shops do not cater to the budget-conscious - it's kind of the Rodeo Drive of Barcelona.

Expensive but worth it!. A beautiful shopping district that boasts unbelieveable architecture and is the most expensive shopping street in Barcelona! The street is extremely long and close to Las Ramblas so there are often plenty of street performers and entertainers! The street is lined with shops like Gucci, Mcgreggors, Levi's, Guess, Zara, Swarovski, etc so bring a chunky wallet! For those who want a less expensive shopping trip however there are shops like H&M, Bershka, Oysho, Pull and Bear, Topshop etc and many beautiful little boutique stores if you wander down towards las ramblas!

Best choice you ever made to come to Barcelona. Walking among people ( I can't recall to visit a city with so many young people like Barcelona)surrounded by beautiful architecture , tapas bars,lovely beach...best choice .

Gaudi House. Loved this magical street with its wonderful buildings. Difficult to walk very far without seeing something of interest. We walked the length of Passage de Gracia stopping every now and again to have a drink in one of the many pavement bars.

Time to Shop. If money is no issue this would be the perfect street.
Lined with some fabulous designer and high street brands to browse through.
The architecture of the street makes the whole experience enjoyable for all

Best residential place to spend a holiday. I spent 12 days in barcelona. The apartment was based in Passeig de Gracia and what a first class choice that was. Clean beach, huge pavements to walk or cycle and a big shopping mall nearby.

Good mix of shops and bars. Great area to walk along - we were staying on the Passeig de Gracia, and the mix of shops, bars and restaurants was perfect. not just the upmarket shops like Chanel, Hermes etc (although they were all there) but younger shops (Guess, DeSigual) and cheaper ones (Mango, Zara) ensured there was something for everyone.... as did the bars and restaurants.
Shopping. If you want to shop and do not have a lot of time, this is it! It is the 'Champs Elysée' of Barcelona, but more friendly to take a walk.

Can't Go Wrong. Wear your best walking shoes, bring your wallet and your camera. The Passeig de Gracia has it all. You can see Casa Batllo and La Pedrera from the street - among other great architecture - and the shops are to die for. Your eyes will get tired just looking in the windows. Don't miss the Loewe shop, home to some of Spain's best leather goods.And if your wallet just can't take it, go down to the foot at the Placa Catalunya and explore El Corte Ingles. They have everything under one roof. And the Placa isn't a bad place to hang out either.

A good stroll. It looks a lot and reminds you of the Champs de Elysees in Paris or Michigan Ave in Chicago. But what makes it different is the architecture be it the Antoni Tapies Foundation bldg, Casa Batlo or La Pedrera. They

Stunning, grand, tree lined boulevard. Must see.. Every tourist who comes to Barcelona must take a walk along Passeig de Gracia. There are the shops and busy sidewalk restaurant terraces. More impressive are buildings you'll see designed by Gaudi, the grandeur and beauty of this wide boulevard...from the fountains, trees, tiled benches and beautiful lampposts. It's a nice walk from Plaza Cataluña to the barrio of Gracia.
Shopping and views. The Passeig is lined with beautiful buildings (some from Gaudi) and offers a great shopping experience. A true must!

Enjoyable. We got off the train and headed to Passeig de Garcia (actually more by accident) - got a tourist map and figured out where we were -loved the Gaudi architechure, nice place to stroll, window shop and eat...

Wide, pleasant, and well located. This Paseo makes a great stroll, showcases great attractions, good shops, some good bars for tapas or snacks, very wide pedestrian space, nicely flat, and good interesting buildings and lamp posts of style. Very near by, at surrounding streets you can find yet more places tom visit a some good restaurants. The street also has very nice hotels.

Nice afternoon walk. The street is nice to walk around, it is right up from Placa Catalinya. For me the street was mostly interesting as Casa Battlo and Casa Milo are located there, so it is definitely worth the walk. It is also much less crowded then Las Ramblas for example.
Walk along Passeig de Garcia. Walk along Passeig de Garcia and shop/windowshop and look at the architecture! It's practically impossible to miss Gaudis' buildings which are really something!
great shopping. wife went ballistic ,, bustle, shops, great smells and tattoo'd chicittas,,,lovely time,, have some good walking shoe's or trainers , ya feet take a serious beating in barce..

The most beautiful buildings in town. This is THE street in Barcelona, with the most beautiful buildings in town, not only by Gaudì (Casa Batllò and Casa Milà are here) but also by other Modernist architects. To better understand the architecture of this period, you can visit the "Centre for Modernism" in P. de Gracia 41. This is also the street of fashion with all the major Italian and international brands having luxury boutiques here!

Eyes wide open. Well, this street is very close to las Ramblas, and has that Great Gaudi architecture. Prepared to keep your eyes wide open and just stand still and LOOK at THAT! wow factor with curves and design and color, Rod iron with !!! I thought entrance to building was high at 20 Euros..so I didn't go in, sorry I didn't..Loved this street. Do it

Gorgeous buildings. Walking down this street gives you a view of the glorious times that Barcelona has seen and continues to enjoy. Well worth a stroll if you like to look at buildings or shop in very high end stores.

Great shopping, amazing architecture. You can walk this street up and down a million times and not get tired. For a start, shopping is great: there is no big brand missing and sales in Barcelona are serious. But don't forget to look at the architecture on both sides, and especially on the upper part of the street before the shops start. Some of the best examples of early 20th century architecture are here.
best shopping street in Europe.. Forget Bond street in London, the glamorous street has it all and with the current recession in Spain , the prices are cheap.

nice for a walk, not for shopping. It is a good place for a lazy walk. But not that wonderful for shopping as I heard before coming to Barcelona. There are mostly international brands which you can find in any other european city. I was hoping for spanish clothes and shoes in particular, but I think this is not the best place for this.

World class street.. I am a native new yorker who could not stop gawking at the beauty and elegance of this street. It is in a class by itself. You must sit on a bench for a rest, have a drink and tapas, and dine on this street. with a taste of gelato or yogurt to top ot all off. You can shop too, if you can afford it. All the top designers are located on the ave.

Wonderful street to stroll and spend the day. I am a seasoned traveler but this was my first visit to Barcelona...Passeig de Gracia could quite possibly be my favorite street in the world!!! Exceptional shopping for all budgets (H&M, Addidas, Cartier, Louis Vuitton, Chanel, Gucci, etc), wonderful cafes and wine bars and phenomenal atmosphere!!!! This street is exceptionally wide (think 3x the width of an American sidewalk), made of paver stones, lined with palm trees!! Not much car traffic as most are walking or biking. Wonderful way to spend the day or stay in one of the hotels on this street!!

Barcelona's Best. It's the 5th Avenue of Barcelona. Lined with fancy shops, great for window shopping, and beautiful architecture. The are also Gaudì buildings. Don't forget to look down, even the pavement is photo-worthy!

shopping and people watching. This is the heart-beat of the city. Its so cool to walk, look, watch, shop... the atmosphere is alive... all day and night. I love this street. in fact it has become the best street in Barcelona to me.

Just another expensive shopping street. This is just another street filled with recognizable american shops. We were there as the new Apple store opened, and it was the talk of the town. this is a typical shop here, with all the stores you would find on the best shopping streets in any city. The difference here in Barcelona is that the sidewalks are filled with dirty kids hanging out all over the place. Compared to Madrid, Barcelona is a huge letdown. While Madrid is cosmopolitan, Barcelona is honkytonk in my opinion. Madrid is clean and beautiful and quiet, while Barcelona is dirty, loud and cheap looking (not cheap in reality though).

Shop, eat, have fun. An amazing street with high-end and not so much stores. If you are tired, no worries - just stop at one of oh-so-many restaurants or coffee places and take a short break, then go on shopping or simply strolling along this amazing street. Barcelona is one of my favourite cities and Passeig de Gracia is one of the must see streets if you are in Barcelona. High-end stores with very reasonably priced goods and amazing customer service.
great! reccommend the bus tours!. Liked the history and attraction point. Connecting road between 2 cities with lots to see and lots of history. Lovely views and great opportunity for photos.

Nice shopping street. A very a-typical Spanish street, full of European designers (Gucci, Guess, Louis vuitton etc). Quite expensive but fun to walk down. If you walk towards the fountains there is a shopping centre which sells slightly cheaper goods.

Shopping in nice surroundings. The street has many of the expected high end brands in a nice relaxed surrounding. The staff are nice and friendly in most stores. I would especially like to recommend the new Dirk Bikkembergs store on Passeig de Gracia 99.

Shopping and Guadi Buildings. This has got to be the best shopping street in Barcelona. I loved it! As you walk along there are many restaurants and bars. Even the local MacDonald's looked smart. Our hotel was around the corner from here so it was a perfect place to have a quick dinner or breakfast.
Shoppers paradise. Great shopping and atmosphere! You can spend few hours gallivanting!It’s a long walk but worth it. We spent a good 6 hours without realising.
So many shops!. Wonderful street filled with all the designer shops you can think of, well worth it just to look at. Gaudi Mila Casa also on this street.

Nice to walk around, so some shoping. Tapa tapa restaurant is good
Beware of your belonings when walking or seating anywhere for food or drinks

Go for a stroll.... If you want to see some of Barcelona's culture go for a stroll at Passeig de Gracia. You will find lots of shopping (for all budgets) and plenty of food options too... It's lively and pleasant, we walked most of it without even noticing time passing by.
A great place to go shopping!. If you like to shop then you are at the right place at the Passeig de Gracia. Here you will find many shops of a lot of cool brands.
Beautiful Avenue. Many restaurants with yummy food, tapas, beer and wine. Great for shoping, Loewe, Zara, Mango, and other local shops
Shop, Shop, Shop. What a fun street! Lots of namebrand stores.....lively, fun. Must at least walk down it. My favorite was the Ferrari store.
Nice stroll. Lovely wide boulevard with beautiful buildings, lots of designer shops ,but if coming from London it's not as impressive as Bond st or Sloane Ave.
Shopping central. Best place in Barcelona for brand shopping. Lovely, grand boulevard with designer boutiques, hotels and restaurants. A must for a luxury experience.
We spent a lot. We saved a ton of money on things that cost much more in the UK. Solid values on cool clothing. Great food. Worth a half day and certainly lunch. Skip ramblas, sucks.
Shopping, food and Gaudi. Walk this passage/street north to see many of Gaudi's notable buildings. High-end shopping (or window shopping) and places to eat along the way.

One of the most beautiful avenues in Europe. A beautiful, wide boulevard with lots of trees and wide sidewalks. People of all ages everywhere. The architecture of the buildings is beautiful and diverse, punctuated by startling and fun Modernista buildings, including La Podrera and the building on the Block of Discord. I don't frequent famous designer shops, but literally every one of them seems to have a shop on Passeig de Gracia between Placa Catalunya and Diagonal. We stayed in a very nice apartment hotel, Suites Avenues, at Passeig de Gracia, 83, so we had the opportunity to experience this wonderful avenue at all hours of the day and night.

A grand boulevard with the finest shopping anywhere!. This magnificent boulevard has every exclusive designer boutique (prices here were comparable to NY - no bargains), unique Spanish labels and dining al fresco for superb people watching.

Nice walk. We walked down this street on our way from La Sagrada Familia to Las Rambles. It was an amazing walk with so much fascinating and beautiful architecture and very expensive shops. Barcelona's Rodeo Drive.

A Gaudi on (almost) every corner. If you are into expensive shopping this is the place to go to. If not its still worth going to, just to see the outsides of the many buildings that Gaudi designed here.

Keep your credit card in your wallet. This is one long trip around the world's designer shops. Everything from Gucci to Jimmy Choo on one street. Thankfully there are a few places to stop for a refreshing drink along the way.
Hermoso lugar!. A must go in Barcelona the street is complete with the shops you have always dreamed and architecture is out of this world! Simply amazing!
location. Our accomodation was nearby,so we spent some time exploring this area,the shops,local markets and restaurants.A very good area.

Busy beautiful big street. Wow wow wow, what a beautiful street with the most beautiful stores. Streets are very clean with these amazing trees and buildings. It was very near our hotel and easy to find our way to all the other places to visit in Barcelona
Good shopping area. All the luxury shops you always dreamed of... at spanish prices... Especially with the current economical crisis, you can get good bargains.
unique. Architecture like nowhere else in the world, very unique details, a must see when visiting Barcelona

An idyllic stroll. Just as we had noticed with other streets of Barcelona, we were struck by the use of trees to create an idyllic atmosphere of rest and relaxation even among imposing architectural masterpieces and busy walkways. The umbrella covered tables with folk socialising over tapas, paellas and sangria, as tourists wended their way from fashion house to architectural site was a traveller's dream. Casa Battlo was right there and and La Pedrera was within walking distance. The neatly lined motorbikes and bicycles added to the European flavour. This is the area for designer stores - Gucci and Ferrari among many others. Even caught sight of a horse and buggy. Blissful!
Great atmosphere,shops,toursist attractions. It was great to see casa batilo and casa mila and loved the hustle and bustle of passeig de gracia great for people watching too.
Cool Shopping Mall. A superb shopping mall contains necessaries & accessories with low prices & discountsFood market are in the basement floorEnjoy !
Great shopping and arcutecture. I loved the shop here. You feel so grand walking around this part of town. Don't miss the Casa Batllo.

Beautiful street. This is large street with beautiful architecture and large amounts of shops and restaurants, it's very pleasurable to walk there after whole day spent in walking in other districts if you stayed in center.
here you can find the gaudi buildings. you'll find the famous gaudi buildings here and you'll find also fishop here, a great restaurant for lunch
Today was the last time I went there. It is a good place to see the "escaparates"of all the great names in commerce. All the big brands, in beautiful shops and buildings from the !800.

Nice shopping street. This was a great place to go shopping. There were alot of shops lined on each side of the street. Casa Batllo and Casa Mila were also on this street, so it was hitting 2 birds with 1 stone!
WONDERFUL BOULEVARD. Main shopping street with all the chic designers. Great cafes for tapas and people watching. Rich in European flavor.

Excellent for browsing and shopping. My favourite place along this shopping route is Caroline Herreras beautifully decorated boutique with the purple pool table on the floor for mens fashion. The area is good for shopping in less crowds than in Barrio Gotico, Born and Raval.

Shopping spree. This is the place to be if you are into shopping. All small and big brands can be conveniently found in this area. And of course in between your shopping sprees you do have ample choice of cafes and restaurants.

The 5th Avenue or Rodeo Drive of Barcelona. This is the most fashionable street in Barcelona. The buildings that line the wide street are the mansions of the Catalonian upper class...now turned into high end luxury shops, 5-star hotels, restaurants and the like. Both Casa Batllo and Casa Mila (La Pedrera) are located here. It is also the home of the who's who of the brand name goods and jewelry. For the short-term visitor, this is street with the main conveniences of many underground Metro stops and both the RED and BLUE Barcelona turistic busses stopping every 15 minutes or so at 2 stops on the street.
Great location!. We stayed at Majestic Hotel in this location. Walking distance to everywhere-La Ramblas and the Plaza de Catalunya. Great restaurants and beautiful shops.
Our favorite. It was quite close to the hotel and you just have to admire all different types of buildings, and of course Gaudí´s arcitecture...

Shop till you drop.... Yes its a big high end shopping bonanza with cafes ..for something a bit more quiet take a detour off the main strip..walk only a few roads over and there are some splendid restaurants..explore..walk..go down Mallorca and Valencia..lots of shops too..Eixample was my prefered area to Ramblas and all the port action with was full of tourists like me..LOL

High end shopping. The architecture along this boulevard is a drawing card. Great lampposts and benches. The stores are the same ones in all big cities. The shopping and dining are better one street over.

Shopper's paradise!. With or without a stack of money and/or credit cards this is a delight for shopping. Wide pavements, although sometimes not wide enough(!) and a range of shops from high end to high street. Buildings old and new including some of Barcelona's architectural gems from top to bottom. Something for everyone so if the husband, dad, boyfriend doesn't want to shop there will be other things they can do!

Barcelona's Avenue of Commerce & Culture. We knew Passeig de Gracia as a strip of high-end shopping venues and had not planned to spend much time along the walk. However, when we found ourselves needing to kill an hour or so before dinner reservations, we took in several blocks. The shopping is there, to be sure, as are a number of excellent restaurants and highly rated hotels. Nestled within them are "la manzana de la discordia", the masterpieces of Catalan modernist residential architecture from Gaudi, Puig, & Domenech i Montaner that must not be missed even if (like us) the shopping isn't an attraction. Finally, this is a great place for strolling and people watching off of Las Ramblas and Barri Gotic. We ventured down Passeig de Gracia early in the evening on a weekday, and many of the locals were out in the common areas taking a short walk, hitting the tapas bars for some wine and a quick bite, and enjoying some time with their children. For that and the architecture it was worth a solid rating for us--it is a can't miss if high fashion or fine dining from Barcelona will be part of your trip.

It felt like any high end shopping area. Very modern and chic. gaudi's 2 houses that he build are on this street. Ate at Mauri's outside dining that was very romantic. It was on a side street. Easy to get to by Metro

Shopping galore. This is the street to go to for upscale shopping. Every designer has a shop here. In the midst is the street of discord with homes designed by Gaudi and others. Lots of cafes to spend some time people watching

Barcelona's 5th Avenue. Charming, with a perfect blend of classic and modern architecture, and all major luxury brands have an establishment here. Yet it is not only for those with wealth in abundance: you will also find McDonald's and H&M outlets here, so it is nice for any budget size to get into the shopping mood. Note the nice public lighting, and the Gaudi works along this grand avenue. Perfect for ambling, window shopping, people-watching, and enjoying a leisurely easy going time, taking in a bit of Barceona's care-free atmosphere.

Shopping shopping shopping!. But not only. You can visit Gaudi's wonderful Casa Batllo, the perfume museum, Casa Mila (also Gaudi's) there are some nice places for tapas or paella but mostly SHOPING. If you are arriving from the Metro station Diagonal then watch the signs carefully because there are two exits (the other one is on the Rambla de Catalunya)
best walk. this street is good for walking, it's not crowded like la ramblas. there you can find international brands stores and good restaurants, but it's generally expensive street

stroll and people watch to your heart's content!. Spend a lazy day just popping in and out of luxury shops, then take time out for tapas or a coffee or ice cream and watch the people go by... a great way to just "be" in Barcelona.

Pretty street..pretty expensive. I used Passeig de Gracia as a landmark. You can get to many attractions down this street. It's a very pretty street with fountains and trees and pretty shops. The shops are VERY nice. I don't see many people doing leisurely shopping here. Palau Robert is here though and if there's no event, you can enter a side gate from Avenue Diagonal and come out onto Passeig de Gracia.
Shopping. If you are looking for designer shops, you find them here.

Passeig de Gracia - Gaudi and more. As with most of the streets within an hour or so walk of here, the architecture is breathtaking. Between a couple of Gaudi buildings (check these out - magnificent) and the more modern buildings, there is a multitude of beautifully designed, exquisitely finished shops. The wonderfully broad promenade is peppered with unique restaurants and food outlets, each providing an interesting take on the cuisine of the city and region. Equally the street can play host to a special occasion dinner or simply a pick-me-up breakfast after a night of partying, watching from the promenade as Barcelona goes about it's business. Also, the transport connections from here can get you anywhere in the city on the Underground, so it is an excellent jumping off point.

Architecture worth looking at. Loved the beautiful architecture in this large elegant avenue. Standing out are La Pedrera and Casa Batilo by Antonio Gaudi. It is also a major shopping street, especially top-end brands
Great shopping and amazing architecture!!!. A must go, while visiting Barcelona. You got everything there form great food, shops to amazing architecture !
Great street!. Great eats and shopping - def a must do when in town

Wonderful atmosphere and fantastic shopping !. This is the place to go to if you like to go shopping. Lots of shops such as all the designer brands (LV, Gucci, etc), Zara, Massimo Dutti, etc. Prices are a lot cheaper here in Spain especially the Spanish brands. There are also a lot of sightseeing to do here as there are interesting architecture and buildings such as Basa Batlio. Nice restaurants are also dotted along the streets and you can try nice Tapas in restaurants such as Divinus.

A shopping paradise in Barcelona.. Not really my cup of tea but I can understand how it draws people in every day and all year round.Typically a very touristy street leading to the barrio of gracia hence the name passeig de Gracia (Passage to Gracia).It's a beautifully constructed street with elegant lamp posts and a lovely fountain at the meeting point of another major road Gran Via.This street is where all the designer boutiques can be found such as Burberry, Tiffany's and Chanel to name a few. It also contains all the other well know retail stores such as Mango, H&M and Zara. It caters for all budgets but slightly more so for those that fancy spending a little more.There are also a nice range of book shops, bars, coffee shops and bars along this street as well as a Mcdonalds (quite a posh one at that).Worth a stroll along just for the atmosphere if nothing else. This is a very busy street and you will get caught up in crowds the closer you head toward Placa Catalunya. As always in Barcelona, keep an eye on your valuables.
worthwhile walk. So much to see as you walk along Gaudi's buildings are great and also the designer shops are interesting
Wonderful street to walk. I was walking down the street And has everything Antiques to new

Beauful neighbourhood. Really beautiful and clean neighbourhood in Barcelona. Beautiful wide streets. Walking distance to restaurants and artistic/cultural sites. A longer and slightly more expensive taxi ride from the airport than expected but also reachable by public transportation. Good access to Metro system.
Shopping paradise. Featuring some Spain's best fashion labels. A visit to Passeig de Gracia is a must for shopaholics.

It is a really nice boulevard. Amazing place to walk. you must do it during the day to visit all the nice shops and have a drink or a bocadillo in the different restaurants but also make sure to do the walk at night when Casa Battlo and la Pedrera are lit up, it is amazing.

Stroll along the Passieg de Gracia. Walk along the Passieg de Gracia where all of Barcelona's fine shops are located. You can continue walking down the street to where Passieg de Gracia joins Las Ramblas. Go to a restaurant, eat ice cream or go shopping!

Wander and immerse in Modernisme. From the sidewalk tiles to the streetlights, Passeig de Gracia provides a wonderful opportunity to see some of the most amazing Modernista architectural sites -- Gaudi's Casa Mila (La Pedrera) and Casa Mila (on the Block of Discord) along with Casa Amatller (by Cadafalch) and Casa Lleo Morer (by Muntaner - the same architect that designed the Catalan Concert Hall).

Great street for shopping or window shopping!. Very fashionable and expensive long street! Great for shopping and interesting architectural buildings.Look out for Casa Battlo, Casa Amattler, Casa Lleo Morera and the Predrera etc....

Shopping for Luxury Goods. This is the place to go for your dose of branded items, i.e. LV, Loewe, Chanel, Carolina Herrera etc. It is a nice street to stroll. Head south and you will end up at Placa de Catalunya.
Perfect for window shopping. There is a world first Loewe museum in the designer leather shop - serendipity to find it! The designer shops are perfect for strolling past and dipping into....
Shopng shopping shopping. Ideale per fare acquisti, ma con budget sostenuti.....
enjoyable. lovely walking about the streets the designer shops are pretty, the buildings are outstanding (including of course the gaudi places)

Shop, eat, enjoy. Shop, see Gaudi architecture, eat and drink.
Lather, rinse, repeat.
Nice buildings and cafes. Beautiful buildings, plenty of little pavement cafes but a very busy area.
Champs Elysees of Barcelona. Big name designers. You could be in any European city. Go one block south to Ramblas de Catalunya for more local high-end shopping, fewer crowds and cars
full of luxury shops & hotels. if you like hi-end shopping, that's the place you should go!!!

Amazing avenue. What can one say about this magnificent avenue? All the famous shops are there ,international or spanish designers ,so if you in a mood for shopping ,this is a perfect place. Also is a truly beautiful avenue full of trees and beautiful lamps.To make this place even more fantastic you have magnificent buildings ,like Gaudi beautiful Casa Batló and Casa Milá (La Pedrera ). Full of good restaurants and bars to have real meals or tapas,what else can one have in the same avenue?Superb ,one never gets tired of walking this avenue up and down.
Very busy avenue. Lots of cafes, shops and expensive boutiques. Food less expensive one block back.
The little 5th Av of Barcelona. This boulevard is the perfect place to see modernist architecture and the place were you will find Casa Mila and Casa Batllo, the 2 apartment block from Antoni Gaudi
Stroll and People Watch. Make sure you see all the Modernista homes and buidings. Great shopping and restaurants on and off main street.

Wonderful avenue to shop, eat, stoll & relax. Great Street for high end shopping and people watching! You can see Casa Mila and Casa Batllo just a few blocks from each other on this boulevard. There are many designer shops on both sides of the boulevard.Barcelona has a lot of beautiful public spaces and broad, shady avenues lined with stores and cafes that are great for strolling; having a drink or snack at an outdoor cafe, shop or people watch and Passeig de Gracia is all of that. When you come off of Plaza Catalunya, Passeig de Gracia starts. It has the most elegant and big brand stores in Barcelona, as well as fine eating establishments. We spent a great afternoon here!
Shopping Heaven. What's not to love - if you like shopping (and I mean designer) then this is the place to be :0)
Cosmopolitan. Grand avenue, where you can feel the pulse of the city and see two of it's most emblematic building: House Batllo and House Milá.Also where all the Couture stores are based.
Elegant street. Beautiful, chic, elegant street. Lots of shops, restaurants and bars. Gaudi house. So much to see, just have a leisurely stroll and enjoy.
Posh stores and amazing architecture :). A must in Barcelona...if you don't like architecture for sure you will be able to do some great shopping on this street :)

so alive!. loved this street, also my hotel was on the same street. Many shops, bars, restaurants to waste the time. Metro stations and tour bus stops widely available on this street as well. It never sleeps!

Center of Barcelona. We actually stayed right on this street and it was the perfect place to stay. IT was minutes from the Bari Gothic and shopping heaven for our teenagers. We felt safe walking anywhere in this area.
A fun walk. Upscale shops, works of Gaudi and other interesting architecture. Great people watching as well.
Fifth Ave meets Regents Street. Very wide boulevard, lots of top quality shops and some museums. Tourist bus stops here too.
No need to go hungry here. Plenty of good places to eat and drink, from cheapest tapas to fancy silver service. We liked Moncho's for fish, tapas, sangria and friendly service.
High end shopping. Fun to walk on a beautiful street with the finest stores!

Upmarket shopping. A beautiful street - wide and tree lined like many in the city. Gaudi's architecture was amazing. Some very chic shops lining the pavements including Salvatori Ferragamo, Tiffany etc

Bond Street in Barcelona. Very high class shops, many upper level brand names. If you have the time and the money this is the place to shop, if you don't mind knowing you could buy the same in London, Paris, New York etc.

Walk up and down and enjoy. Great wide avenue with outstanding architecture and attractive shops and very clean. Sit in any outdoor café and enjoy the sport of people watching (people are watching you.) Be prepared to pay €4 for a mini-bottle of Coke.
Beautiful area. This is where the luxury shops are. I loved this area. This is where the Art Nouveu buildings are. There is a good range of restaurants and bars and most are reasonably priced.

Lovely Avenue for a stroll. Our hotel was located on Passeig de Gracia. It put us within two blocks of the Metro and bus stops. A Gaudi-designed office building/residence was a block away and another Gaudi building two blocks the other way. Many beautiful but expensive stores--like Barcelona's answer to the nice part of 5th Avenue, Manhattan.
Passeig de Gracia. A "buyers" corner of the city. Beautiful architecture on a wide street, full of big and fancy shops and pour restaurants/cafés. Pick a side street to have decent drink/food

Wonderful street. When you love architectoral art then you cant miss this part of Barcelona. You find beautiful houses and buildngs here, pieces of master art. And also good for shopping when you want everyone to be happy...
shopping & joking. the best and wider shopping place in europe. Gaudi's architect creations attract tourists from all over the word.
Shops and Gaudi buildings. A big street with a lot of shops, a few bars and restaurants, public transport and some Gaudi architecture.
Great shopping and bars. This is a buzzing high end shopping street packed with street bars and nice restuarants, much nicer street than the seedy Rambla
Lots to see. Had four hours before leaving for flight and found plenty to do in this area alone
Passeig de Gracia. Shopping and sites galore! Walking distance to the famous Ramblas, Plaza Catalunya, La Pedrera, Casa Battlo. When in Barcelona, you want to stay here.

Wouldn't tire of walking down the street everyday. When I booked my hotel I had no idea it was located in this boulevard and that this was such a beautiful place to stay. You see Casa Mila and Casa Batllo just a few blocks from each other on this boulevard. There are many designer shops at both sides of the boulevard.
something for everyone. great street for window shopping and people watching as you stroll past some of the moderniste beauties of barcelona

CHIC AND HAUTE COUTURE!!!. the most expensive and recognized designers are here ... La Pedrera .... Casa Batllo .... and the most conglomerate of the GAudis' art in the buildings on this beautiful stroll!!!

VERY BEAUTIFUL STREET. The best of passeig de gracia is cassa batllo.From Gaudi.
The worst that some shops are too expensive.
But just walking there is very nice
Rodeo Drive. Not my cup of tea anymore, but for those who like Jimmy Choo, Prada and others, this is the place for you. Very upper east side New York.

Not worth the trip. Its good to say you have been there but the street is full of tacky stalls and shops selling pointless merchandise. Plsu the street is full of pick pocketers, thankfully i was not a victim. there are alot more beautiful parts of barcelona to see than this street.
Good Shopping. Good shopping street. Worth a visit. We thought the prices were quite reasonable. And you had all the brands in the neighborhood.

Champs Elysees of Barcelona. We stayed quite close to PDG so were able to walk along the whole length to av. diagonal..very beautiful street with lots of shops. Make sure to turn east on to Provence street as it houses a couple of cute little boutiques.
Barcelona's "5th Ave.". Barcelona's "5th Ave" and it lived up to it's name. Great street!
Beautiful street and a Gaudi building Great!. The street is lined with magnificent houses, real Grand and the shops are exquisite.

Passeig de Gracia. High end shopping if you are in to that. Bring lots of cash or lots of room on your credit card as there are no bargins here. But if you wants brand names, this is where you get them!

Beautiful Avenue. Barcelona has beautiful public spaces, and these broad, shady avenues are made for strolling; stopping to have a drink or snack at an outdoor cafe; window (or actual) shopping; and people watching. The Champs Elysee has nothing on Barcelona's beautiful avenues.

Just an average high street really! Wonder why its a site at all!. This is really a high street lined with luxury and regular shopping on either sides - wonder how it has made it to the popular sights! dont recommend eating anywhere on the street as you will pay 20-30% extra over other places!

Most Elegant Shopping Street in Barcelona. Coming off of Plaza Catalunya, Passeig de Gracia contains the most elegant stores and shopping in Barcelona, as well as fine eating establishments. It is served by public transportation, but can be accessed on foot from Plaza Catalunya as well.
Safe n central. Safe and central location. Coutoure shopping place but las ramblas and catalunya is a 5 to 10 minutes away by walking.

Nice street of you are a shopper. A nice wide street.Nice houses and nice shops.good restaurants and nice fountain.Other than that nothing major to do there.There are a couple of Gaudi's houses if you like them but I would recommend going there and spending no more than an hour. If your in to shops then you'll have a lot to do there still prices are not cheap.
Shop and eat til you drop. Lots of shops and places to eat. Also lost of interesting Architecture and a few Gaudi treasures on the way, so worth a look.
Beautiful. Our hotel overlooked this street. It is beautiful and full of beautiful architecture and life.
A great walk. View the Gaudi buildings and grab some tapas while you sit outside watching the world go by
If you want retail therapy. Lovely to walk down and window shop. Something like 20% of all Spain's retail revenue comes from the shopping avenue
Like 5th Avenue in NYC. Great strolling avenue, good restaurants and hotels busy but gives you the pulse of the city in an upscale neighborhood

Passeig de Gracia - Barcelona's Beautiful Boulevard. If Barcelona's streets were a family Las Ramblas would be the noisy younger brother constantly getting ino mischief and coming home with muddy knees whereas Passeig de Gracia would be the sophisticated elder sister sitting at a bar sipping a cocktail with an elegant slightly haughty air. Read more at http://bigbarcelonablog.blogspot.com.es/2012/06/passeig-de-gracia-and-la-casa-batllo.html

A little bit of class!. If you want to get away from the Ramblas and window shop (or the real thing!) see Gaudi's houses or just take in the rest of the spectacular architecture this is the place to be!

Just a busy shopping area. Well indeed quite a few of famous spots around there but excluding those it is just a busy shopping street with many big brands but can't really compare to London. We spent less than one hour and left the area as most of the shops are smaller and items are less than London anyway.
Lots of shops and bars. Along this passage there are lots of nice designer shops, and a variety of bars and restaurants, with indoor and outdoor seating.

Check out the gaudi pavement. The avenue in Barcelona,expensive shopping, beautiful gaudi and modernist houses, and a decorated pavement as well as gausi benches. Take a walk in paseo de gracia. A must see.
Simply lovely place to go. Another must go when in Barcelona. Just let yourself go.
The shopping street. Better to wander than the Rambla less hassle and where all the decent shops are
if you like designer shops. this street is the best in town! shops everywhere from Hermes to Zara!
Nice walking down this street. Busy bustling street, with many expensive shops, worth a look even just for the Gaudi buildings

Even if you are planning to shop, you'll enjoy the walk. This street (or avenue) is where two prime Gaudi homes are, and it is just a few block long. It is a no-brainer if you are staying fro a period of 2 days or more. It ends at the Plaza Catalunya, north from las Ramblas. You'll enjoy the walk.

Great Area to shop. Unfortunately I discovered this area on a Sunday... which is an extremely confusing day as a tourist because none of the shops were opened and as far as I could tell it wasn't a public holiday! Try and visit on a Friday or Saturday to get the best of the experience
Amazing area.. Although it isn't a massive area it is amazing, you must remember to look up as walking around as you will always be amazed.

interesting. up market shopping area of barcelona. good restaurants
had a stroll and a browse most evenings, a friendly and safe area

A bit posh but interesting. This leadsdow to the Placa De Catalunya and is prof the poshest shopping streets in Barca, it has a lot of the main high street brands pus places such as Armani and the like. There are some ok paces to eat including Txapela a Basque Pintxos restaurant which I love. You will probably recognise 90% of the shops but a nice placebo cool off whilstshoppingandEl Corte Ingle is at the bottom of it.

Shoppers' Heaven. You can spend the day shopping till you drop here along this street! And when you are ready to relax, stop by one of the tapas/coffee shops to have a bite to get re-energized to shop on the other side of this street, really!
Good. Nice street with lots of restaurant and shops， street are clean and wide， easy access by underground

nice for food and a walk. lot of terraces where you can eat and drink, prices are more or less everywhere the same. Expensive shops with wellknown brands are here nd it is nice to watch people here and drink some wine.
Good area for shopping. Take the subway to Passeig de Gracia and walk the streets while spending money at the many great shops, it's that simple:)
Love it. Good walk ,not very crowded ,lots of shopping and I hate shopping ,very expensive
Best street for shops. Plenty of upscale shops, restaurants, and hotels and a short stroll on may of the sidestreets finds many other small interesting venues
Upmarket area away from the main crowds. Good hotels, restaurants, tapas bars with upmarket shopping and also feels safe in the evening when strolling around. No dislikes.

Great avenue, great shopping. This is Le Champs Elyseis of Barcelona, but friendlier. Great shops and boutiques, from Channel to Zara. Many restaurants and cafes and the address of two of the most famous Gaudi homes, Casa Batllo and La Pedrera. It is nice in the evening when it is a bit quieter and the buildings are lit.

Beautiful Avenue. This is an avenue in the center on Barcelona full of shops , cafeterias and restaurants.
You can find everything you want there.
Gaudi two great buildings are in this avenue.
Very clean sitewalks, beatiful buildings architecture.

A great street to walk down and see Gaudi's masterpieces. If you can't afford to pay the entrance fees to see inside Casa Battlo and La Pedrera (so worth it!), at least walk down this amazing avenue and wonder at the architecture - the other buildings in the L'Eixample area are worth seeing too. The pavements and the street furniture are also very stylish.

The avenue of La Pedrera and Casa Batlo!. Passeig de Gracia is the avenue where is possible to see two of Gaudi's houses: La Pedrera and Casa Batló. In addition, the famous stores like Chanel, Miu Miu, Valentino, etc are there, with many restaurants and cafes.
GREAT PLACE TO STROLL. Passeig de Gracia is a wonderful avenue. Great for shopping, relaxing at a cafe, people watching. Beautiful!

Champs Elysees eat your heart out!. So smart and so clean.. a lovely street with wonderful buildings (and many lovely shops) for an afternoon stroll stopping only for a little snack and one of the sidewalk cafes

Shopping Street. This street was kind of the main drag that led into Las Ramblas (the touristy area). It was wide and well kept. There were a few (2 that I remember) Gaudi homes on it. Otherwise it is a typical shopping street with stores like Burberry, Chanel, and the like... Not a must-see.

chic street. loved walking down this street. Asides from the Gaudi buildings, there were big name luxe brands (Chanel, LV, etc.) but also H&M, Zara, etc. Plus, all the good restaurantes were either on this street or it's side streets.

Top Rate Shops. If you are looking for the Rodeo Drive of Beverly Hills, the Champ de Ellysses of Paris, the Passeig de Gracia offers you the shop til you drop experience with all the high end luxury items that you can afford.
A vibrant street scene. Sidewalk cages, shops, unforgettable architecture, and lots of opportunities for people watching.

A stylish street to stroll and catch your buses. It's a long road on which those double-decker buses intercept, it's lined with designer shops, fancy restaurants, and dotted with really stylish architectures.

Shop till you drop !. Fabulous area for shopping and soaking up the atmosphere of Barcelona ! You will find all types of shops from high end down to high street..and when you have finished, its wonderful to just have a rest and a nice drink at one of the many cafes !
Very nice shopping. A mix of very upscale and moderately priced shopping. One of out favorites was Zara. Also may great eateries where you can sit and enjoy the energy of the city. Worth a stroll!

Best place to feel the real Barcelona. There are 2 things that evey tourist should do on Passeig de Gracia : 1) walk along the street and look around for the beautiful buildings , the stores , the restaurants ...and 2) take a beer , sangria or coffee on a table on the sidewalk . preferably on the eastern side where the view is better !  Just take a drink , do not have dinner there , it is too expensive ; go back to Barri Gotic or la Ribera for local food !

BEST STREET IN BARCELONA. The street is a gem with beautiful buildings,shops,restaurants and cafes.The sidewalks and corners of the street decorated with astonishing great metal lamps .We walked up and down this street also at night,from Placa Catalunya till Casa Mila(LA PEDERA),Casa Batilo,and through a few side streets enjoying the strange but beautiful architecture .A must to see especially at night.
Eh!. Beautiful boulevard with high end designer stores, but nothing really unique in the stores. Just another Rodeo Drive or Champs Elysees.
Great Street. My favourite street in Barcelona. Lots of shops and cafes.
SHOP TILL YOU DROP!. You will not be able to walk down this great street and come away empty handed. Good luck!

A great show of art on the streets of Barcelona. Beautiful tiles on the floor and lamps on every corner, plus Gaudí's works on display passing by La Pedrera and Casa Battló and Amatler. Also, most high end shopping stores round up a nice walk.
gorgeous. Excellent time, everywhere you look there is some building to look at and study, brilliant

busy and colorful!. bustling town, busy and colorful! everything a traveller is looking for... well at least for me! be careful of pickpockets though (ive heard stories but was lucky nothing happened to me) as its really busy and there are really a lot of things (distractions) going on! many shops, great to shop at.. cafes and restaurants al fresco for u to sip your cafe au lait, savor your paella and watch the world dance past you! i miss Barcelona!

Fashionable boulevard near many Modernista buildings. My wife and I walked the Passeig de Gracia on two days of our week in Barcelona. There are many fashionable shops and several outdoor restaurants. In addition to Gauti's Casa Battlo and Casa Mila, there are many Modernista designed buildings within a block of Passeig de Gracia. Get a map that shows all the locations of the Modernista buildings before you walk the Passeig and enjoy the spectacle.
charming and stylish. beautiful street with all possible world famous boutiques, nice to walk day time & evening.
Not sure why this is worth rating - it's a road. As far as I can tell this is a road. It has some lovely buildings on it, but it quite busy and noisy. Worth visiting to admire the floor tiles though.
Nice walk. Its like an open museum , must go there and walk all over to se La Pedrera , Casa Battló and lots of stores.

U can't miss it!!!. It's the main boulevard... All the major shopping stores r on it.. Use the bendy bus or and other local bus (22,24), to see the entire thing... Don't miss vincon if u like home stuff.. It's just after casa batlo facing away from plaza catalunya.. Walking it would b too much.. For walking go to las ramblas.. It's cute

A place to see the Barcelona rich. Well worth a visit to walk along, looking at all the top of the range shops! Not for the faint hearted when you look at some of the prices in the shops but that was half the fun

Barcelona's main avenue. It's a short walk from La Rambla & what a wonderful street - you'll find plenty of designer shops & some of Gaudi's finest works can be found here, including Casa Batllo & La Pedera. Vincon, next to La Pedera is the place if you've ever hankered after Philippe Starck fitted wardrobes - it's also the last word on every other home idea, from lamps to toys. Elsewhere along this stretch of street you'll find fabulous (& fabulously expensive) furniture & antique shops specialising in Art Deco & Art Nouveau. Loved the place!

Such a beatiful road to walk down to attractions. Start from the north of the road, get down to La Rambla; you will not miss the open cafes in the middle and nice boutiques/shops in both sides of the street. Such a clean, like a pedestrian way which is both amazing and charishing your soul
broad open street. nice shops and restaurants. It was the natural walk to the station - som we didn´t spent a lot of time there.

Not local but very nice. Fun area to walk around in but it's the typical high end shopping district that every city has. I stayed here and it was a. Great location but just be aware it's not a local atmosphere. There are two Gaudi buildings within a few blocks and that is nice!
Great. Go there and enjoy this nice area where you can chill out.
a lot of shops. Good prices, a lot of shops, large boulevard, great for a walk!
Sophisticated. Full of fascinating architectural gems, some of which are open. It's worth looking up this area in detail if you're interested in design.

Another Boulevard. What was intended as the major (and only) road that would link the old city of Barcelona with the countryside, over the years and much clever real state business schemes, became what you see today; the most luxurious, expensive, flashy boulevard in Barcelona. And way too crowded. Lines, long lines are the norm everytime tourists try to go to say, La Pedrera or Casa Batlló (both, Gaudi masterpieces). Hords of tourists cram the few tables available outside on the sidewalk some lucky restaurants have. And be prepared to pay three or more euros for a lousy cup of espresso. My advise, go early. Walk the boulevard when no one else does; on a Sunday mornig (but really early). The light is perfect for pictures!

Great shopping street in Barcelona!. Great to window shop, since most of the retailers were far too expensive for our budget. From stores like Tiffany's and Cartier to H&M and Zara. Lots of yummy cafes and outdoor seating for restaurants that gives it that European charm. The Champs Elysee / 5th Avenue of Barcelona.

Hide your wife's credit cards.. Our hotel was in the Passeig de Gracia, and the area had a really safe feel about it, especially at night. Window shopping was a delight, and the high range jewellers and fashion houses were amazing . The hop~on,hop~off buses are here, as is the metro. I really enjoyed seeing some of the street artists who perform here in the evening, my favourite being the "Marlyn Monroe" lookalike who dresses in the famous white dress, and encourages visitors to have their photograph taken with her for one euro!
Beautiful shopping. One of the most beautiful shopping streats ever.....
Beautiful street, great shopping. A nice place for a long walk to view Barcelona's architecture (Gaudi's La Pedrera) and shop the high-end familiar names.

If you want to shop.... This is the place to be if you want to shop. You will find several H&M's, Tiffany's, Totus, Nike Studio, Puma, Mango, Louis Vuitton, Carte, Zara, North Face, a large department store and more.
Expensive shops and lovely tapas-restaurant. Good food, good shopping places like Louis Vitton, Ferrari, Nike..

Take a leisurely walk down this road, if you get the chance. "Passeig de Gracia" is a main road in Barcelona. It is lined by many shops and a few signature sites of Barcelona, such as Casa Batlo and La Pedrera.To access this road, just take the L3 metro and get off at the "Diagonal" station. When you surface to the ground, you will be on "Av. Diagonal" and "Passieg de Gracia". This is a good starting point. Just walk southwards down "Passieg de Gracia". The beginning of "Passeig de Gracia" is a bit quieter with more high end shops, but as you go southwards, the pace picks up, and you will notice a lot more tourists, restaurants and regular stores. As mentioned before, you will see a few of Gaudi's famous architectural masterpieces on "Passeig de Gracia". If you are walking southward, you will notice "La Pedrara" on the left, and a bit further down you will notice "Casa Batlo" on the right. The road itself is about 6-7 blocks. The good thing is, that if you continue on this road, it will lead you right to the Gothic area of the city, which is completely unique on its own.Enjoy some of our shots.

Fashion District of Barcelona. I walked through Passeig de Gracia almost everyday of my one week holiday in Barcelona. My husband & I stayed at Ana's Guesthouse on Avinguda Diagonal where we strolled westbound to Gaudi's La Pedrera then southbound on Passeig de Gracia. Along this road are designer shops, restaurants & all kinds of nice shops. This is the Eixample district where the real estate property is the most costly in Barcelona. The aristocrats live here and you can see it in the exquisite buildings, the pretty benches & street lamps. I never tired of strolling along this avenue which ends in Plaza Catalunya from which point starts the exciting La Rambla.
Shopping paradise. All the big designer names(and some we'd never heard of) plus some wonderful architecture.
easily found but queued up. took about half hour to get in but was pleasant to see the different styles. but by now your back starts to give up walking and standing
Not too special. Mostly worth the walk because of the Gaudi houses. If you're into very expensive shops like Armani, Gucci etc it's worth it too.
Watch the World go by. Apart from all the wonderful Spanish brands here, you can sit and enjoy people watching

How to avoid being ripped off. Ther road is a splendid avenue however beware cafes and always ,always ask to see a price list. DO NOT ORDER without seeing one as the prices can be exorbitant.If there is no price list the waiter will ask what you want so you tell him assuming it will be a sensible price.When a beer(small) and a Sangrai(large) plus one cake come to 31 euros you know you have been done avoid' La Baguetina Catalana' it is close to La Perdera Guadi's apartment block. Be warned. We have complained to the tourist office and will see what happens.
Commercial avenue with top branded stores. If you want to buy brands, this is the place to come.
A lovely stroll. Walked through this area and enjoyed being immersed in all of Gaudi's buildings..ate lunch at an outdoor cafe (food not so memorable) but great for people watching

Evening in the Parc. A wonderful walk UP the hill to the park and a very enjoyable explore around Gaudi's imagination. There is a Cave bar where you can get a drink and snack and look out to the east.

Art, style and fashion. The big plus of the main upscale shopping street in Barcelona is the is located on the Route of Modernism (you can actually see on the sidewalks a red rounded metal sign that tells you are walking on that route. Gaudì masterpieces Casa Batllo and La Pedrera are right on Paseig de Gracia (a few blocks from each other) as well as other beautiful palaces by other famous architects. If you like shopping or simply window shopping that's the place where all the most famous stylist from all over the world have their stores.
A must see in barcelona. Same as Catalunya ,Passeig de gracia is a lively place where you can shop eat and drink. But beware of pickpockets. Besides you will enjoy every moment.

shop shop and shop. till you drop....a lovely street with wonderful designer boutiques and brands.
The cafes & tapas bars here are also worth the visit.
Like any main shopping street, though can get very busy...so always be vigilant with your belongings as pick pockets do operate...
do you want to visit nice shops?. Go there and you will find the best shops - but also expensive shops.

attractive walk, architecture, shopping, eating. Up-scale area with leafy trees, sidewalk cafes, high-end shopping and Modernista architecture. On the way to Sagrada Familia from Placa Catalunya anyway, so enjoy the stroll.

Not sure what the attraction is. Can you say more tapa restaurants and more small shops? I couldn't figure out what the attraction was, and it's not as though I didn't make the effort to walk almost 2 miles to get there. I guess it's all in terms of your expectations. If you want just another row of overpriced tapa restaurants and touristy shops, then by all means, head out! Otherwise, walk just two or three blocks to your left or right and hit the real Barcelona!

Best street in Barcelona. If you are looking for fashion-sense shopping, stunning architecture and Tapas, this is your Street. You can find lots of magnificent buildings like “La pedrera” or “Casa Batllo”.
Main thourough fare. great main street. attractions cavs tourist bus subways trains

Gorgeous modernista building on a pretty street. What a treat to see all the beautiful building by Gaudi and other modernista masters on such a pretty street. The shopping is very good and the tapas bars very good and reasonable. This is so much nicer a street than the Ramblas.
The Shopping Street. Where to go to window shop. The street contains all the top stores one would generally associate with great, special shopping.
