Not to be missed. This is probably not as pedestrian friendly as Las Ramblas, but it is certainly worth a stroll. And keep looking up, as the buildings are stunning, although some are maybe a bit weird!

Big time boulevard.... All the big shops here, so take the credit card. Or just stroll along and window shop. Whilst walking along, we witnessed a cyclist's protest - hundreds of people cycling down the premier route in BCN and all of them completely naked! What a giggle! It's a great area, full of architectural interest - enjoy.

Pick a day there's no traffic.. We arrived on Passeig de Gracia on the day of the general strike. The entire street was cordoned off and filled with protestors, policemen and journalists. from the centre lanes you get a great view of the modernist architecture while mingling with thousands of unemployed young people. From the sidelines, the elderly are willing to strike up a conversation and give their assessment of the situation. No danger in crossing the street or being run over by a motorcycle. .. tons of great photographs possible. Nice change from the usual traffic noise, blaring of horns, fumes of taxis and the incessant tour buses. Banners and slogans provide welcome break from the high fashion shops.Tip: The scene deteriorates after dark when your usual masked ruffians take over.
Beautiful area. Lots of beautiful buildings such as Casa Batlo can be seen there. Took lots of pictures. Great for places of interest.

Very walkable. Walked the length of this modern yet amazing thoroughfare full of interesting aspects of architecture, shops, bars and cafes, & don;t forget the useful bus stops that permit access to other sights in the city. The one intensely annoying aspect of Barcelona is not so evident here with the spaciousness of this street, the immense number of locals who feel a need to walk the streets smoking at all times, it's totally disgusting, once replicated in Paris, they seem to have largely got over this habit, surprising to see so much street smoking in such a modern cosmopolitan city, even the schoolchildren smoke prolifcally. Disgusting. But the Passage de Gracia is thankfully, a little more enjoyable.

A stroll with a View. You have to walk up one side of the Passeig De Gracia and down the other to take in all that is on show. Lots of peopleeverywhere and so many places to eat and drink and sit on a terrace and take in some sun with a bit of conversation.

LOST ALL OF ITS CHARM:(. Ive recently visited Passeig de Graca after many years and to my biggest disaapointment its all about Zara Mango and H&M stores:( The Passeo and the Ramblas used to eb full of typical stores (along with the fancy ones of course) and many typical local stores and restos.. Now, all that glimpes to someone's eyes are the chain stores.. What a pity;(

Walk it More Than Once. This is a fascinating thoroughfare going north/south in Barcelona. Walk from the New Cathedral (Sagrada Familia) to the old Cathedral using the boulevard. Stop and grab a tapa or caffe.. Buses and subway are easy, but this is the 19th-20th century boulevard of Barcelona; walk it.

Long walk. If you are going to Gran VIa, get off at Plaza Catalunya, and walk the street and see the view. >The walk from Passeig de Gracia underground stop to Gran Via seemed like it was about a kilometer in the tunnel.
A Busy City Street.. Passeig de Gracia is like 5th Avenue. It is lined with luxury shops.

Lovely Boulevard for walking and shopping. Wonderful change from Las Ramblas. We strolled along, window shopped in the high end boutiques, looked at the famous Gaudi houses and ate in a local restaurant. Wonderful afternoon walk from Sagrada Familia to Placa Catalunya.

the catalan Champs Elysees. This arteria to the city of Barcelona is always full of visitors and traffic as it contains the most important stores and bureaus of the city. If you are not present there....you are no one
Great window shopping. Love this area - wide pavements, lots of window shopping; my recommendation, see if you can get a table outside a cafe, order some sangria and watch the world go by.
Fun walk, fancy stores... Just take the atmosphere in.Lined with cafes, get lost in the "mini malls" that come off the sides.

Good place to have wine and tapas al fresco in the evening.. A lot of activity at all times. Interesting to see "La manzana de la discordia" during the day and people watch at night in one of the sidewalk cafes.
Barcelona Style. Just walk up and down on the wide pavements and take in the fabulous architecture and the great shops and restaurants.

One of the most Beautifull Avenues in Europe. Fashonable paseo de Gracia has the best stores, and icredibble architecture, including Casa Milla, Casa Batlo and other famous houses from Modernista architects

Lovely!. I just like walking up and down this avenue savouring the atmosphere. I love the architecture, there's a fabulous building on every corner and virtually every building has a beautiful facade. Even the street lamps and paving stones are beautiful never mind the fabulous shops. Just don't eat or drink there. Not worth the price!
The Fifth avenue. Wonderful shops, hotels and restaurants as well as Gaudi buildings, on this street. The neighborhood is delightful. Wide avenue and walking area.

To visit in barcelona. Just walk around to spend some time.
Only commerce but is where is casa Batllo
Stay here. The best location in BArcelona to stay and shop. Forget the Ramblas

Beautiful architectural walk. First tourist attraction usually since it starts at the Plaça de Catalunya and ends at Gracia Quarter. Two of the important Gaudí's buildings can be found on this important avenue, Casa Batlló and Casa Milà (la Pedrera). Also, right next to Casa Batlló is Casa Amatller designed by Josep Puig i Cadafalch for chocolatier Antoni Amatller. This is a very famous and important avenue since lots of beautiful well maintained modernist buildings are found here. Of course, there are plenty of others through out the city but they are concentrated here.Lots of expensive famous designer shops with their fancy window displays and Boulevard Rosa shopping center, lots of restaurant and tapas but most of them cater to tourist so I wouldn't recommend them but if you just want to rest in one of the coffee shops to drink something and have a piece of pastries, it is totally fine to do so. Be careful with your purses or belongings even when you think you are in a safe area.Passeig de Gràcia runs parallel to la Rambla de Catalunya so you can kill two birds with one stone.
Trendy shops and restaurants. Lovely to promenade in the evening and good places to have dinner. Exclusive shopping and wide boulavades

Cool to stroll, have tapas, a cold one and people watch. What can I say? Cool to stroll and see the shops, have tapas, coffee and people watch. Was fun. At the end is the Placa de Catalanya square which is full of people enjoying each others company

Not very long, not too wide: the very best. This is one of those streets that talks by itself: it's not the longest but it has so many wonderful buildings on it that overwhelms you. And excellent shops, and good restaurants, and nice people and Gaudí and.....

desiger destination.. Barcelona's most fashionable street, with buildings by it's greatest architects, and more places to spend money on great design that you could wish. All the great brands, plus Vinçon, a delightful design store that leads contemporary taste.
Reason we love Barcelona. This street in Barcelona was full of shops, historical buildings, culture, restaurants. This is why we love the city.
Beautiful street - preferred it over Las Ramblas. Beautiful architecture, great restaurants and shopping. Much nicer and more peaceful than Las Ramblas.
Barna!. For local people, here is Barna. You will enjoy. Spend a morning here.
Shopping... as it should be. The place where you won't be able to control yourself, shopping is mad there and all your pockets will be empty, Credit cars plays a great role there :D

Maybe better for an Avid Shopper?. I just didn't get that excited about the shopping. Some of the Architecture was great but the Gaudi buildings each have their own ratings on here so I don't think I can credit the whole Passeig de Gracia with that. My wife loves to shop and she only found a couple of stores that she felt we needed to stop at. I much preferred the fun atmosphere of El Rastro in Madrid(the biggest Flea Market you could imagine).
Beware. Beware of an italian on rollerskates call Salvatore! Tries to lure tourists (even in groups of four!) to his "appartment to cook for you"...
Just an avenue. Often called as the "Champs-Elysees" of Barcelona. I was a bit disappointed, because there is a lot of traffic on this avenue, so you can not enjoy any atmosfere.
Meh.... Super expensive strip with high end stores. If you're not a shopper, you can skip the strip unless you're going to Casa Battlo.
Great place to start in Barcelona. Great walk to see incredible architecture, as well as shop like a fiend.

Wonderful street. This is the heart of high-end tourism/shopping in Barcelona. One block away and parallel to it is Rambla de Catalunya, a broad avenue dedicated to pedestrians...it's a bit quieter. Both streets run to the Placa de Catalunya (Plaza de Catalonia) and on to the Gothic Quarter. The big name stores are on Gracia.
A busy city street. If you seek expensive designer shopping and average Tapas, this is the place for you.
Best part of the City to visit. Great scenery and shopping. Easy metro access. I would take in this area on foot or travel to it with the metro. The tourist bus is very expensive and very crowded.

Amazing street. The buildings lining up Passeig de Gracia are so beautiful. Of course none of the restaurants are worth eating in as with any touristy places but it's definitely worth a walk along road to see the modernista buildings but you should also take a tour of inner streets from there

Great shopping. lots of expensive designer shops and lovely restaurants along this street. Keep an eye on your belongings though. We had our bag containing our camera and other belongings stolen whilst we had a coffee in Starbucks.
very swish!. love gracia not only has it got some of the best architecture in the world but the shopping and cafes take some beating!

The "Champs-Elysees" of Barcelona. Take a stroll down this beautiful avenue where art meets fashion, old meets new. With two of Gaudi's buildings on that street and a few other interesting buildings you have plenty to see. Further all the fancy designer boutiques are on that street and those provide great window shopping experience. Small tip: this is not necessarily the ideal place to eat for example as it is rather touristic, check the smaller side streets to grab a bite!

Visit the galleries. Passeig de Gracia is a fantastic place to visit if you love art. It has a lot of interesting art venues both on the road and on roads nearby, for example:Fundació SuñolFundació Alorda DerksenFundació Foto ColectaniaKowasa Photography Bookshop and GalleryI can thoroughly recommend a visit to all of the above! Most cost very little and show some of the most interesting art and art collections in Barcelona.
Fun to window shop. Interesting street. Great architecture. Great people watching.
Barcelona's Champs Elysees. A great street to see famous brands and stores. Kind of a shopping area. Also you can see Gaudi's buildings when you keep walking to the north.

Great Mix. Loved the fountain half way up Passeig de Gracia and the great mix of designer shops mixed in with more affordable shops! Loved the big wide pavements, Barcelona is so much more pleasant to travel around (not so busy, with traffic or people!) as other cities.
Commercial street. Very touristic stressful street, with to expensive and glamours shops for my taste.
Expensive. Similar to Bond Street, tree lined avenida buzzing with people and traffic but very expensive and the sales assistants had a complete 'attitude' problem.

Better than Ramblas. To be sincere I didn't found Ramblas so interesting; on the other side Passeig de Gracia is full of class with its buildings and shops.And it has not the same "pressure" on tourists like Ramblas has.

a passagway of fun. Passeig de Garcia isa fun walkway in Barcelona. Here is where the city begins to define itself especially the mile north of Plaza de Catalunya. It is tree lined and filled with large boutiques and shops and sprinkled liberally with bars and nice eating places that a tourist can enjoy. it also has some Gaudi artifacts and the Casa Padrera house along the way. We highly recommend the walk.
Barcelona. Very elegant street with lots of expensive shops and beautiful architecture

Designer shopping paradise. Like Fifth Avenue in New York City, all premier designers. If you don't want to shop still a gorgeous street with very wide walkways, patterned cement, Gaudi designed lamp posts and benches.

A lovely street with Casa Batllo, La Pedrera and some great shops. One of the main streets leading off of Placa de Catalunya, Passeig de Gracia is a lovely easy walk passing some great shops, Casa Batllo, La Pedrera (Casa Mila) and, if you look up, some amazing architectural buildings and roof tops as well.
Better than rodeo drive.... because of this street Barcelona is a major city. shopping & dining on this street is a very nice experience. "Brown" restaurant is perfect.
Better than La Rambla. I would head here instead of La Rambla. Much nicer mix of people, shops and food....although do not miss the Market on the Rambla.
Busy Busy Busy. Lots of lovely shops, old buildings with a lot of character and history, very clean city

Nice street. Good for window shopping, as all the really major brands (like channel and so on) are there.The street is sided by two of Gaudi most know Casas, Milla and Batló. Floor of the sidewalks made accordingly to Gaudi's plans to those houses.Safe and clean area of the city, good to walk during the day or night.Well served by public transports.Lots of restaurants and tapas pubs on the street.You're sure to go there if you're traveling to Barcelona.
I can't imagine . . .. How inventive! One must smile, but can only try to imagine what must have gone through the mind of the artists.

can't be missed. I do not think anybody visits Barcelona without walking Pg. Gracia. Worthwile for the special buildings on it and, for some, the shopping who gets more exclusive and design-like by the day.

The most expensive street in Barcelona. Passeig de Gracia is an important avenue of Barcelona. Its limits are Placa Catalunya and Carrer Gran de Garcia.Here are the most expensive properties from Barcelona. Also, here's a major shopping and business area.Me and my wife were impressed by the very beautiful houses of this avenue.I can mention few attraction of the area : Casa Batllo, Casa La Pedrera, Museu del Perfum, Palau Robert, Hotel Majestic, Teatre Tivoli.Metro stop "Passeig de Gracia" - Line Mauve L2 or Line Green L3.

Shops, Tapas, Bars and Gaudi Houses, what more could you need.. We were very lucky to stay in a hotel on the Passeig de Gracia as we were right in the centre of the most vibrant part of town. The large avenue is lined with upmarket shops, cafes and Tapas bars. It is always busy with locals going about there daily lives. The buildings are an interesting mix of the old and new. Two of Gaudi’s best buildings are here. The fantasy castle like Casa Batllo with it’s brightly colour glass tiled exterior and its eccentric inferiors. Further up the street is Gaudi’s apartment block the Casa Mila with its iconic white tiled chimneys. Both are well worth a visit, but get there early as the lines of tourists build up quickly. There is a lot of traffic in several lanes, but there are plenty of pelican crossings and the pedestrian ares are large enough for you the forget the traffic is there. The street lights are beautiful, so make sure you look up. This is a great place to spend on morning shopping and sightseeing and there are lots of places on the main road to get a coffee or Tapas. If you want a restaurant investigate the side streets, they are packed with shops, cafes and delightful restaurants. Not the cheapest parts of town but definite must for any trip to Barcelona.
Great Shopping. A nice clean part of town. The side walks are huge and styled after tile Gaudi created for the Casa Mila.

Pleasant walk with good window shopping. Walk from the Avenida Diagonal down, do some window shopping at luxury stores, admire the Gaudi works, and stop by Tapas 24 for some lunch.
If you have to use the restroom you can go to the top floor of El Corte Ingles.
The walk for shoppers. Lots of storess for shopping. Nice cafes for people watching.

Walking in the past and the present. A grand avenue full of gracious old homes, spectacular Gaudi buildings, expensive shops and over priced sidewalk cafes. Well worth a stroll and the price of a table to people watch from or sit on one of the free Gaudi benches along the way.

Great area to have drinks and dinner. This was recommended to us by two lovely local ladies, they described it as safe with little streets lovely bars and restaurants. It was exactly that. Not far from The Wilson Boutique Hotel, Av Diagonal
Below Average. This place is okay but there is nothing too exciting about it. It is however, filthy.
Beautiful area. Very clean and so much to see. Beautiful buildings and lots of points of interest. Expensive shops
shopping. Great street to shop, people watch and have a coffee or sangria!
Gorgeous. We stayed in this area. Designer shops and lovely cafe bars everywhere. Just to watch the world go by with a glass of white wine
Nice shopping street. One of the nicest shopping streets in Europe, from boutiques to global chains and even luxury. With some very pleasant tourist attractions too.

The Barcelona "Champs Elysées. This is the place to go , to be , to look for, to visit.It is the place where you can find the "casa batillo" and the "Pedrera", both from the genial Gaudi.Do not miss to go for a walk at night....Like the Plaça Catalunya , it is full of life.In Passeig de Gracia, the "Gaudi" is everywhere , even in the resting place you will find here and there.

Rodeo Drive, Michigan Ave, 5th Ave of Barcelona!. Beautiful luxury shopping and trendy restaurants. I'm a bit odd in that I avoid locals-only restaurants, unless they are affluent locals. It's a beautiful street to window shop, have a coffee outside and watch the most chic of Barcelona parade by.
Very nice walk. Very nice walk,plenty of nice shops,plenty of cafes- tapas bars.
Amazing ambience!. A must-see. My brother and I enjoyed walking around this area. So many street performers, so many shops available for food and drinks and internet shops!
Good. Again plenty to see glad we included it use the buses to get around

One of the prettiest streets in Europe. This is an amazing street even if you have no interest in high-end shopping. Forget about Las Ramblas - this is the street to see in Barcelona. Do not miss the next street over - Rambla de Catalunya; it is just as good as the Passeig de Gracia.
Excellent. Excellent just because la Pedrera and Casa Batllo is situated here
Major street in the City. From the stores, the hotels, and cafes. You can't avoid this long street to get around the City!
Top brands in Barcelona. Passeig de Gracia is the top shopping street in Barcelona. The best brands and the amazing architecture make the perfect blend.
Best shopping street. This is where you find all brand shops, like LV, Ferragamo and other - famous Gaudi house is also along it.
Love it!. Lots of beautiful buildings!!! You can also do your shopping there :-)
People watching. Be aware that you pay more for food and drinks here. But it can be worth it if you like people watching while having lunch or a drink.

trendy shopping street with lively bars and restaurants. Passeig de Gràcia is a thoroughfare rather than a destination in its own right, but a tour of Barcelona without coming here would be deficient. This is the trendiest major shopping street of Barcelona, and a strip of good bars and restaurants, as well as a natural walking route linking interesting architectural sights such as Gaudí's La Pedrera and Casa Batlló. Many top fashion and luxury brand boutiques are located in the 10 city blocks of Passeig de Gràcia between Avenida Diagonal in the north and Plaza Cataluña in the south. Be vigilant against pickpockets and bag snatchers.

Lovely boulevard for a stroll.... Lovely wide boulevard with great shopping, great gelati places. Travel a block do some shopping, another block have a cappuccino, another block try a gelati and to top it all off at the end of a long day shopping and walking have some great Sangria

Very Nice Avenue. we visited this nice avenue in 7/3/2012. such avenue that contains two of the most beautiful buildings of gaudi , La Padrera and Casa Batllo , mush be beautiful. there is a lot of old nice buildings and a lot of cafe shops and shops. good place to just walk and shop. it is more beautiful than the Las Rambla , and more beautiful at night.
beautiful avenue. a walk at night is a must, shops, restaurants, people fom all over the world and the Gaudi buildings are a perfect mix
Walk past the modernista buildings. Big boulevard with shops and cafes, the modernista buildings are all in near proximity.

Every high end store is here. If your trying to do some serious shopping this is where you do it. Every high end store you could look for is on this main strip. There are other stores to at lower price points so you do get a good selection of both.
Great place to shop. Fun place to shop - lots of interesting and big name shops. Good places to eat - but expensive and geared to tourists. Stop in at any Farggi for great coffee and ice-cream!
Beautiful Avenue. Bonita avenida llena de gracia!Beautiful stores of famous world griffes

Gracia's store. It was Paris Champs Elysees that inspired the city to build Passeig de Gracia. Alongside the boulevard’s street cafes through narrow streets to the left and right and its 19th century houses you will discover a virtual paradise for fashion shopping. Shopping Gracia’s stores is always followed by live spanish guitar performance of the Gypses around that echoes the streets and leaves you a lifetime memory to remember.
Very nice shops (expensive). This part of the city is upscaled and has nice Gaudy buildings. Cafes are great here. experience outside dinning euro stye.
nice,... to shop. nice, typical european. a lot of cute little places and also familiar stores.

Shops to die for, and great Gaudi architecture. Many top brands have dedicated shops including Chophard, Chanel, LV, Tumi, Jimmy Choo etc. No lack of places to eat & drink but note that great people watching comes at a price as eating and drinking on the pavement will cost considerably more than being inside.
Favourite part of the city. Great walk around this area taking in the architecture and the best shopping in the city. Just minutes from Las Ramblas
Shopping with all the top brands. All the top brands here, LV, dolce, hugo, some nice cafe's. If you like shopping take a trip.
monumental. The whole boulevard it is like a museum of different stiles of architecture.it was amazing!
Love it. Gracia neighborhood is very nice for strolling and window shopping.
Fashion House paradise. All the big names are here and housed in some fantastic buildings to boot !

get here early. this place always has a line, but if you get here real early or in OFF season, you will have no problem. If you are going in July August or sept, Bring plenty of water and maybe sunscreen. the wait will be up to an hour or more. One of the great structures of Antonio Gaudi. A must see, absolutely, dont come to Barcelona without seeing this and the Sagrada Familia Cathedral.

Beautiful stroll, idyllic for Barcelona. Wonderful atmosphere and if you're looking to avoid the mayhem of the ramblas while still enjoying a very nice people watching walk, head towards this street just a block off the placa de catalunya filled with surprisingly reasonable tapas bars in the typical pedestrian island in the center of the street and take in all the trendy shops and people around every corner. As you head further up the hill you'll also notice a few of the buildings built by Gaudi - in my opinion more beautiful than the sagrada de familia - and just as interestingly designed. Whether summer or winter this neighborhood, further up the road, called Gracia is a must-see, must-stop for at least a tapas or two.

Amazing Broadway with Charming building. Passeig de Gracia ( PDG) is a wide street through the center of Barcelona. It is lined with exquisite buildings, shopping and restaurants on either side. PDG brings out the modern side of Barcelona. We spent some evenings sitting at side cafes and seeing the city go by. It is spectacular.

If Haute fashion is your thing, then you must spend time on Passeig de Gracia. This is one of the main roads in Barcelona and it is lined with some of the bigger brands and bigger stores than most other places in town. There are also two great Gaudi houses on this famous road and 100's of places to eat and drink.

Amazing Shopping and People Watching. You can tell this is 'the place' to walk around in Barcelona. The street is huge and it is filled with all the high end shops one could possibly want. Amazing restaurants and great access to the Metro and Renfe. Our B&B was a block away from here and we felt right athome.
Great shopping. All the big brands...chanel, gucci, bvlgari, jimmy choo, plus some great little tapas places
Classy. Classy street without being snobbish -- not many cosmopolitan cities have class despite being expensive.
Worth strolling around here!. This is a nice street to stroll around do some shopping and have some coffee and cake!
5th Avenue of Barcelona!. Full of great stores and that's also where Casa Batlo is located. Great to walk or just seat and do some people watching.
Need Shooping?. Very comparable to PAris or London except more hip! at least you have options for tapas or a good coffee for a stop over! At least this way you will not get as exhausted :)

Gaudi. Gaudi has two unique buildings on here. The first has the roof of the dragon and the second has a roof terraace with excellent views of Barcelona & the stunning designs! Well worth the €13 to go in and see
Champs Elysees in Barcelona. Beautiful and elegant street. Nice shops, good tapas restaurants. Great buildings, the Gaudi style suits the surroundings here.

Unmistakeably Spain!. Everytime I come here I want to come back. One of the few places in the world that within a small proximity, you have shopping , architecture, food, night life, and fun.If you come to Barca and dont get tapas or paella on Paseo de Gracia it will be a mistake you will regret.One of the best places in all of Europe bar none. Don't forget jazz night at Casa Fuster Hotel on Thursdays!! Wow!!
Great area!!. There are lots of restaurants, shops and the location is central to everything.

love it. love to walk for passeo de gracia all the times, when is sunny, rainning, night day, is just great, love the people walking around and the shops. loads of them everywhere, stop for a nice cafe and have a nice sandwich, love the restaurants there, passeo de gracia is just amazing
Global. Just like one would expect from anywhere peculiar in the world.
like any shopping avenue in europe. Dont expect anything more extraordinary than any shopping avenue in europe
Place to wander and see Gaudi buildings. We wandered up this wide street taking in the architecture as we went.

Nice walk into the heart of Barca. The highlights are the stunning, voluptuous Gaudi buildings, but there are plenty of pleasant (if pricey) bars and cafes on the way from Parc Guell to Placa de la Rambla.

Barcelona at its essence. I walked every day during my trip in Barcelona on this marvelous street, gathering around some of the most interesting buildings of the town. After seeing it, I don`t think I`ll like the same any other large boulevard of Europe:)
what an exciting street. along this street one sees many beautiful and interesting buildings and excellent restaurants and tapas-bars

Beautiful St. Loved this street, I could walk up and down it for hours! Shops are amazing, love all the trees, feels quite personal even though it is a large street. Definitely worth a visit, very clean too!
Beautiful!. Love this area. So clean and lovely to window shop and people watch.

The ideal place to shop, eat and watch the world go by. I think it was when I discovered the Passeig de Gracia that I first fell in one with Barcelona. I never did discover all the shops, as there were just too many. I tried to eat at as many tapas bars as I could, but that was a challenge too. When I was tired from siteseeing, I would return to Gracia to sit with some tapas and a glass of wine and watch the world go by. The locals use this wonderful street for an evening promenade. Elderly couples arm in arm, families with toddlers in strollers, gay couples hand in hand, people in wheelchairs being pushed along. They are all out here taking the evening air between about 5pm - 8pm.
The Michigan/Park Avenue of Barcelona.. If you like shopping and/or people watching, this street is a MUST.
A wet dream for architecture students and style shoppers. Food, shopping, design and architecture all in a gentle stroll. A mustn't miss (free!) visit.
Lovely and Relaxing. Such a nice place to spend a lazy afternoon - wandering around. Real authentic Barelona feel to it. The locals are very friendly and will help out however they can.

Great for a wander. Wandering up and down this most majuestic street full of wonderful architecture and promenading families was a delight. There are amny exclusive shops but we were more interested in the history. But certainly if you wanted to shop this could be the place.We were there around Christmas and the Christmas lights added an extra magic to walking at night.

Fantastic Buildings & Shops but lots of thiefs!!!!. You really need to be be on youre guard, although the area is a must visit it is full of pickpockets. We were aware of crime in Barcelona like any other major tourist city. But was shocked to discover how bad it was. Coming out of the metro station I caught a woman with her hand in my bag. Just standing back and observing It was surprising to see just how many couples were working together to rob the tourists.!!!!

The place to see and be seen in Barcelona. Rolex, Boss, Dolce & Gabana, Burberry, etc. etc. plus Modernisme galore, don't miss a stroll down this lovely boulevard. Great place to grab some fridge magnets and postcards for less than on the touristy la Rambla.

THE "IT" PLACE!. I loved Passeig de Gracia, because it has Gaudi´s buildings ("Casa Batllo" and "La Pedrera") mixed with the signature label shops and elegant hotels. The sidewalk is so pleasant that we had a good mind to stay there all day, during every day. Our hotel was so close there, that we transformed this place in our usual way! Don´t miss Passeig de Gracia experience!

Born ultimatum... The Passeig de gracia is located in my favourite area of the city. The born district is the place to be and all those in the know head here.. make this area a must on your visit to Barcelona.
A "must" avenue to walk through!. Busy, vibrant, artsy, metropolitan, Gaudi buildings, great restaurants, a must.

Tourist street. This was the biggest and most expensive street near our hotel. We used it just to get to the subway. Street was packed with tourists. If you want to be robbed, hang out here. Multinational fashion street.
Shopping Central !. This is full of interesting shops, restaurants, Gaudi attractions! Lots to see and do!

Fun. happening spot, great shopping, well dressed crowd, lots of activity. One might find amazing deals at international brands.
Its a nice walk during the holiday season.
One can get hop on and off at the various metro stops if one finds the walk too long and tiring.
Passeig de Gracia. Full of interesting modernista buildings including Casa Milla and Casa Batlo - a must see in Barcelona
wonderful. Beautiful street full of restaurants, cafes, and fashion shops. Packed with people and very lively. Much nicer street than Rambla.

The most beautiful paseo. JUst love staying right off the paseo de la gracia.. There are so many restaurants, bars, and it is a safe area to be in. It is quiet at night and just perfect. The sightseeing bus stops here .. it is perfect!
5th Avenue in Barcelona?. A very nice business avenue with fashion shops. It is 100x times better then the Rambla.
Shopping street. There are many creations of Gaudi and shops. Shops spanish and international.
Busy and lively. Great place to walk around and see the sights, shopping a plenty.
My favourite street in Barca. This was my favourite street in Barca, the buildings are all so beautiful and the mixture of old and new make for an amazing walk
One of Europe's best streets.. This is one of Europe's best streets for a walk and to spend your money. Classic, elegant, safe and beautiful.
Designer boulevard. great if you're looking for designer gear Furla shop and all the big names
nice part of town for window shopping!. nice neighbourhood with nice feel to it many designer label shops - good tapas bars

Shopping!. Prime retail here in Barcelona's swanky top fashion street. I think the bargains are elsewhere in the city, but this is more than worth a stroll in the sunshine. Some lovely touches in the street furniture.

Barcelona's Rodeo Drive. Beautiful buildings with great window displays not to mention various designers such as Chanel, Valentino just to mention a few. Beautiful light standards with built in benches to give your feet a rest from carrying all your shopping bags
great area. stayed in this area, very safe, very nice. renfe train from here to the airport is very useful

nice fancy shopping street. Here you'll find all famous shops like Mango, Esprit etc but also very expensive boutiques like Carolina Herrera, Chanel etc. Go to the terrasse in the Majestic Hotel and have a drink while enjoying the sunset. It is fantastic.

Upscale shopping your thing?. If you enjoy lovely long urban shopping streets then this is your street. It was lovely to stroll morning, noon, and night. We stayed off this lovely street and walked it daily.
Serious Shopping. What a mecca for designer gear; spacious elegant avenue dotted with stunning buildings
Nice and charming. Great brands and the most luxury place in Barcelona. If you want to spend on expensive clothes, watches, acessories you can find the most important brands of the world.

high class shopping. A nice high class road full of shiny shops and bright lights! If you like shopping in a busy road it is great to go here and should be top priority for shoppers. Some of the shops are more expensive than other areas but not all. Away from plaza Catalunya you can reach Gaudi's casa Battlo and La Pedrera. There are not many cafes/bars on the street but some are on the side streets to get some rest from continuous shopping. Of course you can find many other much more interesting shops and cafes in Barri Gottic!!

Nice Mix with good (luxury) shops. We personally enjoyed this shopping area more than Las Ramblas. Not so hectic and overcrowded (at least when we were there).You can find some really nice local brands with good offers as well as good (luxury) brands within mainly huge shops which makes shopping more convenient. Nice combination is also the overall ambience of the area and the interesting architecture buildings around.

Genuine Barcelona Experience. Go walk the Passeig de Gracia! Incredible people watching abounds. There are many shops, hotels, markets and sites to see and enjoy all along this pedestrian friendly walk.
Wonderful. We loved staying in the Eixample and exploring this whole area on foot. The juxtaposition of architecture alone is fascinating. It's a beautiful area.
dream time. unbeleivable shops unbeleivable prices dont go without seeing this for yourself
Shopping. a huge shopping haven, must not be missed for shopaholics

Excellent to walk from Plaza de Catalunya. This is a very classy street, keep looking up because the buildings are amazing! You will see Gaudi houses and other architects homes up the street. Stop by in any outdoor bar and watch people go by.
It's a place for a nice walk and to people watch!. We went during the day and it was nice to see the people and go into the shops!
Great sites. Great sites and nice restaurants. Take note of the sidewalk pavement stones.
Great people watching. The place to stroll day and night and get a real european feel. Great stores and architecture
Upscale shopping!. Needed much more ttime than we had to do this area justice. The architecture is just beautiful.

Posh shops and swanky restaurants. Clean, smart, business area with some interesting gaudi buildings.
I'm not so into a lot of shops with things that are too expensive for normal people. Some nice little cafes and shops can be found in amongst them.
Shopping & Guadi. Great shops but Guadi buildings better. Some very good restaurants around as well

Passage to Grace. Well, my opinion is bring all the brutal and uneducate dpeople of this world to Passeig de Gracia and let them stroll up and down for a few hours. This will definitely teach them a lesson about what separates humans from beasts. A lesson in art, ingenuity and playfulness, that's what this street is all about...
Very posh. Go for a walk and have a look at the posh side of BCN!
Shopping, sight seeing, everything!. Great area for shopping or seeing great architecture or just people watching. Something for everyone.

Shop till you drop. Other than shopping till you dropped, there are many nice architecture buildings that you can enjoyed. don't forget about nice little tapas places and churros places that you can enjoy while you resting

Worth the walk, Take a camera. This has quite a few unique buildings by Gaudi and Gaudi inspired. It is worth the walk down this street and make sure you take your camera. You can enter many of the buildings but the prices are pretty steep to do so. Worth viewing from the outside though.
Gaudi. The Gaudi buildings are fantastic. What's so great about them is how they still a functioning part of the everyday life of the city.

I could take a walk there every day!. This is a huge open space with so much history and beautiful buildings on it, that I would gladly take a walk there every day. The neighborhood Eixample on both sides is also fun and quite safe.
Great architecture & shopping. A great place to shop & dine that starts from Plaza de Catalunya, some of Gaudí's masterpieces are there to look and see.
nice place. not suprising but very nice to see.... go to ysl!!!!
Finally some Big City Grandeur. with a bit of Gaudi and other heroes of modernism thrown in

Where the really top end shops are. This is a great part of town to walk and stroll. There are all the top end shops selling at top end prices. One little tip though Spain has fantastic sales in January and August and even here there are major major reductions that last at least a month. So for me it's a place to look for 10 months and 2 months to buy!!!

A road with histories. You can't help but marvel at the exterior of the buildings on this road. You will find so many notable buildings on this road, especially the famous Casa Batlló and Casa Ametllér. Take some time to sit and sunk in to the unique architecture designs which you can't find anywhere else in Spain.
shops. You can find all brands and you can see also Casa Batllo and Casa Mila.
fantastic. Amazing park, something different and interesting. must visit the park during your stay in Barcelona

But the street is also the location of two wonderful Gaudi houses - Casa Batlló and La Pedrera, now a museum, so you can easily offset the vulgar with the beautiful!

A Window Shoppers Paradise. It costs you nothing just to amble up this beautiful Avenue and absorb the atmosphere of being in a beautiful place. Shops are lovely though pricey!! Just looking is fine and a great way to spend an afternoon.
from airport a direct train comes to Passeig de Gracia. waling in minutes to de metro net to catch up with the rest of the city

Barcelona's top shopping street. Paseo de Gracia is the top shopping street. All the top names plus arcades with smaller interesting outlets. Some Gaudi buildings. Plenty of restaurants towards the Plaza Catalunya end.
One of the most beautifull streets. Its impossible to miss it. Is imponent with many luxurious shops and many important bildings.

Pure elegance - a joy to stroll along. Wide boulevard, broad pavement, lined with works of art - that is to say fine buildings and beautiful shops. Join the Spanish in an evening stroll along this avenue.

How can you not love Passeig de Gracia. Considering several of Gaudi's masterpieces are here, it does make a visit kind of mandatory. There are several good cafes and one really good Tapas place that makes outdoor dining a people watching experience.
The most "Chic" of Avenues in Barcelona. The Shopping, the Restaurants, the people it was simply awesome, don't miss this attraction!!
woman loves this road. Is the most popular road in Barselona, a shopping street that everyone walks every day or night.

A must see - approx. 1 hour tour is enough. A short tour on this lovely street will expose very interesting buildings with unique architecture.
This street is also famous for its very luxurious shops - for most of us it is only window shopping :-)
Credit card alert!. Great shopping area for all tastes. Spoilt for choice if shopping is your thing.

Shopping haven!. I love Passeig de Gracia. I had the privilege to also stay here while was in BCN and was strolling up and dow for 5 days. Great for shopping, not so good for eating as it can be pricey! and not so good. Go there for shopping and casa Batlo! the eating you can do at Las ramblas

Awesome Architecture. Awesome Architecture, high end shopping, great cafes fantastic for people watching. Lots of bars, restaurants, and shopping, although a bit on the more pricier side, it's a great experience.
Attractive. High end shopping, beautiful architecture, bars, cafes. Nice place to walk, sit in a cafe and people watch. Safer than downtown.

excellent street. lots of nice storers, quite expensive, but really ggod shopping - s/thing like Oxford and Regents street in London
the fifth avenue of Barcelona

Great!. Passeig de Gracia was my favorite area to walk around day or night without issues. One will find people walking anytime of the day. You get a selection of restaurants, high end stores and get to see Casa Batlo and Pedrera all within walking distance. This is a high priced area where more of the locals hang out.
If you love shopping. If you didn't bring an extra suitcase, buy one. You will need it to carry home all the lovely clothes that you buy. Every store you want in one place.
Chic. Our hotel was right next to it. Beautiful avenue, filled with shops, a few restaurants, lovely houses

Terrific !. If you are able, take a great walk from Plaza Catalunya up Passeig de Gracia and see how the "new" Barcelona was meant to be. A wonderful plan and great architecture. You can easily walk past the Gaudi sites and the Block of Discord. Enjoy some good restaurants and tapas bars and shop in high end stores if you wish.

Tourist traps, overpriced shops. If you are from the middle of nowhere it may be interesting to see Chanel/D&G/Armani stores that charge €120 for a t-shirt. If you are super rich it may be fun to buy these things. If you are neither, you will probably feel the same way I do about it.The restaurants are all tourist tapas places, bad food for too much money.

Passeig De Gracia. THis is also a must see for the extraordinary Modernisme Architecture on this street. You can start up at La Pedrera and walk down tot he Placa Catalunya and take in most of it. The people watching and shopping is also great
Location. Perfect hotel location. We enjoyed the walks and shopping.
Great place to roam about in the city... Nice place to walk up and down with great shopping, sights and more. Pencil this in for your visit to Barcelona.
Loved it - amazing architecture. My fiance is a Gaudi fan, and I knew nothing about him until I went to the Passeig de Gracia. Beautiful rooms, so much to see. Definitely worth the money.

Great neighborhood!. What a great area! Lots of high end shops, restaurants and overall nice area to walk around. The tourist bus does drive you through here as well, if you aren't able to walk a lot. Definitely a nice part of Barcelona, that is worth exploring!

Enjoy the architecture and cafes. Love this street!! The architecture is amazing on all the different buildings, especially the Gaudi houses- Casa Batllo and Mila. There are nice cafes along here too. Very upscale and nice to just stroll.

Melting ice cream. This streets bustles with tourist craning their necks to see multiple examples of early “moderisme” architecture by Antoni Gaudi, Lluis Domenech Montaner, Puig Cadafalch and others. Be prepare to take way toooo many photos and dodge traffic trying to get that perfect shot. Also, please keep in mind where there are crowds of tourists, you will also encounter pickpockets. Please be alert. One place that is normally not mentioned in guide books is a business building called “Vincon” just up from Gaudi’s Casa Mila, which we called “melting vanilla ice cream.” Vincon is an upscale interior design store spaced about on several levels. The second floor has stunning moderiste wood pillars, ceilings and an ornately designed fireplace. And on that same floor there is a delightfully quiet outdoor courtyard with views of the side of Casa Mila. And once you step foot into that peaceful courtyard, the noise from Passeig de Garcia melts away.

OMG shops everywhere. having been to paris and monte carlo, these have nothing on barcelona, the amount of shops is incredible, all the high class shops you can imagine, honestly it makes the champs elysees look like a little back street boutique.
Barcelona's Rodeo Drive. Very posh -- fun to see. The most beautiful street in Barcelona.
Heaven for shopaholics. This street is full of shops and restaurants. If you like shoping it will be heaven for you.

Invigorating Stroll. After the crowded Ramblas, a stroll on the clean and attractive Passeig de Gracia is a welcome relief. Window shopping and site seeing are fun & relaxing. You can also find reasonably priced local restaurants for a fine snack or a main meal.
Casa Batllo by Gaudi - a Must see in Barcelona. THIS is the Gaudi house you MUST see inside. It is worth the wait (usually there is quite a line at the entrance) and every penny.

Lovely walk. I wouldn't count this as a tourist site, but it's a lovely walk, and you'll see both of Gaudi's most famous apartment buildings. And of course all the designer label stores lining the street. Ends at the south with Plaza de Catalyun, and the beginning of Las Ramblas.
Delightful street!. Great street for strolling! Lots of shops to browse & several of the Gaudi buildings to see!

Passeig de Gracia--Plaza Catalunya--a great Stroll. Lots of fun cafes, shops, and stores along these avenues.
You can take metros to Passeig de gracia, have a drink in Casa Fuster an old historic hotel!
Stylish Shopping Station. whether you like window shopping or actual shopping this is a must visit for all the big name stores.
old and modern. This part of the city never sleeps, beautiful, engulfing and just simply great to see
Great place for a stroll. If high-end shopping is your thing, this is the street for it. If not, it's still worth a stroll, just to admire the architecture and the Gaudi buildings.
A Good Stroll. Interesting walking street. Interesting people and great shops.

This is one of the most beautiful avenues in the whole world.... Passeig the Gracia is total worth to visit it...it is an amazing avenue which goes crosses barcelona from the sea to the mountain...is the mnost glamourous avenue in barcelona...were all the best shops of fashions have their own shop....i total recommend a walk in paseo de gracia

Equity Point Centric hostels location. It is high end shopping with great tapas cafes, excellent for strolling on a beautiful or rainy day. Las Ramblas is all tourists, Passeig de Gracia is all locals....stroll with the locals it is amazing

Great shopping. 2nd most famous street in BCN next to Las Ramblas. Great shopping and people watching all over. Some of the restaurants are tourist traps and expensive. Close to several of Gaudis sights.
Spent a lot of time up and down this street.. Very convenient with lots of places to stop and have some Tapas. Casa Batllo was located on this street
Great street. Fun window shopping, strolling street--lovely and lively.
one of the most beautiful streets in Europe. A wide, tree lined avenue, very clean and pleasant, with beautiful shops and buildings
A must.. It's a wonderful avenue to walk. You have lot of restaurants, and lots of places to buy. All great brands are here. And you can also visit Casa Batllo y Casa Mila which are fabulous.

Nice street. Lots of shops, the better restaurants and cafes are off of this main road. Avoid the chain tapas places as they are crap and overpriced. Check out Gaudi's buildings, truly an incredible sight.
Make sure you allow enough time to walk this from one end to the other.... Great shopping precinct and the architecture of the buildings along this strip are stunning !

The Passeig de Gracia Is a Wonderful Place to Stroll. The Passeign de Gracia is a wonderful place to stroll, from the Plaza de Catalunya to the Diagonal. There are two Gaudi masterpieces here, namely Casa Mila and Casa Batllo. Most of the buildings are very elegant and are well maintained. There are very many international designer stores, showing that many Barcelona people have plenty of money. Even if one cannot afford anything from these stores, it is still entertaining to see their show windows and what goods they offer. There are very many jewelry stores also, with a display of gems that only the rich can afford. However there is a place called El Bulevard Rosa at Passeig de Gracia, 53, which is like a small shopping mall with small stores, but stores that are very affordable. Most of them are clothing and shoe stores, and many stores for baby clothes too. What I enjoy about this street is that the sidewalks are very wide, so even if there are hundreds of people walking on the street, one does not feel cramped because there is very much space. The thing I enjoy most is looking up the buildings and see the decorations on their facades. Very original. It is too bad that modern architects cannot learn anything from these elegant buildings. Modern architects are in love with minimalism, which does not go well with me. A little decoration on the façade of buildings will make streets more beautiful. Anyway, this is my favorite street in Barcelona.
Walk, walk, walk. Wonderful street to people watch, sit at an outdoor cafe and view the architecture!

Shopping and taking a stroll in style. This is the upscale area of Barcelona, all the traffic as Las Ramblas, but not the tourist restaurants and goofy entertainment. This area is sophisticated. Great neighborhoods designed by Gaudi and other famous architects, luxury shopping, nice restaurants that take reservations, and many metro stops for convience.
Lived on it! Great Street with shops and restaurants. Great place for a stroll. Nice cafe and some good restaurants. Recommend Citrus. very good value for money
Wonderful place to walk, eat and shop. Loved the outdoor sitting caffees till late at night, beautiful stores and buildings

great shopping and interesting houses to admire. A leisurely stroll along here gives you great shopping and plenty of interesting architecture to look at . THere are many good restaurnats in the area.

perfect shopping area and more!. After visiting La Pedrera and Casa Batlló both of which are in this avenue, take a break in one of the restaurants, there’re lots of them. And then have a lazy walk down to Catalonia Square. It’s a perfect shopping area! Expensive, yes, but offering authentic brands – really high quality. And there’re discounts, you won’t find, say, Jimmy Choo’s leather for this money in Moscow.
The two Gaudi Buildings. This would be an ordinary street were it not for the two attention-getting Gaudi buildings. They are a little difficult to locate, but you certainly know when you see the!

A beautiful Street. The architecture and shopping on Passeig de Gracia are fabulous. Don't forget to check out the beautiful paving stones that seem to light up in the setting sun. There are also a number of restaurants lining the street.
Busy but good shopping. Even in October, it was super busy, but there's great shopping and lots of places to eat.

if you like moderhiste architecture this is the street to walk up. A great shopping street with really nice restaurants. The building are absolutely fabulous. Gaudi's Casa Milia; Casa Batllo; Cadafalch's Casa Amatller; Muntaner's Casa Lico Morera are all along this street between Placa Catalunya and Ave. Diagonal. it's called the block of Discordia and it doesn't cost a dime Unless you elect to visit Gaudi's Casa Batllo & Casa Milia (La Pedrera)
Madison Avenue Revisited. Having grown up in NYC, I didn't feel the need to be shopping on a fancy street! I can do this in NYC. I like the "old Spain" better...each to their own!

such wide streets. Great area what buildings,easy to get to .IF you want shopping this looked the place to go,has easy access by the merto.Rather a busy pavement as so many people going to the same buildings,not to be missed tho
Great area to stroll about. Again, lots of interesting bars and shops that you won't find in any other city. Very authentic.
Window Shop or Bring Lots of Money. Fantastic window shopping. Fantastic shopping. Both side of the plaza and the surrounding area. Fairly expense, very designer oriented.

Great food and shopping. This is a great street and we always felt safe here. Food and shopping wit hgreat people watching fron the street seating that most restaurants have. We went here several nights and really loved.

Shopping Heaven. shopping shopping shopping.
i was in heels and my legs were almost crying.. Wear comfortable shoes.
Casa Batllo and LaPrera-Casa Mila can easily be spotted.
im not sure if this is normal for Europe but toilets are VERY hard to find unless you are having a meal in the cafe.

Barcelona's most fashionable avenue. Passeig de Gracia is the major shopping avenue in Barcelona with all the luxury and high end brands. It is a wide boulevard which leads straight to Plaza Catalunya. In addition to all the shops, it is the location for 2 famous buildings by Gaudi. The combination of unique art noveau buildings, beautiful greenery and endless fashionable stores make Passeig de Gracia a place not to miss when visiting Barcelona. Just make sure that you don't go there on a Sunday or during a public holiday as all stores will be closed.

Electrifying atmosphere. The main shopping street in Barcelona with showrooms of all major international brands. Connected to La Rambla but more sophisticated and less crowded. The main departmental store "El Corte Ingles" and famous Gaudi Buildlings Casa Mila and Casa Batlo are also located on Passeig de Gracia.

So much culture on one street. Each building is made with so much soul. Not just Gaudi's masterpieces but some many other masterminds. While you walk down the street, don't just gawk at all the shopping to do (as there is a lot) but take a look at each of the buildings and the detail work that was put into each of them. Learning about their history was just as fun so check out "Hi...This is Barcelona" and ask for their outdoor museum tour ;)

Much nicer and more enjoyful then La Rambla. This street is really nice with exclusive stores for window shopping and really nice building, it's a perfect place to stroll around and it's much better then La Rambla.Enjoy a beer and watch the people pass by :-)
Walk Along This Street If You Have The Time. I had a really good time walking on this street. Far better than the overated La Rambla. It's filled with architectural miracles.

Beautiful avenue. We just passed once through Passeig Gràcia and I found it very lovely. Along it we find beautiful buildings such as Casa Batló and La Pedrera. But there is much to see along the avenue. I'm sorry not to have walked through it. I’ve just saw it along my Bus Turistic ride.

This Gives A Whole New Meaning To The Song "Funky Town". To be honest our goal was to see the Island of Discord and the Pedrera, which was amazing. To us there was a lot of interesting architecture all over Barcelona and the Passeig de Gracia was just a bonus.
The most beautiful avenue in Barcelona. This is the best avenue in Barcelona. Amazing Gaudi’s buildings, great shops and boutiques, nice café and restaurants. Make sure you walk there on night too.

Beautiful Walk. I love this avenue!! So much to see and experience. If you like Gaudi and Gaudi inspired work, this is a walk that could take you an entire day. One beautiful building after another to admire, as you get a good sense of an authentic slice of Barcelona life in the process -- this is not a particularly touristy part of the city, despite having a couple very famous Gaudi buildings along it -- Casa Batllo and La Pedrera (Casa Battlo is especially worth visiting!!) Make sure to walk not only through the Eixample district just north of Plaza Catalunya, but into the Gracia neighborhood that continues along the northern stretch of Passeig de Gracia, past the Diagonal (the other wide boulevard that crosses Passeig de Gracia).
Enchanting. What wonderful street full of fabulous architecture. Gaudi on both sides and all around, what a treat to be lucky enough to have my hotel room next door to a fab building. love the place!
